author: {'steamid': '76561197968810923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1609161026}
review:
Decent, inexpensive study aid. The game itself is a very basic RPGmaker game where you have to identify hiragana characters in order to attack and defeat them. The progression through the hiragana syllabary is reasonably paced, introducing five characters at a time (plus dakuten). Writing the characters is not part of the gameplay, but the stroke order is shown and the player is encouraged to practice on paper. Some introductory vocabulary is also taught, though it is not the focus of the game.

However, the game mechanics have not been polished to work well with this premise, meaning menuing attacks is a chore, offensive magic is non-existent, and "overkill" attacks are simply wasted (since they will hit a non-matching character). Also, aside from the different characters identifying them, enemies within a given area are pretty much identical and all have the same attacks. The enemies within the encounters are also not randomized: there are just a few predetermined sets of enemy characters, and after spending any amount of time in a given area, groups of enemies will start looking familiar, which is not great for learning.

Level design is also rather tedious. Frequently, you will reach the end of a map, only to discover you need an item at the other end, forcing you to backtrack. Worse, you cannot even pick up the item until you've already reached the obstacle that requires it to pass. Furthermore, encounters happen randomly and do not even stop happening after an area is "cleared," resulting in exploration becoming truly obnoxious. At least it's easy to flee battles, but that sort of defeats the game's purpose.

The economy is also poorly paced. There is no point in buying weapons past the first tier since you will find better ones before you can afford upgrades. Money is much better spent on armor, the top tiers of which will make you basically invincible.

This game needs a remake to bring it up to the level of the subsequent games, which are still RPGmaker games but have largely fixed the above issues. You do not have to play this game first to play the subsequent games, so if your hiragana skills are already pretty good, skip this one and move on to Katakana War or Kanji Combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561199049790103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 3975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3975, 'last_played': 1607361810}

author: {'steamid': '76561198263625706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1657130032}
review:
This Game is in itself really good for what it's trying to do

you learn the Hiragana Characters and you defeat those with what you've learned about them

The story is obviously not the moste serious and at some point a real Laughing stock but it does the Job. 

My only negative, as an advice for the Developer, is following.

try to balance the Amount of characters you have to fight during each section.

It is a good way to fight the characters how you do to memorize them more but it's not good if you encounter some Characters 10 times while don't meet some of the others at all.

I for one already learned some basic japanese privately so i don't have that much issues but if you start that game as a total beginner it will actively influence your ability to memorize certain characters especially if you seriously want to learn the Language.

other then that its does it's Job really well so 8/10 for what it wants to be

author: {'steamid': '76561198062165805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1608956793}
review:
If I had to describe this game in one word it would be "tedious.‚Äù 

[b]The dungeons are tedious.[/b]
The game frequently features locked doors that require backtracking to get the key or whatever Mcguffin to unlock the forward path. It's more annoying when you know it's coming, but can't push the button or find the key until you check that the door is locked. It's a lazy way to pad the gameplay and it's made even worse by all the random encounters along the way. I suppose you could argue in this case that more random encounters means more chances for learning the hiragana characters, but....

[b]The random encounters are tedious.[/b]
Random encounters are normally pretty tedious, but this game makes them even slower than a normal RPGs because only the correct answer "attack" will do any damage, so you have to scroll through an ever expanding list of characters as you progress. You are going to want to have "command remember" on in this game and possibly use a mouse instead of the arrow keys so you can somewhat limit all the scrolling you'll have to do. I can't come up with a better solution, but having to scroll through 46 characters and their variations, but it's annoying when you have to do it for four heroes.

To make matters worse the hiragana warriors are not lined up the same on the battlefield as they are in the sub-menus. Pressing down on the enemy list takes you to the right on the field and pressing right in the menu takes you down on the field. I‚Äôm not sure if this is an RPG Maker quirk or design flaw specific to this game. When you kill an enemy, if other heroes were going to attack that enemy, they will use their readied attacks on the next available enemy, which 100% of the time results in them using the wrong attacks and zero damage, since you will not encounter more than one of same enemy in a battle. These kinds of mistakes may eventually diminish as you progress and learn which heroes are faster, which are stronger and how much HP the enemies generally have, but this could have been remedied if the game simply displayed enemy HP so you don't overkill on enemies.

These two things often lead to the player fumbling the correct answer on the wrong enemy resulting in a wasted turn of no damage and unnecessary confusion, which takes you out of the game and out of learning mode.


[bSmall complaints:[/b]

Equipment
I personally never earned enough yen from the battles to even afford the second tier of weapons for all the characters, before I was handed the third tier for free by one of the dungeons, which also made the battles feel less rewarding. Also, since third tier of weapons was handed out mid-dungeon it made the issue with overkilling enemies more prevalent until I re-learned how strong the characters were.

Vocabulary words
The game teaches vocabulary, but it often teaches words that contain kana the player has not yet learned. Furthermore, most of the words taught are shown in a mishmash of romaji and hiragana. This is not good for someone learning the kana for the first time. While teaching hiragana is the point of the game, the vocabulary isn‚Äôt included in the combat (only in a few side quests or NPC dialogue), so it almost seems tacked on for no real reason.


==========================

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
If you‚Äôre interested in this game because you want to learn Japanese or for a fun game experience, I would suggest looking elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198251156872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1637454259}
review:
Something I always try to remember, is that education is a journey, not a race. I say this because there are faster, dare I say better ways to learn Hiragana than by playing this game, people who can devote themselves to a task could easily get them learnt in a couple of weeks.

This is the way to go for everyone else. If you're anything like me, this game is a Godsend for this sort of thing. You'll learn a script or two, and some basic words and phrases, but sooner or later try to come to terms with the fact that learning Japanese, along with any language, is a lot of books and revision; you aren't going to learn it through fun little games like this. HOWEVER, not only do I find that this game is still a fantastic place to start, it's also skyrocketed my confidence that I can learn another language, I went to one of the worst schools in England at the time, and my passion for education still struggles to recover from that, but this game not only made me feel confident in learning Japanese, it made me damn well enjoy it, even the boring textbook stuff. I mean, the game starts in a snowy field, how could that *not* pull me in?

Anyone who wants to learn Japanese but doesn't know where to start, start here, this will build you a strong foundation from the ground up I promise you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205489499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1204, 'last_played': 1650658409}

author: {'steamid': '76561198300747804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1607405888}
review: As an RPG it's mediocre but as a learning tool it is bound to be helpful.  It's basically a memory training device where you 'fight' hiragana symbols in rpg battle by choosing the correct translation.  The lessons are nicely set up and even show you how to write the characters if you want to start learning that too.  Realistically this is just a small first step in learning another language but it gives you some variety and a fun context to learn with.  The additional vocabulary and cultural details add as well.  Tediosity is going to be your real worst enemy in language learning so having a game to learn part of language could help you to keep at it.  The interface isn't perfect as others have mentioned but that doesn't cut into the study aspect much as you are trying to build by repetition.  Story and characters are ok but generic, don't expect the best rpg ever.  I paid less than a dollar.  Might want to wait for a sale and get all three titles if you are a serious learner.

review:
Also vorab: Wer meint mit diesem Spiel kann er locker Japanisch lernen... nein leider nicht. 

Japanisch ist viel zu komplex um es so zu lernen, aber es kann helfen, ich lerne derzeit Japanisch per Busuu und da kommt mir aber das Programm gerade richtig. 

Wieso: 

Weil eine Sprache auch immer √ºber die Schrift geht, es wie bei der Buchhaltung, die Basics m√ºssen einfach sitzen, und Basics bei einer Sprache sind eben nun mal die Schriftzeichen, ob Hiragana oder Katakana.
Und da hilft das Spiel extremst, die Wiederholung der Schriftzeichen, es geht schnell man lernt neben dem Zocken und pr√§gt sich besser die Schriftzeichen ein. 

Sicherlich, die Story ist ein wenig fade und es ist das Standartsetup vom RPG Maker  aber schaut einfach dar√ºber hinweg. Ich finde es bisher klasse, gerade um Schriftzeichen zu √ºben, das diese besser sitzen. 

Erwartet aber keine Megastory oder das ich Zeichen schreiben k√∂nnt in dem Spiel, geht leider nur per Auswahl, aber das ist ok, sicherlich bei 75 Zeichen ist es dann schon m√ºhsam zu suchen, aber dabei ist der Lerneffekt ja auch mit dabei. 

Ich habe mir alle 3 Teile nun f√ºr 5 Euro gesamt geschossen und daf√ºr ist es echt ok!!.. die 5 Euro sind gut angelegt.. finde ich. Aber muss jeder selber wissen, ich benutz es gerne um meine Schriftzeichen zu √úben und zu verbessern, f√ºr den rest hab ich derzeit Busuu

author: {'steamid': '76561198045788951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1657455907}
review:
I buyed this product to learn hiragana in a funny way.
But this piece of software fails in both way, as a game and as a teaching software.

The idea to mix both, playing and learning is good, but this game fails just cause the developers didnt put any effort in the interface. They just take the provided interface the "rpg maker" provides by default, and that is a very annoying interface. 

Here are the main points what make this game unplayable and fails to be a good teaching product:

1. You learn the hiragana syllables in little tutorials, and these tutorials have no repeating mode which ask you the new learned hiraganas, until your error rate goes under a specific value.
You learn by repeating and there is no switch in the tutorials or in the very short test that follows to do that repeated learning.

2. After you learned some hiraganas you go on mission where you fight against monster hiraganas. You have to fight them by selecting the right romaji (which describes how to spell a hiragana with latin letters). 
And this is the biggest negative point in this game. For example you see a „Åã monster and now have to fight it with the right "ka" attack. So you have to choose this attack out of a list of 
5 in Level 1
15 in Level 2
25 in Level 3
(this will go up to ~75)
And with level 3 all the fun is gone cause you have to search the right attack out of an big list. There i stop to play this game. That is slow and not funny. Where is the point to play a learning game that has no fun.
I decided to use raw learning websites that ask you over and over again for the correct answer and see my success rate rising over 90% was more fun that the game. And that with less time. With ~30 minutes a day i learned the first 35 hiraganas (inc. dakuten) in 3 days with ~88% hit rate.
It really needs an interface where you can type in the right answer instead selecting it out of a list.

3. They dont support the learning rate with playing the vocal sound when you fight the hiraganas. With playing the sound you would be able to learn faster and learn the right spelling of it by the way. And the sound quality of the spoken hiraganas is not good at all.

Cannot recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043821953', 'num_games_owned': 397, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1605977742}

author: {'steamid': '76561198364545558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1606472808}
review: Great game but it became a little rushed at the end. The content creators clearly realized including a bit of vocabulary and specially grammar basics can significantly help the learners to get a grasp of the big picture and inspire players to further study Japanese on their own. However it was a bit too late (just before the final boss) to introduce the grammar stuff and the vocab lessons were clearly designed as low priority side quests so to me it seemed like a missed opportunity. Aside from this point, the game is fun and informative and I'm definitely gonna try the Katakana war. Hopefully there will be more grammar and vocab lessons there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159426714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1610460602}
review:
A fun way for beginners to get a handle on Japanese hiragana and learn some basic vocabulary along the way. The tutorials are excellent, going over each character and how to write it. They also provide some basic vocabulary, along with "side quests" to help you practise it. 

For the main missions, you have to find various objects to complete an area, while facing random battles against "hiragana warriors" along the way. The way to beat these "warriors" is to correctly identify them - a fun way to learn and really drill the characters into you. You have four "allies" who take turns attacking the "warriors" and can be attacked in turn (there are various weapons and cures to help your "allies"). If I have one complaint about these battles, it's not always very clear to me which "ally" is supposed to attack which "warrior". Quite often I will correctly identify a character, but the "ally" will attack the wrong "warrior". It's most irritating.

Still, if you want to get started in Japanese, this is not too shabby an introduction. Of course, you need to learn the katakana and kanji once you've mastered the hiragana, but these guys have made companion games for that! They have all the bases covered. I reckon by the time you're done, you should be able to read Japanese hiragana quite proficiently and be able to say at least some basic phrases. So it's a great way to start, or a handy supplement to an existing course (I use it in conjunction with Duolingo's Japanese course). So also worthwhile as a study aid if you're doing a beginner course elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201528455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1605197619}
review: Having already known Hiragana, this was a bit slow paced in its teaching of the characters, but for a beginner, I think this pace is really good. In the matter of about 10 hours I beat the game, so I'd say maybe around 15 hours to learn hiragana by this method? Which is pretty good, if you ask me. It also gives you vocab and very minor grammar points. A good place to start off, if you need an RPG maker game to help you study or recap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136430622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1615210584}
review: This game is incredible. I'm a student at university doing a year abroad in Japan, and it's so invaluable. For the last 8 weeks I've been struggling to learn the hiragana- "I'm bored, it's boring, bugger it lets go watch suits on Netflix". I'm not good at motivating myself to do boring things. This game feels like I'm cheating- I've memorised nearly all the hiragana in about eight hours. I went to sleep last night, woke up and I still had them memorised. The vocab sections are amazing too. I can't wait to do this with katakana and kanji. I'm way ahead of the rest of my Japanese class simply because of this one game. It's incredible. Best purchase I've ever made and I could not recommend a game more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084076229', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1689885407}
review:
Quer aprender o b√°sico de japon√™s? Ou melhor, memorizar cada Hiragana que existe, mas acha ma√ßante os m√©todos de estudo? Porque seus problemas acabaram! Esse jogo serve muito bem para se acostumar com Hiragana e tamb√©m te d√° o b√°sico de vocabul√°rio para come√ßar a aprender japon√™s! 
O jogo √© um RPG em que as batalhas voc√™ e sua party luta contra "Hiragana warriors" ou os kanas. Ganhar experi√™ncia nesse jogo √© menos um ciclo repetitivo desgastante, pois voc√™ est√° treinando sua mente com as batalhas, aprendendo cada vez mais Hiragana.
Estou na terceira semana estudando Hiragana e Katakana, o primeiro n√≠vel j√° est√° completo. At√© o final do jogo estarei com cada kana no sangue! E sempre vou poder voltar ao jogo para mais.

review: Surprisingly fun rpg. went in with 0 hiragana experience finished the game in 16 hours and am confident I can read and  remember 90% of hiragana characters easily. the repetitive nature of rpgs means you'll be spending plenty of time with each character to remember them, and each set of characters has its own location you can revisit if you need a reminder.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073816937', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1604859910}
review:
So... I'm gonna start by saying that I'm a person who learned a bit of Japanese before. However, the alphabets don't really stick to me and I was hoping to find a way to force them into my brain using something more fun than flashcards (ugh). Well...

4 hours into this game and I went to my wishlist and removed other titles from this series. 

It's bad. Frustrating. And it distracts you from learning with bad design choices. 

Look, initial lessons are done quite okay, it's done 5 signs at a time, in order, you can see how they are written and what sound they make. Cool. Then you go off on an adventure, right? Technically, yes, but, my dog, that is a one turd of an adventure. 

[u]Premise[/u] is boring - a bad guy shows up, does damage, you have to learn Japanese to defeat him. Written like could seem potentially okay. But its delivery in-game is not. I literally couldn't be more disinterested after the initial scenes. And store page has the audacity to say "exciting story". LOL. 

[u]Characters[/u] are boring. I don't even remember their names and I stared at those for quite a while now. 

[u]Jokes[/u] are boring too. There was one (literally one) dialogue so far, that made me smile but for whatever reason I can't take screenshots in game, so it's gone forever. And I don't even remember now what it was about, so probably nothing worthwhile. 

[u]Fights.[/u] This is my main criticism. Fights are extremely tedious. EXTREMELY. To attack an enemy once you need to 
1. select the hero
2. select if they attack or do other things
3. select the enemy hiragana sign
4. select the right sound that sign makes from a long list
5. accept
All that for one hero to attack a sign once. It wouldn't be too bad in a regular j-rpg style game, where these attacks can really vary and stuff, sure. But this game is supposed to teach you an alphabet and I can surely think of better ways to direct focus towards learning, instead of "try not to missclick in the menu while doing the same steps four times". 
Imagine how nice it would be if there would be only three steps: 
1. select the hero
2. Select attack
3. [b]type in[/b] the sound using your [b]keyboard[/b]. 
Revolutionary, I know, using the keyboard like that. It would improve the gameplay 100% and maybe I wouldn't be so annoyed with it.  

All the enemies are the same - so, hiragana. Their attacks don't really differ, it all falls flat and becomes boring very very early in the game.

Fights happen all the time. You enter the location - there are chests you want to reach and a passage north. Every few steps, a fight. Even worse, I reached all the chests, fought countless fights, reached the passage only to learn I need wood to build a bridge over it. And that I can get wood on the other side of that location (so basically, backtrack to the entrance). I try to do that and after two steps... a fight again. That was a spot where I ragequitted for the day. And let me tell you, these fights are not getting better, further in the game. 

Enemies don't have health bars!!!!!! Game, what the hell. How am I supposed to fight when I don't know enemies health, order of the attacks during the turn, anything useful? It wasn't a rare occasion when I scheduled attacks to defeat one sign and it died after the first and the rest of the attacks went to waste. However you square it, stripping gameplay of important information for no reason is just bad user experience. 

[u]Equipping items[/u]? Yeah, this is bad on its own. It should be transparent and easy to manage. It is not. 

[u]Game speed[/u]
Everything in game is SLOW. Animations are slow and unskippable, choosing any items or attacks is unnecessarily complicated, some of dialogues and quests are really redundant and only slow you down even more. 

[u]Pet peeve[/u]: game teaches you keyboard setting that doesn't work (like it cues WASD for walking but only arrows work) 

--

I don't feel I'm any close to finishing this game but I guess I'll have mercy on myself this time. It really makes flashcards and duolingo lessons [b]interesting[/b] and [b]fresh[/b]. Go figure. 

Also, by the way, I think that out of all these hours I've spent in-game, maybe 15% of it had anything done with Japanese. The rest is walking, fight's menu, managing items and boring dialogue. And none of that is appealing in the slightest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077399574', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 978, 'last_played': 1633814240}
review: Nice way to learn the basics of Hiragana and a few words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018117897', 'num_games_owned': 2025, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1603753596}
review:
While the Japanese Lessons are actually pretty good, the gameplay surrounding it is not so great. It plays like your standard rpg-maker game, but I find it has very little depth or fun to it. The gameplay is actually [b]so[/b] monotonous that it manages to distract me from the lessons themselves. 

Learn Japanese to Survive can be an ok learning tool if you manage to ignore the boring gameplay, but I personally really could not do that. I want to learn Hiragana, but I can't really learn much of anything when the gameplay almost puts me to sleep. Also keep in mind that this game is more for beginners than anything else. You learn Hiragana and some basic words, but that's about it. It's a very good start, but not much more. 

However, I don't think this is a completely garbage game. In fact I actually think this is a pretty good game overall, especially for beginners! It's not perfect or spectacular, but for the most part it's definitely pretty nice. It's just the monotonous gameplay that ruins the experience for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198832119803', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1603749910}
review: Don't go into it expecting an amazing RPG experience, it's pretty bare-bones in terms of story and design. But that's absolutely not the point of the game. As a fan of the genre, the RPG approach was engaging enough to keep me playing and was a really fun way to learn. The game is broken up well into digestible chunks so you build your knowledge base without it ever feeling too overwhelming. I'll definitely be continuing the series to learn Katakana and Kanji.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965186284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1600610067}
review:
Although certainly no expert in Japanese, I already knew Hiragana quite well before starting this game. I haven‚Äôt had any real practice of it in a long time though, so I felt like running through this game would be a good refresher and I was curious at how long it would take me.

That was just under five and a half hours, which included all the side quests the game offers. The in-game timer is greatly inaccurate though, showing double that.

As much of my previous experience with Japanese was from Slime Forest Adventure, a very similar Japanese learning RPG, I can‚Äôt help but compare this game to it.

A substantial issue I had with this game is that it‚Äôs running on an RPG Maker engine, which really showed some limitations of building this type of learning game around it. In Slime Forest, when needing to enter an answer, you simply typed it from your keyboard. This game though, you constantly are needing to scroll through menus for the attack you want.

It‚Äôs made worst as each party member keeps a history of their last attack. Although generally what you would want in a usual RPG, I felt it was more of an annoyance here. While playing, I did gradually become used to it though.

The whole RPG element makes this far more of a game then an educational tool, finding Slime Forest to provide a much better learning experience. In particular, the random battles here are exactly that; random. There‚Äôs no attempt to focus you on what needs improvement, and there‚Äôs also a factor of managing an entire party, rather than focusing on the Hiragana itself.

On a positive note, despite using templated assets, the graphics were nice, along with decent music. There‚Äôs a story but it‚Äôs very generic, along with its characters, not that you would expect otherwise on a game like this.

Overall though, I can‚Äôt recommend this as a learning tool. Slime Forest is the superior Japanese learning game, having a great deal more content as well, despite the poor graphics and lack of sound. Unfortunately, it doesn‚Äôt hold up much better as a game either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063431965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1559, 'last_played': 1600411871}

author: {'steamid': '76561198385666083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 946, 'last_played': 1599678647}
review:
Bon. Pour une question de pr√©f√©rence, j'ai commenc√© par les kanjis (la fin, en terme de jeu). Du coup, j'√©value mieux les forces et faiblesses de cette s√©quence.

[b]L'histoire[/b] est vraiment peu cr√©dible (tout particuli√®rement un certain plan d'attaque ennemie), mais reste l'√©l√©ment le moins important.

[b]Viabilit√© technique et m√©canique de jeu[/b]
Un seul crash sur l'ensemble de la partie, yatta ! R√©el soulagement par rapport au dernier-n√© qui m'obligeait √† sauvegarder √† l'issue de chaque combat (m√™me vieux PC, Windows 10 x64).
Il y a quelques d√©fauts du c√¥t√© de l'interface, les maps sont trop grandes et les random encounters p√©nibles... ce qui est r√©gl√© dans l'opus des kanjis. Merci aux joueurs pour les retours et d√©veloppeurs pour les correctifs ! Les groupes d'ennemis sont peu vari√©s (et le resteront, mais passons).

[b]P√©dagogie[/b]
Je ne suis pas fana de l'hiragana et reste un peu f√¢ch√©e avec, mais ce jeu m'a aid√©e √† faire un premier pas vers la r√©conciliation. Il est plus que dommage que les syllabes et mots ne soient pas lus afin d'aider √† la m√©morisation, dans ce premier volet.

En bref, le bundle sold√© ne mange pas de pain - le prix d'une baguette ou deux, √† la r√©flexion ! -, vous serez servi si vous cherchez une √©tape pr√©liminaire aux manuels et dictionnaires bilingues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105034993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 1040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1610984519}
review:
I learned more from the first few hours of this game than I did from months of Duolingo. I'm not sure if that means this game is really good or just that I suck at learning from Duolingo, but either way this game really helped me. It goes through all the Hiragana characters, generally about 5 at a time, explaining how they are used and how to write them. You then get plenty of revision by fighting Hiragana enemies you have to defeat by correctly identifying them. There are also plenty of side-quests that teach you vocabulary - for instance, one side quest teaches you the names of food in a cafe and how to order them - and a lot of the writing for the side quests is legitimately hilarious. I won't spoil any of the jokes, but I laughed out loud at a fair few of them.
The game plays like old-school Dragon Quest, right down to the little details like the little musical chime that plays when you rest at an inn, and as a long-time fan of Dragon Quest this made it lots of fun to learn Japanese. I didn't view playing the game as work, it was something I did for enjoyment.
The only thing you really need to remember before you buy the game is to make sure you have pens and paper with you, take notes on everything you learn, and constantly revise your notes. Play this daily, and you'll have Hiragana memorised in no time! Then you can move on to Katakana... then Kanji... Oh God, the Kanji...

author: {'steamid': '76561198306015037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1510, 'last_played': 1597457405}
review: This game has been really helpful in getting me to actually memorize hiragana. I've wanted to learn Japanese for years, but it's easy to forget to study when there isn't a memorable and engaging way to do so. If I were to make one suggestion it would be that the developers try to fix one of the lessons of phrases. It lists "Africa" as a country under the phrase "Watashi wa Amerika jin desu". Africa is a continent and not a country so simply changing it out for a country in Africa (Like South Africa, Ethiopia, or any of the other nations of the world's second largest continent) seems like it should be a simple fix, though I am no game designer so maybe I'm wrong. Regardless, I do highly recommend this game to anyone like me who simply wants to learn the language, but finds the process of memorizing alphabets to be tedious or forgettable. The game also tries to include very helpful basic vocabulary and phrases making it a great starting point (especially if you're not sure where to start with learning vocabulary or grammar).

author: {'steamid': '76561198336618373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1597188317}
review:
The concept of learning Hiragana through a RPG is a good one, but a number of design choices makes playing this very clunky in practice. The UI in particular is very outdated and clunky. 

For example, most of the game consist of you fighting enemies by matching the correct phonetics to the Hiragana, but the only option is to pick through a menu to find the right words. There is no search option nor an option to type the answer. This makes the game more and more tedious to play as you pick through an ever longer menu to pick the right answer. 

It's baffling UI design choices like this that makes the game frustrating to play. I would Avoid unless you have a lot of patience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996555478', 'num_games_owned': 620, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1597112860}
review:
Too slow paced if you're already familiar with hiragana. Too focused on teaching by writing. Too many clicks to get through a battle so it feels like a chore. It doesn't even really work well as a revision tool. There are better free resources on the internet that teach you faster and test you better. Maybe it might work if you use it along side another better learning tool, but I think the pacing kills its utility.
I'll try playing it again, but it honestly felt like the game was just wasting my time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048563162', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1681663885}
review: An educational throwback to the 16-bit RPG days. It can be a little cheesy at times, and could maybe use with a small explanation as to why you write characters in a specific order, but making the repetition into a game helps. I would have liked to see a sort of quiz/review mode that didn't involve wandering around trying to run into specific enemies. The RNG seems to really favor certain enemy combos. However, after only a couple of hours I've been able to at least sound out a couple shorter words/names in various anime shows, which is my primary goal: to learn enough to read signs in shows that may not have sub translations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198983873165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1596572219}
review:
Two things upfront: It's a Kickstarter-Game (which I didn't know) and I find it to be alright for a refresher. 

I learned Kana some 20 years ago for fun and this brought everything back on the Hiragana part. 
Overall, while pretty basic in almost every aspect, it's a fun little learning experience that doesn't outstay it's welcome. Of course, if you intend to learn it for actual usage, you'll need to keep going and the game offers you to go back to every lesson, even after you finished it. 

Pros:
- You can see the drawing of every letter and it's stylized counterpart, along with a soundbit to guide you to it's  pronunciation. 
- The music is not obnoxious and goes along well with the game. 
- Visually nothing special but pleasant to look at. I like the character-sprites and their animation. 
- You get basic phrases and words thrown in the mix you'd encounter in beginner courses as well. You'll probably recognize a lot if you ever paid any attention to anime, movies, series. 
- For difficulty you can utilize level-ups from sidequesting if the combat is too hard/tedious for you. I didn't find it difficult, but being able to speed things up at times is a nice qol-feature I appreciate.
- You cannot advance if you don't learn and remember. Less of a problem when you can simply look up things, but true to what a learning-game should be like.
- Characters are likable. Didn't throw me of my socks but I didn't dislike anyone. On top of that almost every NPC looks different from the next one. 


Cons:
- Basic features and little adjustability. Heck, you can't even turn it off in the menu. When you do  adjustments on sound, or turn the music off for a bit, it takes effect on the next screen. Things I would expect from a somewhat contemporary RPG-Maker build. I still wonder if I had ever made back into post-game Snow Leaf Village if I had Alt+F4'd out of the Kickstarter-Scrolling at the end...  
So, not state of the art by any means, but to be fair it never ever crashed, slowed down or froze on me. 
- The pronunciation bits are too quiet and sound clunky, muffled and chopped up, except at the very end for the basic phrases. Those are pleasant and actually sound what I would expect every sound clip to sound like. Budget issues, I guess. 

Overall it really does cover little but the Hiragana, but that's already apparent from the title. And they do make you aware of alternate script sytles and the like. Still, I can't get over how lacking I found the audio for the pronunciation bits... Then again, there are plenty of other online-resources and at the end of the day it will provide examples for beginners that don't have a clue how Japanese sounds like. 

Like I said I had fun and it worked well as a refresher, so a thumbs up from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182044218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1597536945}
review:
Ich habe vor vl einem Monat damit angefangen japanisch zu lernen und versuche seitdem auch √ºber Anime, Videos von Muttersprachlern, Spiele etc. das Gelernte zu festigen/neues zu erschlie√üen.

Zu diesem Zweck eignet sich das Spiel wirklich gut, ich bin froh dar√ºber, es gefunden zu haben. Es zwingt einen die Zeichen/Silben immer wieder zu wiederholen und sie so gut zu festigen und das in einem motivierenden Rahmen.

Wie allerdings von einigen anderen Rezensenten angemerkt: Ich w√ºrde es eher als begleitende Lernhilfe nutzen, als nach dem Spielen zu glauben, man k√∂nne nun ausreichend japanisch. Die unterschiedlichen Fonts f√ºhren leicht zu einer Verwechslung/Probleme beim schreiben, wenn man die Hiragana noch nicht kennt. Au√üerdem w√§re eine echte Stimme wesentlich hilfreicher gewesen, als die computergenerierte Alternative.
Edit: Die Musik musste ich nach einer Weile durch meine eigene ersetzen. ^^

Von dem Gameplay habe ich nicht allzu viel erwartet (bin vl zu einem Drittel durch damit), wurde aber positiv √ºberrascht. Wenn man kein besonders ausgefeiltes RPG oder Kampfsystem erwartet, erh√§lt man solide Kost, die sich nicht durchgehend anf√ºhlt wie ein Lernspiel. Es gibt einige nette Nebenquests, welche dem puren "lernen" von Hiragana nochmal entgegenstehen. Im sp√§teren Verlauf gibt es auch K√§mpfe bei denen man z.B. von der Romaji-Umschrift die passenden Hiragana nennen soll, ich hoffe auf weitere Variationen.

review: Just started the game, but have been streaming it on Twitch as well as publishing a Let's Play series on my YouTube channel for it. A couple of friends have even purchased it, we're having a blast learning Japanese so far. Only a couple of lessons in but I'm super excited to learn as much as possible. I'm a fan of the way the hiragana are presented, in 5-character blocks and seemingly in the same vowel pattern (a, i, u, e, o). Makes for better familiarity. The music is great as well!

author: {'steamid': '76561199067128448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1681859575}
review: I really love that the game teaches you the alternates ( " ) of the hiragana directly after teaching you that set. The books I studied would always teach it after the whole base hiragana, so they'd always be hard to recognize for me the sound that it would be meant to make- but this game makes it super easy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999837334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1595315969}
review:
This game is a good starting point for people who have no experience with Hiragana. If you want to learn Japanese grammar this game will not help you much. The game isn't very long and covers 10 main lessons, That work out to all 71 hiragana characters, 15 phrases and ~30 words. The side quests will show give you additional words( roughly 80), but usually only give the hiragana or romaji spelling for them, which is fine since by the end of the game you should be able to work out the other one.

The level design isn't very good and by the time you reach the end, going through the list of characters to attack becomes tedious and annoying.

The music is average, sometimes it can feel repetitive but for the most part it works for the game.

The story is probably the worst part of the game but I suppose this games whole concept is silly and a story could be hard to write for this. However, if you are hoping for an engaging story you definitely will not find it here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280691699', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1595120167}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive is, at its core, an educational experience. The constant, Hiragana-focused battles and the progression-based character/vocab/grammar lessons solidify this. While the developers could have shipped off a product that's only as deep as its educational merits, Sleepy Duck ultimately created a world and cast with substantial charm and humor (especially for an educational source). The game, alongside being fun to progress, is an excellent gateway into the endeavor of learning a new language. I would highly recommend using external sources, such as Tofugu and Realkana, to round out your educational journey. Good luck studying!

 this steam guide goes into more detail: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1573508156

author: {'steamid': '76561198067817027', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1680292977}
review: Im going to start this off by saying I got this game mostly as a bit of a meme. However it is a surprisingly good way to learn the very basics and hiragana. I used to use guides online for learning Japanese and worksheets to memorize hiragana, however while I would learn them, I'd have a bit of difficulty retaining the information or would just see a wall of text and kinda just blank out. However because game has story sequences between lessons and has you matching the right hiragana to their English equivalents in any battle you're essentially forced to take a bit to absorb it in and slows you down, meaning that its much less information taken in over a longer period of time allowing you to actually absorb a good chunk of that information. For what I paid (a total of 3 dollars for the whole bundle of thse games from fanatical) it is a surprisingly good experience and actually ended up teaching me a few things. Even the game for 6 dollars is a good deal in my opinion solely for the reason of actually absorbing the information if you don't have enough discipline to not rush through it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104796136', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1593621131}
review:
You have to understand that this is a mere guide, since repetition is key to learn this, but it's still an RPG so it could be a bit boring.

I tried to play it several times but didn't have the right mindset to learn, just expected to magically know hiragana, but the last time something clicked. You must know that this alone isn't enough, it will give you some vocabulary and obviously the hiragana but you must put a lot of yourself, I did some practice outside of the game and know I can read hiragana; I can't understand a thing but is the first step.

The game by itself is a nice start but keep in mind that you'll have to practice and research on your own too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960598374', 'num_games_owned': 1114, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1564546436}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993987330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1593961464}
review:
I personally find this game to be a great revision tool if you're into the classic RPG format. I find it to be very engaging as well as very entertaining. Having a pen and paper is crucial to playing this game as it's the kind of thing that requires a 'cheat sheet' of sorts to get through if you're not particularly adept at Japanese - in saying that, for some learners I would also recommend starting out by using the charts that help equate characters to pictures to help ingrain the characters properly.
In summary: perhaps this isn't the greatest of learning tools, but it's an absolutely brilliant revision tool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198390983427', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1593984615}
review:
The game really does what it promises, at the end of the game you'll have learned all the hiragana alphabet and will also know a few japanese words. So if you're a begginer, I strongly recommend it.
Now, as a game, you'll need a lot of patience to complete it. The game has a VERY high rate of random battles/encounters. Sometimes you barely walk three steps and tadaa, another battle. I know the game wants you to fight a lot because those are the moments you most practice what you've learned during the lessons, but come'on, there could be 30% less battles and you'd still have to fight a LOT. So that's a big negative thing for me.

My final score for it is 6.8 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198243947008', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1593399610}
review: This game has a great amazing soundtrack, good story and great for learning hiragana. I think it should not cost it's current price ($8.95 AUD). If you already can speak and read Japanese it's not a game for you. If you are willing to start learning this is where you should start learning. If I Were To Rate It, It Would Be ( 7 Out Of 10 )

author: {'steamid': '76561198169506667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1594411469}
review:
A few notes on possible improvements and my general thoughts.
1. This is an accessory to learning Japanese, the best way is probably by purchasing exercise books (I prefer Timothy G. Stout from Tuttle. You probably won't really learn Japanese as fast as you could solely by playing this game but playing it subsequent a session of self-study with an exercise book will hasten the process.
2. If you already have some knowledge of the Japanese writing system, the early game might be a little tedious. I recommend that the developers in future updates or products introduce a system that tests you first so you can play according to your knowledge level.
3. The gameplay itself varies. It isn't greatly in depth and the main focus does seem to be the learning of the language but I wonder if an RPG would be the best method. Perhaps there would be other designs that could function better. Maybe like Papers, Please where you're a bureaucrat or translator traveling through Japan and lending your services. Something of the sorts. Not to say it's uninspired but the gameplay feeling empty might attribute to players losing interest quickly. 
4. The gameplay is a little rough in the sense that there's illogical leaps where your character will answer a for the next hiragana following a hiragana that has already been defeated, thus answering wrong. Moreover, if the purpose was simply to learn Japanese, the gameplay could've been easier. It's not very simple to juggle winning the game and learning the language at the same time.
5. Some of the characters are really poorly written. The blonde guy is the stereotypical culturally insensitive gajin. Straight off the bat he's telling us he wants to learn Japanese to get it on with Japanese women. I thought the character was stupid and annoying. I am not learning Japanese to get it on with hot geishas but because it is an interesting language from an interesting country. Wish they had a different characterisation.

All things considered, a handy accessory to learning Japanese. It sure beats Du*Lingo, the ersatz tool for broke retards who will never learn the language.
If you want to learn Japanese faster, get this game and play it whenever you're through with your daily exercises. 

7/10, it kind of does well what it intends to do

review:
This is an awesome game to learning Hiragana; almost every Hiragana's pronunciation can be read from our native language or its dialects(E.G.: Telugu) but some of them are very tricky, for example, you can read „ÅÇ, „ÅÑ, „Åà, „Åä from English language but what about '„ÅÜ'? And the same reasons of „Åó and „Å°;  and more, we also can discover the rules of pronunciation about the hiragana's muddy sounds like if you pronouncing „Åå, „Åé, „Åê, „Åí, „Åî then you can't use your "Soft G" in English to pronounce it otherwise it will become „Åò and „Åò„Åá sound; and the vocabulary is very well, although it includes a small amount of words, however, you need to use these words to fight final boss because language is used to speak, not just only to remember words and phrases.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114185627', 'num_games_owned': 886, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1578450829}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198058709061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1589655037}
review:
Hiragana Battle is a pretty cool edutainment game !

If you want to start learning Japanese, this is a pretty good spot !
You CAN definitely learn all of that on your own, but I think making it a game makes it more enticing to learn everything until the end (it definitely helped me !).
This game will teach you Hiragana one row at a time, along with quite a few useful words (a lot of them at the end of the game) and even a bit of grammar at the end.
As for the learning part, it works great !

However as for the game part, well, it's kind of basic.
The story / writing is extremely basic, but does the job I guess.
The balancing of combat difficulty was also a bit of an issue for me (I mean purely the amount of damage taken/received, not your ability to answer properly lol).
At the beginning, battles are a bit hard but not too much, it then becomes kinda hard to really hard, but becomes easy again when you are introduced to the side-quest system.
It is a system where you can exchange points that you get by completing side-missions for 1 more level for all members in your party. They tell you it is optional and you can supposedly beat the game without this help, and for middle-game to the start of the end, you would go through hell but yes it might be possible, but I have no idea how you would beat the last level without it...
Also, the visuals are kind of basic, but I don't find this a major issue.
Although, this game always kept me by surprise by switching certain mechanics around to keep things fresh. I especially liked the mechanics of the final level !

The in-game timer tells me that I took about 11 hours to beat this game with all side-quests.

Quick note: The pre-bundled executable did not work properly for me, the sound was really weird.
Hopefully, you can run this game in any web browser (yes, this is an HTML5 game) by temporarily disabling some securities (--allow-file-access-from-files option for Chrome) and it works just fine ! I used a Powershell script to run Chrome with the option and pointing to the index.html file.
That is why my game time is so low on Steam, just ran the actual executable to get the cards.

Don't think about my comments on the gameplay too much though. It is a very cool educational tool, that I would definitely recommend to anyone !
Now, onto the second game, Katakana War, to continue learning !

author: {'steamid': '76561198030704251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 988, 'last_played': 1591849107}

author: {'steamid': '76561198349773291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1602813740}
review: If you want a big fully functioning game for the sake of playing a game, this may not be  the one for you. However, the game does an excellent job of teaching hiragana. I had some basic knowledge of hiragana at the start. By the end of the game, I could read through a list of hiragana and be able to tell you which one was which and I could do it rather quickly. The combat is fun and the side quests are rewarding. All in all, amazing game to learn hiragana with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041499783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1387, 'last_played': 1591472020}
review:
This game does a great job introducing series by series the hiragana, then let you practice recognition: you face hiragana characters and must find their romaji equivalent to win. There's even a short part where you face the romaji transcription and need to find the corresponding hiragana.
Each time you learn a new set of hiragana, you can be assured that you'll face that set in the next area, but the game also does a good job to include other hiraganas from series you learned earlier as well.
I yet have to finish the game (I just finished the Mount Fuji part), but if I had one suggestion to make, it would be to have more of the part where you face the romaji transcription: it would help make the association both ways more easily. Still, the most important ie, know how to pronounce and read hiraganas is covered, so that's not a big issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975546362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1591032338}
review:
Has had a random freezing bug since release that the developers never fixed. Seems to affect some people and not others. Teaches in alphabetical order, and through repetition only; no mnemonics or exercises beyond rote "match the hiragana to the romaji" or "match the romaji to the hiragana."

This developer's other "Learn Japanese to Survive!" games are decent, the Kanji one moreso than the Katakana one. Avoid this one and use Heisig's "Remembering the Kana" to learn hiragana instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076910886', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1590888557}
review:
Considering that this game is designed to be a learning tool, there are actually 2 questions answered in this review. 

Is it a good game?
Is it a good study guide?

As far as a game goes, it's pretty weak. About an hour of extra grinding throughout the game in addition to just playing and I was able to one shot most of the enemies. Once I got to Tokyo, I had enough money to buy the best weapons and armor for all of my characters and the enemies couldn't hurt me for the rest of the game (about 1/3 of the dungeons). The combat is basic. You have a handful of spells that you will never use because killing enemies is faster. Your attacks are all just answering the Japanese (and sometimes English) characters that you encounter as enemies. That being the case, every attack is physical and only targets one enemy. However, as you progress, the amount of "attacks" you have to search through in the menu to attack gets to be very long. I found this tedious, but because it is being used as teaching tool, I understand why it was the way it was. The game crashes relatively often. I had a half dozen crashes over my 10 hour completion of the game and all of its sidequests. on top of that, there is slowdown in a few areas. I've noticed this type of thing with RPG maker games on a few different systems, from super high end to mid tier computer. It's some coding issue that some of these indy games have. It wasn't too common this time, but it was there. The config options are just bad. There are 4 audio sliders, of which only 1 does what you think it does and you only get 5 stages of adjustment, making things either way too loud or too quite. Music is there, but nothing special. Characters have no personality and motivations for villains are never covered. As a game, it's dull and boring.

As a study guide, I have mixed feelings about this. First off, I studied Japanese is high school many years ago and so I already have a very dated understanding of some of the vocab and the characters. I've forgotten most of what I learned so I wanted to use this game as a small refresher of some of the basics. For me, the learning of Hiragana was rolled out a little too slow, but for someone being exposed to it for the first time, I can see it being paced alright in that regard. However, the game also introduced some basic terms and phrases, but it did so slowly over the course of the game, then didn't test you on it until the final dungeon. So even if you were taking all of your notes, by the time they mattered, you likely forgot the early ones as the newer ones were more fresh in your mind. All of the bosses were just more of the same hiragana characters, so what I would have liked to see instead is that bosses would use those vocab questions and then give us more bosses so we could work on multiple aspects of the language at once. Some things, like phrases, were only introduced to help the player out in real life and had no impact on the game. This is fine and good, but I would have used those phrases a little more when it came to the sidequests. I also would have liked it you could select which phrase to say to NPCs to initiate dialogue. All in all, I think it works alright as a study guide, but it is nothing special. When I was learning, I printed off the romaji for song lyrics and then kept filling in the hiragana and later katakana until I was able to recognise which characters better. The advantage to doing this is being able to practise writing at the same time.

TLDR: If you think the fact that this is a game will help you learn Japanese as a complete beginner, then give it a try, but don't expect to get an interesting game out of it. For me, it wasn't a fun game to play and it wasn't a particularly effective study guide either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138139495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1589902273}
review:
Da es schon sp√§t ist muss ich es kurz fassen, aber dieses Spiel und Lernprogramm ist mit Abstand derzeit das beste was man bekommen kann, um spielerisch in die japanische Sprache einzusteigen. Es sei gesagt dass ich auch mit Videokursen und B√ºchern gleichzeitig arbeite, diese Spiele aber vor allem f√ºr das Einpr√§gen der Schriftzeichen gekauft habe. Ich besitze n√§mlich alle drei dieser Reihe: Hiragana, Katakana und Kanji, welche auch jeweils das Schriftzeichen-Set lehren. Die Idee ist simpel und gleichzeitig genial. Man nehme RPG Maker oder √§hnliche Tools und baut ein rundenbasiertes Abenteuerspiel mit Helden und gegnerischen Schriftzeichen und bei dem anstelle der typischen Angriffsf√§higkeiten eines Gruppenmitglieds die repr√§sentativen Laute in form unseres lateinischen Alphabets (Japaner nennen es Romaji) gew√§hlt werden m√ºssen. Ein Hiragana-A kann also nur mit der Nennung eines lateinischen A wirksam getroffen werden. Neben √ºblicher JRPG-Mechaniken wie Heilung, St√§rkung, R√§tsel l√∂sen und Nebenquests und der gleichen wird das lernen und trainieren wirklich vertieft. Als JRPG Spiel lenkt es gerne auch immer wieder ein wenig in der n√∂tigen Dosis ab. Ich hatte nie das Gef√ºhl im Konzept eines Lernspiels oder im Konzept eines Abenteuerspiels unter- oder √ºberfordert zu sein. Mal muss man ein Gruppenmitglied heilen oder in die Stadt zur√ºck um seine Figur besser auszur√ºsten. Dadurch bleibt man, in meinen Augen, jedoch h√∂chst konzentriert, zu mal beim Aufenthalt in der Stadt stets die Lehrerin angesprochen werden kann um alte Lektionen zu wiederholen. Die Lektionen sind in den Fortschritt/Geschichte eingeflochten und werden St√ºck f√ºr St√ºck langsam an den Spieler und Lernenden ran gebracht. Diese Lehrerin ist auch der Hauptquestgeber in der Storyline wo man von A,I,U,E,O bis WA und N wirklich alles an Hiragana lernt und trainiert. Zwischenzeitlich gibt es auch Vokabeln, Redewendungen und etwas Kulturinfo √ºber Japan. Zum Teil auch sehr nett in Nebenquests verpackt. Recht sp√§t im Spiel muss man auch die ersten gelernten Hiragana beim Lesen einer Shop-Liste verstehen um eine Nebenquest zu schaffen. Auch gibt es sp√§ter im Spiel zwei oder drei kurze Abschnitte bei der hiragana-gegner umgekehrt abgefragt werden. Man muss dann die Romaji Gegenst√ºcke mit einer Hiragana Antwort besiegen. Echt gelungen, und ich glaube ich h√§tte mir ohne dieses Spiel nicht so viele Hiragana am St√ºck gemerkt. 
Drei wichtige Anmerkungen: auf meinem PC war das Spiel recht absturz-anf√§llig. Ich rate jedem, alle 5 bis 10 Minuten auf einem oder mehreren Save-Slots zu speichern damit nicht so viel Fortschritt verloren geht, falls euch das auch passiert. Trotzdem rate ich zum Kauf des Spieles und Support des Entwicklers, denm von allen Games, die ich jetzt auf Steam und am Handy gesehen habe, ist dies mit einer so enormen Tiefe und Liebe gemacht wurden, dass ich nichts vergleichbares nennen k√∂nnte. Au√üer KOE das jahrelang in Entwicklung ist und gef√ºhlt nie kommt. Und s√§mtliche anderen Spiele bzw Lernspiele wirken alle nicht vollst√§ndig oder sind am n√∂tigsten Punkt eher unausgereift oder nicht so tiefgehend wie diese JRPG Reihe von "Sleepy Duck".
Die zweite Anmerkung sei noch, sich tats√§chlich, wie von der ingame-Lehrerin gew√ºnscht, Papier und Stift zur Hand zu nehmen und reichtlich Notizen zu machen. Einerseits lernt man Hiragana auch durchs Schreiben noch effizienter (Muskelged√§chtnis) sondern auch deshalb, weil die einmaligen Vokabelnotizen (bitte in Romaji und Hiragana aufschreiben) sp√§ter essenziell wichtig sind um einen bestimmten sp√§ten Story-Abschnitt meistern zu k√∂nnen. Passned zum Thema des Spiels wird der Endgame-Abschnitt recht knackig, wenn man nicht gut mitgeschrieben hat und keine anderen Schulmaterialien besitzt. 
Dritte und wichtige Anmerkung: Nat√ºrlich -nicht anders zu erwarten- ist das Spiel auf englisch. Einerseits wird der Entwickler wohl kein Deutscher sein, andererseits ist englisch eine internationale Sprache, und damit ist dieses Lernspiel international zug√§nglich. Und f√ºr die ewigen Englisch-Verweigerer sei gesagt: lernt Englisch, dann Japanisch :)
und Ja, das Spiel sieht etwas "alt" (retro, pixel-look) und klischeehaft aus, und selbst wenn man RPG Maker als Grundlage f√ºr so etwas nicht mag, so denke ich mir jetzt nachtr√§glich: es gibt aber auch nichts und niemanden der es bisher schon besser gemacht h√§tte und damit am Markt w√§re. Viele pixelige JRPGs, sogar bei den Konsolenplattformen, gibt es ja zu hauf. Aber kein einziges mit Sprachen-lernen als ernstes Konzept. Und es gibt auch nicht ann√§hernd etwas vergleichbares.
Da ich den Hiragana-Teil heute "durchgespielt" und "durchgelernt" habe, werde ich demn√§chst mit Katakana weiter machen. Das Spiel dazu hei√üt "Katakana Wars" vom gleichen Entwickler. Angespielt habe ich es bereits und ich muss sagen es lohnt sich, denn die Spiele bzw deren Editor-Grundlagen, mit denen sie gemacht wurden, scheinen sich von Teil zu Teil weiter entwickelt zu haben. Nach Katakana und dem dazu passenden Spiel werde ich Kanji angehen, und auch wieder das dazu passende Spiel des Entwicklers laufen haben. Es lohnt sich in meinen Augen wirklich.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043782587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 598, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1590169687}
review:
Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle prides itself to be a quality multimedia edutainment. What they, Majestic 12, don't want you to know is that it's neither a smart education nor a good entertainment.

Let me list the reasons:
Ladies and Gentlemen...
RPG Maker.


Which isn't to say that RPG Maker sucks as engine, for it gave an absolute awesome birth to OFF. But you know how years ago mentioning gaming engines was seen as showcase of graphics and powers yet in these years it just immediately brings picture of shovelware games into mind? Yea.

Ok, real list:
 - Every asset is RPG Maker stock asset. Aside from Hiragana, obviously. And I heard that the game had kickstarter.
 - Controls and interface and gameplay are all RPG Maker stock. Mouse users will sure to enjoy having to double click everything. And they didn't even include the exit game button anywhere. You will play the game forever and you will like it. Also, not a fan of RPG Maker MV version engine, it gives me nano-loading freezes whenever I go exploring into status menu.
 - The plot is cheese that nearly reaches a cringe level. Ebil wizard attacks your stock RPG town with Hiragana symbols that you can harm only with your Hiragana knowledge. Which would have been more fun if it was written in adult maybe self-aware, way. Then again, I want to strangle all the self-aware humor in 2020 and this cheesy plot probably allows kids to enjoy the game too.
- You would think that in order to reinforce Hiragana knowledge you will be shot many kana at high pace. Nope, devs took too much inspiration from JRPG of olde to the point where it doesn't fit. Each battle lasts like 30 seconds both because of slow unskippable animation and having to manually select the Romaji answer to kana from the ever increasing list of choices that doens't fit to a single screen and also leads mostly to patten recognition instead of direct learning and you will be sick of doing it for all 4 characters manually. At times battles last more than one turn which is pointless for learning. 
 - Enemies can apply status effects that seem at times to last only one turn and then normal combat lasts only like 2 turns so if you made use of antidote magic you just wasted a turn you dood.
 - If two characters gang on one kana but it dies in one hit, the second character will hit another kana with same, now wrong, answer, wasting your time.
 - There are only few preset sets of Kana squads you can encounter per area instead of being actually randomized, you will learn their patterns soon. Once again, more of pattern learning instead of directly learning. Gaming the system. Of course, I came here to learn Hiragana so I forced myself to remember the pronouncation of Kana first but you know, I brought a game and it should be a challenge that teaches you, otherwise you should just use flashcards and what not.
 - Developers didn't quite handle the intricate art of stats tweaking in RPG Maker. Once you get midway through the game when your characters will have like 100+ defence each, the game balance will be constantly hinging between whooping your ass and doing 0 damage.
 - Featureless mazes ahoy with no interesting things to explore, few misplaced tiles aside, that  make you run in circles while you pop enemy encounter every few steps that you have to grind, which I call grinding instead of learning reinforcement due to mentioned flaw of having only few preset kana possible encounters per area that you will exhaust real fast.
 - I have used the game along with unrelated book to learn Japanese but I must say that if you dedicate the whole game to Hiragana alphabet you ought to get real into it. Book says that in order to make long M in MA series of kana I should place N beforehand. Nothing like that in the game.
 - Combat where you translate Romaji into Hiragana was nice but too rare, should have made it common encounter.
 - The game teaches you vocabulary as a side content and I hate it. I am of a camp that believes that it's best to learn your words by translating texts and then reinforcing it with tests. Game here just randomly gives you separate semi-random phrases and words through a game out of context and then only reinforces that in the very final level, suddenly rushing down. I just tanked that part of a game through because I know that I will forget words in few days with this kind of teaching. Then again, the big idiot is me for tanking through game part I didn't like instead of watching walkthrough, heh.
 - Besides, you are supposed to remember words by their kanji (hieroglyphs) writing and I heard that devs made a mistake in Hiragana writing of at very least one word, so.
 - Lessons are so slow and clunky so I don't ever want to revise them. It's true that "study guides" you get as item are just a single screen but they lack info and you can revise vocabulary only at your femme sensei.

Overall, you are being sold real amateur RPG Maker project there and you ought to skip it. Hiragana is not that scary, you can do it yourself without gaming motivation that will just annoy you here.

It did help me to reinforce Hiragana memorization but then there are other ways to do it. I just had this game already purchased back when I was less grumpy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986283507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1588565916}
review:
This is a less boring way to learn Hiragana characters. That being said, there is room for improvement to increase the enjoyment of the game, as well as for learning purposes.

If I could make changes to the game, it would be this:

* Reduce the number of players in the battle. You spend most time selecting which "attack" (answer) to use, and most of the time you use all the players to attack the same enemy (logically so). Since there is no tactical advantage changing up the attacks, having multiple characters attacking the same word multiple times seem pointless (see my second recommendation for how it possibly could be solved).

* The attacks quickly become boring. The idea of having to select the words matching the hiragana is brilliant, but it does not feel like a good game. If we could mix in a few elements of Final Fantasy, say adding spells and attacks such as "Fira Ka", "Fira Ki", (...), "Quick Attack Ka", and so on, with abilities that could be unlocked as we go (as you do with each lesson), it would feel more rewarding. Each attack with different colors and effects to make the game feel less mundane, and make each attack stand more out.

A way to go about this would be to have a Spell type, Physical type, and possibly a Status type for every character. "Fira Ka", "Slash Ka", "Sleep Ka", depending on the character. This would change how you play, by using the different characters to actually affect the flow of battle.


------


If you are completely new to Hiragana, this game definitely wont keep you entertained while learning all the way. This would be best played in short sessions (perhaps once a day, every other day) while learning a set of characters. Even then, you will have to grind a bit to be properly adjusted, in order to battle the stronger "Hiragana Warriors".

Would I recommend this to learn Hiragana? "Yes, but". I would not recommend this as the sole way of learning Hiragana. This is a supplement. A way to practice without making it feel like a chore (which is very good). Just keep the sessions short, no more than perhaps 20-30 minutes (perhaps that is too long), to avoid getting bored. 

-----

tldr; A good way to supplement your learning. It is simple, perhaps too simple, which can make it boring in the long run. Play in short sessions to keep it more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009517770', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1605943444}
review: I just finished this game and while there are probably more efficient ways to learn Hiragana, I think that Learn Japanese to Survive - Hiragana Battle at least makes the process engaging and meaningful. I'd recommend you play with bikke the pirate's guide in the Guides section of the game on Steam. I'd also recommend trying to memorize the vocabulary before finishing the game because it will help in the end. You have to do the side quests to acquire much of this vocabulary, so do them all before completing the game. I think daily practice using something similar to the Real Kana app and website will help. You won't learn to speak Japanese from this game, but it will set you on the path to be able to read Hiragana which will help you in that journey. Best of luck! I can't wait to try the other games in this series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088431876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1590412662}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028405707', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1588474794}
review:
I've been using this game to supplement my learning of hiragana and it has really helped a lot. Do not rely on it entirely, include it into your studies instead. 
Personally I will practice whatever hiragana I will be learning next outside of the game by way of brute force learning. I visually memorise the hiragana until I feel I have them nicely remembered. Then I will boot up the game and follow its handwriting tips on a practice sheet. When it comes down to the battles I have that practice sheet squared away so I can't reference it and I haven't lost a battle yet. The battles are a great way to recall what you have learned. 
I try to aim for one new line of hiragana a day and this game really does speed that up.

So yeah, don't rely on this always use as many devices to learn as possible, but this one does help a lot! 

Other things I have been using to learn are listed below:
- Practice Sheets: http://japanese-lesson.com/characters/hiragana/hiragana_writing.html
- A good and customizable quiz: https://kana.pro/
- Tofugus mnemonics list: https://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn-hiragana/

Enjoy and happy learning

author: {'steamid': '76561198008367456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1819, 'last_played': 1587504582}
review:
it did realy helped me to start learning Japenese.
But,
Has a game designer and level designer a saw 2 principale problem all along the game and a small 1 at the End.
1 The enemy partern.
I found out that the enemy patern was extremly repetitive inside the same biome. What i mean is that I pass throught a full chapter without ever encountering lot of hiragana that was the principale studies of that same Chapter. exemple: You learn the H b and P groupe. During the encounter for that exact 3 groupe I never saw must of the P and never I saw any ho, bo or po. In another exemple At a rediculous ratio of 60% chance i was encountering di which is very rare to use in japenese (acording to the person i know that know Speak Japenese)
Solution: making That the % rate of spawning a pecular Hiragana increase every time that you don't see it.

2 No retro study
So when you get in a new Chapter you learn new Pool of Hiragana wich is perfect. During that chapter you will mustly encounter those Hiragana (which is perfect). THe real problem is that i never saw a pool of Hiragana of 2 chapter prior to the chapter i was. 
Solution: 
Actual Studied Hiragana Spawn Ration: 60%, all the others 40%.

Solution 2:
 to fix both first problem would be to put enemy into the world map. Those enemy pool should be all the Hiragana Studied yet.

Problem 3: 
The End Game.
The game is quiet nice. Ultra charming (that is what kept me playing instead of starting to study without it), have a nice Story. Basicly the problem is that i don't fell confident enought to go after a bigger fish with my actual skill. A end Game thing to help to study more instead of buy the Katakana Battle game can be nice.
