author: {'steamid': '76561198003508577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1586776149}
review: Awesome stuff. I'd tried learning hiragana before, but without the practice and a fun way to make it stick, it always failed so thank you! The RPG grind and straightforward story make it serviceable and engaging learning, very easily accessible and how the characters are introduced, including the accompanying dakuten and handakuten are excellently done! Finished this so now on to katakana and kanji! Thanks guys! Arigato gozaimasu!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994346855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1606, 'last_played': 1586718187}
review:
My actual in-game playtime for this game was about 24 hours.  I spent quite a few hours learning to write and read Japanese Hiragana characters while the game ran in the background.  

The learning part of this game is very light.  They show you how to write each character, give you a brief description, and tell you how to pronounce it.  You will then get a small quiz after each lesson.  The RPG part of this game is also fairly light.  There is not much depth to the characters, and using abilities aside from attack and guard is almost pointless.  I was able to one-shot almost all of the enemies in the game because I kept my level as high as possible, and I made sure I upgraded equipment as soon as possible.   Very standard old-school JRPG kinds of stuff.  

You will however, be in for a world of hurt if you don't either memorize everything, or at least write everything down in a notebook.  Also, you should keep the vocabulary lessons in a completely separate section from the Hiragana lessons.  This will come in handy throughout the game.  

Overall, the adventure is fun, and I love that I learned something about speaking and writing Japanese in the process.  I recommend this game if you are considering learning Japanese as an additional language.  It will give you a taste of what you're in for, and show you if you really want to learn the language, or move on to something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168346778', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 1261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1586602572}
review:
I tried to learn Hiragana in the past, but I couldn't find the proper technique and motivation. This game helped with both.

As far as a learning game goes, it worked well for me. The more you fight, the better you memorize the different hiragana and can read them more easily. One problem I had with it was the font used for them during battle. Sometimes it differs a lot from the font in the text, which can be confusing.

However there's a problem with the battle system. It's hard to explain it, but the way the attacks and valid targets work, as long as you have assigned more than one hero to fight an enemy and the enemy dies with the first strike, the second attack will be lost. This prolongs the battle and forces you to attack the remaining enemy next turn.

The game itself is not without flaws as well. In the second half there's an elevator door that's supposed to open so that you can progress in the game. Except that usually it won't. I got stuck there for a while and had to look up the solution. You have to leave and re-enter the building a couple of times, until the elevator decides to trigger.

This educational game seems to be inspired by games such as "Lufia 2 - Rise of the Sinistrals". The chests look very similar, especially the beautiful blue ones. And they had the same concept of focused energy as a weapon.
The story is easygoing and rather fun. There's a limited selection of equipment, armor and weapons. It features surprise attacks and ambushes as well as status effects. The later don't really matter, since they only last a round or so and the normal battles never took more than two.

As for the playtime, I'm a slow learner and I spent a lot of time grinding "levels" and "money" - but in truth I just needed and wanted the practice. It took me 21 hours to finish and I probably wouldn't mind replaying it at some point, just to refresh my knowledge.

Oh, one more thing. Do yourself a favour and write any word down that the game teaches you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988999542', 'num_games_owned': 1080, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1613651330}
review: Finished the game and great at teaching how to pronounce read and write Hirigana. Think pokemon battles but fighting letters instead. I personally think repetition is great for learning and that is exactly what happens in battles. It shakes the letters up a bit but I am getting to a point early on where I recognise without having to think about it as much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005329310', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 788, 'last_played': 1586377938}
review:
First of all, while this is a game, it is intended as a tool to learn Hiragana first.
I've finished the game in about 13 hours, within 3 days. I think I managed to memorise about 90% of the lessons in the game.
I strongly recommend approaching this as a class more than a game. The battle elements are like homework : you get presented with a character, and you give your answer to that character. You get it right, you damage it, otherwise you do nothing. I have hand-written the characters maybe a hundred times each to commit them to memory, and did not use a cheat sheet for battles (but I would write all enemies as if I was asked to write them down for an assignment).
The battle system is more than basic. After a while you can one-shot most enemies until the next lesson, ailments all wear off after battle, and enemies can't damage you that much if you get equipped. A little more depth, better UI, and more variety would have been welcomed. Often, you won't encounter much of the previous lessons' enemies in newer areas, which means that if you want to study them you need to go back in older (and laughably easier) areas. Still, there are a couple of nice surprises, but they're mostly in the last areas.

If you are not serious about learning the Hiragana alphabet, this is not for you. It is simple, but it expects you to study on your own, maybe even without the game open.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042537843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1586193790}
review:
This game has helped me learn half of the hiragana characters in less than 5 hours. It's not the only resource you need, as I've also been using flashcards, but it's extremely helpful in getting you to recognise the characters. 
The game elements are enjoyable, although I admit it wouldn't be worth playing were it not for the educational aspect. I don't think that's a negative thing, however - because if you're not interested in learning Hiragana, you wouldn't be playing this game anyway!

review:
Es un buen juego pedag√≥gico para el aprendizaje de los caracteres b√°sicos, vocabulario y ciertas cuestiones gram√°ticas esenciales. La tem√°tica RPG lo hace un juego ligeramente interesante, aunque la historia no es muy profunda. Es un juego que recomendar√≠a si te encuentras interesado en comenzar a aprender japon√©s, es un buen acercamiento al idioma, pero si lo buscas principalmente por una buena historia, jugabilidad o por gusto a los RPG no ser√≠a una compra recomendada, ya que podr√≠a resultar aburrido para quien no se encuentre interesado en el idioma japon√©s.

Por cierto, este juego tiene su secuela que es sobre el sistema de escritura katakana y una tercera de los kanjis b√°sicos para un nivel JLPT 5.

review: Great game that teaches you the Japanese syllables but at the same time says it has few exceptions to how you learn but as you find out there is a lot of exceptions. A lot of characters that mean the same thing but are just specific to say pronounce/write-out something/someone. Japanese takes 900 hours of study and I've played this game over once before and when I started again a flood of memories and characters I have yet to study again reappearing in my mind. So it does do a good job and making you memorize the characters. Learning all the different words the Japanese culture has to offer is up to you.

Memorizar los hiragana es un poco complicado si no tienes las ganas necesarias para repetirlos hasta aprenderlos correctamente, en cuanto a eso, este juego presenta un modo en el que terminar memoriz√°ndolos sin darte cuenta mientras avanzas en los combates. Por supuesto, no es recomendado evitar combates y es muy buena idea intentar conseguir todos los objetos que entren a tu vista, no para hacerte el juego m√°s f√°cil o algo, sino que para practicar un poco m√°s.
En general, por el precio es un buen juego tanto para entretenerte un poco o para aprender los hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198427390684', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1582564430}
review:
Okay. I generally have a rule not to review games I haven't fully completed yet. But I MUST write this review now, because I need to emphasize very important points of this game as someone who learns Japanese by himself. I will give this game a negative review for now (it may change in the future, I can't say this for sure). At this very moment, I like this game in general. But it has VERY serious issues when it comes to [b]teaching[/b] kana.

This game is perfect if you are searching for an educational game which is good for drill exercises. We'll talk about this later. But I have several pretty big questions about the lessons.

In each lesson we have a set of kana characters (one row from gojuuon table + (han)dakuon, if available). The first issue comes from the presentation. What we can see on screen is the calligraphic (printed) representation of the symbol from embedded Japanese font. It's being used both here and in the gameplay. But when the player asks for the animation to learn how to write this symbol on paper, these two versions (calligraphic and animated handwritten) do not match. It's natural, since we do not write letters exactly as they are printed in the book, but it creates a problem. When we are being asked to practice this character in our notepad what we can see on screen is the calligraphic version, not the handwritten one. And I, personally, couldn't understand from looking at my monitor, how exactly I am supposed to write it. BTW, [b]I know[/b] how to write these - I'm in no way a complete novice in learning Japanese, I considered this game being a nice short practice for me. But this is what confused me from the very beginning.

The second issue is the hints for writing. I couldn't understand from these hints whether I'm learning [b]calligraphy[/b] or trying to practice my [b]handwriting[/b]. Because some of these hints are useful for the former, but not for the latter. Also, to develop a consistent handwriting you need 1) an [b]exact sample[/b] of the symbol, it's usually presented inside a square 2*2 grid so you could understand the proportions and relative position of lines; 2) a working sheet with the same grid to practice (you can use checkered notepad or notebook); 3) hints for positioning of your hand (Japanese and Western styles of writing are different!). None of these are being featured here. The DLC study guide has the printed and handwritten versions of the character on the same page, though, but that's all. Oh, and also I want hints like how not to mix up some characters which are pretty much identical (I'm constantly reading „ÅÇas „Åä and vice versa).

The third issue. We are being constantly reminded about the order of strokes in kana characters. But it's probably a common question for everyone who is learning Japanese. [b]Why the order of strokes is important?[/b] It could be outright inconvenient for some people to write these symbols the way they are supposed to be written. For example, when we write Western letters (Latin or Cyrillic ones), we usually write the "body" of the letter and then add something, like diacritics. So why it's important to write kana and kanji in Japanese exactly like this? Here it's a question without an answer. I want at least a brief explanation of this, like: 1) When you write fast, wrong stroke order could make your handwriting incomprehensible, or you could easily miss a stroke and turn, for example, „ÅÇ into „ÇÅ or „Åç into „Åï or something; 2) When you'll start to learn kanji and their keys/radicals it's very important to write these [b]fast[/b], and fast cursive handwriting will be absolutely indecipherable with the wrong stroke order; 3) The stroke order is important in handwritten input for the right recognition of characters; ... Well, you got the point.

The fourth issue. You must not use a robot for voiceover in teaching! The right pronunciation is very important in Japanese and similar languages, and the voiceover must be done by a native speaker.

The fifth issue. The vocabulary, which is pretty out of place. I understand that you have to provide examples of the words with these kana characters just explained. But could you choose the words a bit more wisely or consistently? For example, do not mix romaji and kana in the beginning. It will improve the effect from learning greatly.

The gameplay. As I said, this game is good for drill exercises, when you repeat the same characters over, and over, and over, and over... The battles with the "enemy" kana characters (vulnerable to the right guess of its pronunciation) are literally every dozen of steps here. Also, it's good for training to recognize kana visually [b]for reading[/b] (but not by ear, it's not really relevant, but it could be a nice addition to write words in kana by ear). The gameplay itself is your mediocre "educational" story made in RPGMaker, the RPG element isn't really deep or something, it's more like it does absolutely everything to make the game longer. Which is understandable (longer gameplay - more enemy encounters), but sometimes just plain boring (the locked door is on the one side of the labyrinth you just went through, the key is... you know where). And it becomes bad when the RND doesn't work at all. I was forced to play the same battle with the same three enemy characters [b]three times in a row[/b]. I'm supposed to know 25 characters already, what about the other 22?

upd: And another thing which pretty much annoyed me here is that EVERY single menu button in this game must be pressed twice to work! First time for highlighting, second time for activating. It could be a legacy of RPGMaker, but seriously, what the...?

The game actually has nice hints and some basic trivia about Japan for everyone who is learning Japanese. It's useful, really. It's entertaining, and it's good. But if you want to actually [b]learn[/b] kana, not just for reading and understanding these characters in texts (this game is perfect for this task), but for using it yourself, then it will be much better to find a free kana course in Google, print materials and use these for actual learning. I used materials from one of these sites (I won't put the link here, since it's not an advertizing, but you can find it easily on first page by searching "free hiragana self-study course") and there are really good hints and examples for handwriting along with short examples with pronunciation on YouTube. And really, it was much better for me.

-----

If you are interested in other games I'm playing, check my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36682541-Lonely-Dev-Reviews/]Curator page[/url]. Maybe there will be something good for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995782746', 'num_games_owned': 1051, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1582370614}
review:
Can it help you to read and memorize hiragana better? Absolutely. Especially if you try to complete all side-quests and to get the best armour and weapons in the game, you will have to grind a bit. And battles the same subset of hiragana dozens of times will commit their shapes to you memory like nothing else. 

Positive:
- It has exactly the right length, a 100% run will only take about 6 hours
- The visual are nice, nothing extraordinary, but pleasant to look at with no style clashes. The sequel is better, though.
- The mazes in the dungeons are not overly complicated. It's a learning game first, and a RPG second.
- If you complete every side-quest and try to grind just enough money to buy the best equipment you will have no difficulties whatsoever, the RPG part of the game becomes trivial. Your progress only depends on how well you can recognize hiragana, which is exactly the right gameplay approach for a learning game.

Negative:
- The music just OK. The battle theme kind of sucks which is a pity because you will hear hundreds of times. The sequel got this MUCH better.
- The battle system has built-in flaw. You have to provide commands for all of your characters at the beginning of a round and only afterwards the round starts and the commands are executed. Since your attack only damage enemies which exactly match your attack choice (hiragana) as soon as an enemy is killed and you have another character left attacking with the same hiragana the attack will randomly shift to the next target for which the chosen hiragana won't match (there are never more than one enemy of the same kind in a battle) and the attack will be wasted. This was fixed in the sequel.

RECOMMENDED.





Negative:

author: {'steamid': '76561198076296740', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1580365056}
review:
So this is gonna be a long in-depth review of LJTS-HB. Ill add a TL;DR at the end but this is gonna summarize my experiences and what I believe are pros and cons of the game.

So an overall summary of the game is that as a SIDE learning tool, it is really helpful. I am usually terrible at learning new things and maintaining the information, especially languages (took a German class 5 years ago and only remember like 5 words, but I remember the alphabet because its the basic 26 + 4 more letters) so learning all brand new 46 characters is and still somewhat is a tough thing for me. With the game being at a somewhat slow pace and playing about 45 minutes to an hour per session for me, it really helped me out with not being such a fast learner. I enjoyed the same from the beginning to about roughly to the end (Explained later in cons section)

[b] Pros [/b]

+ Good pace(for slow learners): If you have a hard time retaining information and/or don't have all the time in the world to study, this game is a good pace for you.

+ Study guides: The game has included study guides so in case you are having trouble with some characters, you can go back and re-learn a set of characters if needed. I personally never used it but I feel like if I ever needed to then I would have used it to better reinforce it to my memory

[b] Neutral [/b]

+- Story: the story is nothing AAA but that isn't what you came for here, it was to learn. The story is at least better than average In my opinion but not 100% memorable.

+- Side-quests: same thing with story, they are not terrible. Majority of them are just learning words in hiragana and that's it. 4-5 will make you fetch/buy items to then learn words. I THINK that probably 60-65% of the words you learn are not average day words that are used in a typical day in Japan. Also more of a con than a neutral, but side quest knowledge isn't implemented into the gameplay at all which sucks, but then the game would have been more difficult for non-side quest players so I understand.

+- Visuals: Nothing too special here. The game is created in RPG Maker so most interfaces and assets are nothing too special in my opinion.

+- Grind: Like most RPGs and JRPGs, there will usually be a time of grind. I will say out of my 8 hours, probably 30-45 minutes were spent grinding for levels and yen. I beat the end of the game without the highest tier armor because I would have probably had to grind for 1 hour or so, but at the end everyone was LV. 30+ which is enough to beat the game

[b] Cons [/b]

- Battles: While I can say that the battle do help you remember and put the characters in your long-term memory, the fights are not 100% random. From KeyofW's Review, the battles are predetermined 2-3 hiragana sets in each area, so basically just need to learn the combinations to remember what characters are in what group. The game as well said by KeyofW should have had a more flexible system that could have had 100% random encounters.

- Ending: So I will say this as the game will tell you this, but DO WRITE EVERYTHING IN THE LESSONS DOWN! While that seems like a no brainer thing to help you remember the hiragana, some lessons teach you words, which I don't see that as wrong, but 'SPOILERS' the final location of the game, [spoiler] the hiragana warriors you face are the words that you learn in the lessons. The final area took me an extra 30 minutes to complete because I had to re-look at my book that I was writing things in almost every fight to remember what combination of hiragana is what words. It felt very tedious and while I could look and say "yeah I know the hiragana" I couldn't remember what word they made. [/spoiler] Probably just a me thing but it really made the ending not the best for me.

So to summarize everything I just wrote: The game isn't the worst tool to use, but it could have been better in some aspects. I will take the knowledge I learned from this game and use it as a secondary tool for me to help remember the hiragana. I currently own all the games, thanks to a bundle, so my next game to play is the Katakana one so I might do a review of that one once I beat that, but I'm gonna drill the hiragana into my head for a while so I have this info in there and I don't have to keep looking up characters from time to time.

[h1] Overall score: 6/10 [/h1]

TL;DR: For a secondary tool, not a bad choice. good pace for slow learners, average story, but not the battle system or ending.

Update (3/7/2020): Lowered the score due to after playing Katakana War and at first rating it a 8/10, I realized that was a bit too high for what it was so lowering that to a 7 and this a 6 because in comparison that game was better in some aspects.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023696939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1579365174}
review: A pretty good and interesting way to drill and memorise your hiragana - just wish the lessons were skippable for those who have already learned some hiragana, and just want to practise. It would also have been nice if the hiragana characters were more mixed up in the battles - e.g. for hiragana from the earlier series you learned to also appear at the later stages, as a way to also practise those you had learned earlier. Or at least have the option to do so, for those who wish to practise that way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100491936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1668384252}
review:
The game feels like it runs way too fast most of the time, with movement, text prompts during combat, and combat animations being insanely fast. Combat can also change drastically with a single level up, with enemies that could 2 or 3 shot you if lucky now not having a snowball's chance in Hell against you after you ding. And yet the seemingly insane encounter rate makes the treks through the, thankfully, short stages take a while. However, since combat is how you learn Hiragana, the high encounter rate is kind of understandable. The story is pretty silly and cliche but it's self aware of it and just owns it. As a vehicle for a Hiragana lesson though, the game is perfectly serviceable and I came away learning the basics of Hiragana pronunciation and a few simple words. If you're curious about learning Hiragana and have the coin to spare, I can give this game a recommendation. I'll likely play it again at some point for a refresher, but currently I've moved on to the sequel, Katakana Combat.

Sidenotes: If you find yourself getting really roughed up after every fight, just buy Ramune in bulk and use that to heal up after every single fight until you out level the enemies. Ramune is like 1/9 the price of Deluxe Ramune for 1/3 the HP recovery. So as long as you aren't depending on it inside of combat it's a cost effective way to heal up. Also save often, since you can save anywhere you are.

review:

O game √© sub dividido em fases, que s√£o representados por locais do mapa, e para desbloquear cada fase uma "aula" deve ser feita, nessas aulas s√£o demonstrados progressivamente os kanas, afinal cada fase tem um nivel de complexidade diferente, quanto mais kanas aprendidos + complexo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068687649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1622075368}
review:
I think, the idea of a game with a repetitive mechanic, used as a way of learning the fonetic and characters of a language, in this case ( Hiragana, Japanese ), is wonderful and funny at the same time. Think about this, you are playing an RPG style game, and your enemies are actually hiragana characters and the only way of defeating them is that you know the sound of each one of them, it's a great idea! Because as i said the repetitive mechanic is what makes the learning process more comfortable and enjoyable. 
For me its a good way to start learning Japanese.
I totally recommend this game to everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004260705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1577446506}
review:
You can get through it quickly, there are side quests, by the end of it you know the Hirigana alphabet, and the final boss is more creative than the rest of the encounters combined. 

The fighting does get a little repetative and kind of pointless as your characters all have the same strengths and abilities. You also can't change your lineup so the same two characters always get flattened. 

But I finished it in 4 hours and feel like I wasn't studying for that time so I'm recommending it. It's fun and silly, it just gets a little tedious by the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000950964', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2882, 'last_played': 1576911211}
review:
Taking the time to bounce in and out of the game. I wouldn't warrant this as a standard for learning the language. You can tell that the people who worked on this game, are passionate about how they wanted to allow players easy accessibility to learning the basics of a language. 

For this, I would like to say, you have done a wonderful job at a very easy to understand game. I am looking forward to playing more of these types of games. 

As someone learning the language from the Genki books, this was a breath of fresh air to apply what I learned into somewhat a realistic situation. 

If you are learning japanese and don't know where to start, I can't say it's the most optimal, but for someone who has a bit of knowledge and wants to put some of it into use or need a refresher, this is an excellent memory jog. I recommend this for anyone who is entry-level into japanese. Make sure you have some pen, paper, and a self driving nature to push through this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052544029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1517144006}
review:
[u] Note: [/u]
First things first, reconsider learning Japanese. No, I'm not gatekeeping you. I'm just trying to warn you. Japan has shown time and time again its unwillingness for global cooperation, which is evident through strict border controls and xenophobic policies barring international students, among others. Passionate learners that have poured their heart into this language are mere statistics in the eyes of the LDP. If you're interested in East Asia in general, Korean and Chinese might be safer bets.

[h1] Review [/h1]
With that out of the way, let me explain why I gave this game a negative review. I found "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" tucked away in a steam sale, back when I couldn't speak a word Japanese. It's cute, simple, and delivers on what it promises. Yet it has no business being a video game.

Hiragana is a simple syllabary system that doesn't require 16 hours to master. To prove my point, most universities will breeze through both Hiragana and Katakana in the span of two lessons. A more efficient method to memorize the characters would be to write them down while looking at a hiragana chart. If you have trouble getting them to stick, try spaced repetition with programs such as Anki or websites such as Quizlet.

Whilst I agree that everyone has their separate ambitions and goals concerning language studies, I need to emphasize that Hiragana alone won't get you anywhere. In fact, this game might be worth picking up if you're content with that reality. If your purpose is to find out what Japanese is all about but not commiting to it, have at it! To everyone else, be prepared to put in a lot of time once you know how to write the characters. I promise you will have a lot of fun, though! (but keep your eyes peeled for kishida and his LDP)

author: {'steamid': '76561198018134069', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1576842359}
review:
Hiragana Battle is a perfectly enjoyable little game with an excellent educational spin. It's perfect for complete beginners to Japanese, and a fairly effective tool for committing the hiragana alphabet to memory. I had previous experience with hiragana before playing this game, and I knew a few Japanese words and phrases, which gave me a bit of an edge, but with study, review, and diligent note-taking, anyone could perform well and leave the experience with a great understanding of how to read, write, and pronounce hiragana. 

This game succeeds primarily because its educational components are so well paced, it doesn't go on too long, and it gets you right into the action. It's less than two minutes before you're learning your first five hiragana and you've been introduced to the entire plot and cast of characters. After only a short period writing, reviewing, and completing a quiz, it has you experiencing the turn-based combat that asks you to match the hiragana character with the equivalent English syllable. Once you've mastered those five, you receive a brand new set of five, and along the way you learn a bit of Japanese vocabulary, some grammar, and a few particles. Eventually, there's sidequests to complete that all have fairly unique gameplay challenges which I found simply delightful, and reward you with new vocabulary. Hiragana Battle even surprised me with the creative changes it would introduce to mix-up the sometimes tedious gameplay, which I'll leave you to discover for yourself (one example might be that when you arrive in Japan, a lot of text is now written entirely in hiragana without translation). In particular, I was a huge fan of the final dungeon and the last boss fight, which was remarkably exciting, challenging, and had a great tonal arrangement. 

As this is an RPGMaker game, it isn't as eye-catching as a stand-alone. The graphics are simple, sprite-based, and reuse a lot of assets. They picked a fairly good font for the hiragana characters and written text, and the character art is decently cool, mixing western and Japanese aesthetics. I enjoyed some of the more detailed aspects of the towns, background, and the setting for battles, and I thought the music was really good for a game of this size. There isn't much to say for the writing or story, as it's so direct and simply worded it's impossible to miss details, jokes, or what's going on. During the periods when you're learning new vocabulary and characters, it's very relaxing and easy to focus thanks to the visual and musical arrangement. 

I will say that I found some of their choices for Japanese instruction to be questionable (I believe that a few individuals pointed out a couple eccentricities in other reviews, which are a bit beyond my ability to explain), but I also thought that it taught WAY more than I expected, and that made me happy. My main gripe is that the font used for the hiragana is different than the stroke order animation, and it's not possible to keep the stroke order visible on the screen outside of a short video. Sometimes this makes it difficult to learn how to write a symbol, or you begin to associate a rather specific, fancy font with the character, when it's more common to see something simpler (the "ri" hiragana was an instance I found particular trouble with, and I eventually turned to writing it in another style that I had learned). That said, the stroke order is correct from what I recall from other materials and instructors, so it's a pretty reliable tool. 

On the subject of the gameplay, some may find it shallow, whereas I thought it was just simple. It's a turn-based RPG where "attacks" are based in matching sounds to letters, and you can also equip weapons and armour,, cast buffs and healing magic, and use items. The damage that enemies put out can be intense, so I found it's useful to have characters with strong agility and to make the correct decisions on attack order with speed to get rid of enemies without wasting your attacks. I hardly ever used improvement spells like +speed, +armour, or the block ability because battles were over quickly and the benefits wouldn't carry over. I tended to mainly use healing items and healing spells, but if you complete all the side quests it's possible to level up a ton and be able to avoid a lot of the damage while putting out enough to one-hit-kill enemies. It's a strategy game, but encounters are short, so it's not too difficult. I agree with the notion that perhaps the gameplay does not help your memory of hiragana (as compared to writing practice), because you can get into the habit of simply repeating patterns. I believe the notion that "enemies appear in clumps where you end up fighting the same few hiragana over and over" is a little dishonest as a criticism. Hiragana appear based on what you just learned, so each new level focuses on exposing you to what's new, and only rarely does it draw back on old material to try and slip you up. I think with the variety of dakouten marks, and how similar some hiragana can be, this is a suitable challenge that doesn't get boring or force you into patterns. The only time I felt that I was experiencing too many of the same encounters is when I had to "walk back and forth" over an area, since you had to complete objectives on one end of a maze, and then return to the end of it usually, and encounters would pop up too commonly for that system. Levels themselves usually only consist of one screen before they change the rules or hiragana you will fight, so I don't think it was horribly repetitive, and you have learning exercises and side-quests to break up the tedium. My tip to prevent repetition and boredom is to always go to the "main objective" of an area first, such as a supposed exit at a door or a building, so you queue up the next part of the quest, and then explore the rest of the level while you're fulfilling those objectives. Since you learn a lot, there's always new challenges that will appear, and the game will eventually even test you on extremely different, surprising material (which had my on the edge of my seat with excitement). 

Given the price, size, and satisfaction provided by Hiragana Battle, I totally recommend it even as a fun time-killer. I'm really excited to try out Katakana War and Kanji Combat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067032507', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1575509079}
review:
Amazing tool!

The game is very well designed and I think the lessons are well paced and interesting. It doesn't only teach you the hiragana, but some vocabulary too, which was nice.
The story is actually interesting and you feel like a part of the world. I found it very nice that you're not penalized for skipping lots of encounters, so you get to decide how much you want to practice (you don't need to actually battle every single thing that comes your way).

I used this game alongside a simple guide on the internet (Tofugu) and 2 apps to practice the hiragana (KanaTown on my phone, realkana.com on the PC) and I found learning this was a lot easier than I had anticipated. It took me about 11 hours to finish the game (counting the time I left the game open while using my other resources), spaced out around 3 weeks, and I'd wager it'll take about 3-4 hours or so of more practice until I can get every hiragana right without thinking too much about it, so about 15 hours total.

Although you can use just the game, battling the hiragana warriors to boredom until you know them by heart, I would recommend using some else (like the app I mentioned), because even though the battles are fine and they do work to get you to memorize stuff, they are, of course, repetitive, so it does get REAL boring at some points.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989803948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1593326517}
review: The game introduces you to a forgettable little story, and not long after, it gently introduction to your first Hiragana characters. At first glance, the concept of learning Hiragana while playing a simple RPG appears to work. But it doesn't - at all. It becomes a chore to play very quickly as you fight against Hiragana characters. Sure, it helps memorizing those characters, but so are simple cards or free learning software. The point of this game is of course gamification, and that is were it fails. There is zero variety in gameplay and fights don't have any tactical depth. It's just scrolling through the same clunky menu in search for the matching English character over and over again. Of course, this is an educational game, I understand. But then why even bother with boring fights and tedious RPG elements? Things like byuing armor take too much room and are destracting. The fights are more determined by level than actual knowledge. To be honest, I feel more like being punished for wanting to learn Japanese.  None of this is motivating me to play the game any further. It just doesn't work and is tedious as hell.

‚Ä¢ Mais no come√ßo quando se aprende os silab√°rios A-Gy≈ç / Ka-Gy≈ç / Sa-Gy≈ç s√£o introduzidas palavras com silab√°rios ainda n√£o aprendidos, introduzir as palavras assim: HA-„ÅÑ ou „ÅëÔΩ∞N-PA-„ÅÑ n√£o ajuda muito, o japon√™s √© uma l√≠ngua rica, com certeza tem palavras que podem ser aprendidas utilizando somente A-Gy≈ç ou A-Gy≈ç + Ka-Gy≈ç ou A-Gy≈ç + Ka-Gy≈ç + Sa-Gy≈ç e por a√≠ vai...

author: {'steamid': '76561198045124825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1573017069}
review:
As much as I enjoy this game, keep in mind this isn't a AAA jrpg level experience.  The story is very basic and won't change how you view the world and yourself.  If you take it as a simple lighthearted story that has comedic and ridiculous elements in order to make learning less of a repetitive chore you will find that it's alright. 

As someone that studied Japanese before this is a really fun experience.  I love old school rpgs and the battle system itself although simple and straightforward is a motivational way to memorize your hiragana.  The short breaks from straight grinding of hiragana characters to applying them to everyday life vocab is nice.  I found myself having fun running around and talking to npcs just to try and read the Japanese and test myself (even though they do tell you the translations).  Some items are only in hiragana so its fun to read them out loud and figure out what they are.  I have yet to finish them game but, so far I am most likely going to finish it and continue to the next game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015038652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1572482705}
review:
Fun little game for those looking to learn or simply refresh their Hiragana.

The game teaches all the Hiragana symbols, as well as a few dozen common words and a couple of basic phrases. It also contains some basic information about the Japanese culture to give context to some words and such. A rather perfect introduction to the language.

The "game" itself is a pretty basic jrpg. You control 4 characters. They each have attributes and you can buy combat gear and consumables, but it's all very linear. You buy the best stuff you can and that's it. Combat is similarly basic. You can attack, defend, use spells or items, but I think you're better off just attacking 100% of the time.

Game is really easy, but there's some grind to make sure you level up enough for the combat to be reasonable. But if you consider the "grind" is repeating letters and words you've learned, you kinda WANT to do it.

The game takes about ~5 hours to complete without rushing it or grinding much. 

Well worth the price if you're interested in the language.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263824172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 656, 'last_played': 1601948277}
review:
As I've now completed the game, I figured it was time to leave a review.

I've studied Japanese off and on for years and wanted to play a game to try to get back into the swing of things, as I've been starting up again and found myself occasionally hesitating on some characters ("wait, is that one 'ro' or 'ru'," etc).

This game was pretty entertaining and honestly pretty helpful in drilling the characters into my head again. I think it would be beneficial to both total newbies and to folks that just want a fun way to refresh.

There were a few game mechanics that were a little annoying (for example: you have to pick all of your team member actions at the same time, so if an enemy dies earlier than you expected, a character might end up giving the answer they intended for that enemy on a different enemy) but I've heard that many of these were fixed/changed in the next installments so I'm excited to try them out! I also wish this game provided a little more practice for vocabulary you learn throughout the game, and I hope that's also changed in the following games.

Overall, I definitely think this game is worth buying!

author: {'steamid': '76561198054700495', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1572182082}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995355816', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1571636746}
review:
The title of this game alone is enough to make some people cringe, and while that‚Äôs a little unfair, its content is certainly not dispelling that first impression. [i]Hiragana Battle[/i] isn‚Äôt just an educational RPG about learning Japanese; it‚Äôs a story where knowing Japanese can make you a world-conquering wizard. The laughable premise could be forgiven if the rest of the package was worthwhile, but the art, dialogue, audio, and gameplay are so excruciatingly bland that they should be covered by the Geneva convention. Being an [i]RPG Maker[/i] title means it‚Äôs perfectly functional, but that may be the best thing I can say about it.

I‚Äôd be lying if I said I didn‚Äôt learn some things from [i]Hiragana Battle[/i]. Whether I‚Äôll retain them is a different matter, and the experience certainly wasn‚Äôt entertaining. Combat consists exclusively of matching symbols to sounds or vice versa, with no attempt at utilizing the RPG mechanics beyond the barest possible implementation. The battles are too easy when doing well but quite punishing of mistakes, on top of being frequent and repetitive due to winding level design. All of which makes sense from an educational perspective, but an educational game is supposed to make learning [i]more[/i] exciting, not less.

[b]Score: 3/10[/b]

https://www.imlgames.com/learn-japanese-to-survive-hiragana-battle/

author: {'steamid': '76561198010597539', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1569753710}
review:
A fantastic game, and great fluid of mechanics and methods to teach Japanese. 
I really had good fun with it and I learned alot.
From my perspective, combining education in an RPG game is a brilliant idea. An idea that should be implemented more.
This game, surprisingly, has a very good soundtrack, too.
I would definitely recommend it for those who wants to learn Japanese in a productive and fun manner.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966094624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 948, 'last_played': 1569413480}
review:
I'll preface this review by saying this game isn't my first dive into learning Japanese. I took several classes in college, and did well in them. It has been years since then, and the thing about learning a new language is the importance of repetition and usage every day to maintain and excel. I didn't do this, so a lot of what I learned has dropped off in time. For me, this game was more of a refresher.

[b][u][h1]RPG Battle System[/h1][/u][/b]

As far as RPG elements go, this game is extremely basic. Standard attacking is all there is, and there is little to no difficulty at all to the game from a battle standpoint. I stayed a level or two ahead of whatever content I was zoned into, and at that level the mobs die in one hit, sometimes two, and when they damage you they often times deal zero damage. There are a few cure, antidote, awaken, etc spells, but they are rarely / never used. One major frustrating part is that for the majority of the game Eric and Leon are out of sync with the rest of the group in attack order. Until later in the game when you get a single item that can increase Eric's agility (speed), the attack order will always be Claire, Misaki, Leon, then Eric, despite Eric coming before Leon in the line up. This can get frustrating when lining up attacks, especially when you are doing a lot of one hit kills. All in all, just a bare bones battle system, but that's not what this game is about.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Simple battle system that doesn't take away from the learning experience.
[*]Extremely low difficulty to allow you to focus on the lessons and memorization.
[*]Leveling is quick, easy to out level a zone with just a few extra minutes of grinding, which is good for memorization anyway.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Battle system is a little bit too easy and can leave an experienced RPG player, or someone that has a minor level of background with Japanese already, wanting just a little bit more.
[*]The UI for selecting the right answers gets quite encumbered. In the early stages of the game it isn't too much of a big deal, but later on when you have 30+ answers to shift through per person it can become very tedious. A sub level system would have worked much better.
[*]If you've played any of the older Final Fantasy games, then you'll be familiar with the random battle encounter system. That in and of itself is a whole different level of discussion, but I personally put it in the con section.
[/list]

[b][u][h1]Teaching System[/h1][/u][/b]

The big ticket item for this game is, of course, teaching you Hiragana. It does so in a fairly ingenuitive way. Each enemy represents a letter of hiragana, and it is your job to attack it with the romanji equivalence to deal damage. If you don't have it written down or previous teachings, this is a great way to beat it into your head. Each zone focuses on a particular set of hiragana that you were just taught, with a few previous ones sprinkled in. You can easily review past lessons outside of battle. The lessons themselves are fine and do their job accordingly, but the difference in font used for the enemies and lesson presentations vs what they teach you to write can be annoying to first timers. The best English equivalent I can think of is the font used by computers and text for lowercase a vs how we are taught to write it using pen and paper. The vocal recording of each letter is almost robotic and often unintelligible, but the vocabulary words are just fine.

Speaking of vocabulary words, this game teaches you basic vocabulary (some of which is typically written in katakana, but written in hiragana for the purpose of the game) that you'd often find in an intro to Japanese text book. Unfortunately the game fails to utilize any of these teachings outside of the standard alphabet until the final zone, where they suddenly decide to test your vocabulary skills as well. There are two sections in the game where they flip the battle process and make you select the correct hiragana symbol to attack romanji characters. This is a brilliant system, but sadly it is under utilized. With a few simple UI corrections they could have integrated the two in order to make a much more robust teaching system.

An additional flaw is the repetition. Yes, repetition is part of learning a second language, but what I'm talking about is at the programming level. The way it is currently programmed to work is that there are battle sets, and when you encounter a battle you have a random chance of each set. An example of a set would be the following three enemies: "ka", "ku", and "o". It is possible to get this exact match up several times in a row. Add on the fact that the battle system remembers what the last answer you selected for each character was, it can make a grind very easy without much need to pay attention. After a while in each zone, you'll figure out exactly what each battle set is. The way it [i]should[/i] have been programmed, would be to have two sets of possibilities in each fight. First, a percentage chance for the entire roster to contain only new hiragana characters, and a chance to contain one or two previous characters as well. From there, each set is completely randomized with the parameters set for the possible outcome for each zone.

As you progress through the game, you run into the case where you will start to see less and less (if not none at all) of previous hiragana letters. Since the game isn't utilizing vocabulary to maximize the learning, or at least comprehension, of the letters you have to rely on memory and lists when the final zone comes around. In a traditional class / book setting, your exposure to previously learned letters would continue as you used your vocabulary. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Good job at repetition to help drive the letters into memory.
[*]Simplistic system teaching system that is easy to revise to refresh any forgotten previously earned lessons. 
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Repetitious (in programming) battle system allows you to naturally make use of pattern recognition and system design flaws to negate the teaching and memorization process.
[*]Under utilized vocabulary section that would have put this game on a whole different level. Even if you ignored the actual meaning of the vocabulary, using them as a reading and letter comprehension tool would have done wonders.
[*]Most alphabet letters fade out after one or two zones. You never / hardly see them again (such as the base vowel section, "k", "t", and "s" rows are a good example, meaning it makes them easy to forget.
[/list]


[b][u][h1]Conclusion[/h1][/u][/b]

All in all this is a good game to use in tandem if you are learning Japanese through other professional means, or just trying to brush up stuff that you already knew but forgotten to time (such as my case). It's cheap enough when on sale, but for sub $10 at base price it's still a good deal. I haven't said anything about the story line because, well it's an educational game designed to teach you the alphabet... If you're here for the story, well then there is no hope for you from the start. All in all, despite some of the design issues it still does a decent job of getting the user familiar with hiragana and that's really all we're here for.

TL;DR: If you already knew hiragana in the past, or even just want to learn from scratch, the game is worth it at its cheap price point. This goes double when it's on sale.

review: Well... I learned hiragana with this, so I have to give it credit for that! Honestly, it's a really good educational tool for learning hiragana. I highly recommend using a notepad to practise writing the hiragana as you learn them as it's a good way to help memorise them, and they show you the exact right order in which you should draw the lines of the hiragana characters, which is actually quite important.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006824332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1566013607}
review:
This is the first game in the "Learn Japanese to Survive!" series; I am writing this review after having completed all three games of the series.

Hiragana are one of the writing systems of Japan, used for representing the sounds (rather than meanings) of Japanese words.  In this game you have to defend against an army of monsters shaped like hiragana by correctly identifying the sound of the characters.

There is a story, a map to explore, and combat against the monsters; these are sufficiently entertaining but the main point to the game is teach you this Japanese writing systems.  The game teaches you to recognise the characters, it also shows you how to write them, though there is no assessment of writing, so it is entirely up to you if you want to practise writing or not.  

The combat system and combat map exploration have a number of flaws, such as not being able to go very far without being ambushed by monsters and having to identify the same monster multiple times to defeat it.  Most of these flaws are ironed out in the later games, which have much smoother game play, but this is a solid start to the series.  

In summary, while the game mechanics are somewhat basic and could have been improved, it is a fun game for learning hiragana, and I would recommend it to anyone looking to learn how to read the characters of this Japanese writing system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025403989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1566234120}
review:
Boff‚Ä¶ premetto di non sapere nulla di nulla di giapponese. Questo √® un gioco realizzato con il motore di  RPGMaker al fine di insegnare al giocatore il sistema giapponese di scrittura Hiragana.

Ora, vorrei separare la questione giocosa da quella culturale.

Dal punto di vista del gioco si tratta, appunto, di un tipico prodotto RPGMaker, nel senso che prevede i soliti scontri casuali (anche se non tutti i giochi realizzati con quel motore li contemplano), con una trama di base, l‚Äôacquisto di equipaggiamento per rafforzare il party e l‚Äôottenimento di punti esperienza per livellare i personaggi che devono portare a compimento una quest principale e una serie di quest secondarie (molto poche e spicce, spesso servono a imparare solo qualche sostantivo in giapponese come premio di missione).

Il problema √® che √® tutto molto scarno: la storia principale √® appunto una scusa per l‚Äôinsegnamento dei caratteri Hiragana, ma √® brutta che pi√π brutta non si pu√≤. I personaggi sono davvero insulsi e i dialoghi al livello dei Teletubbies. 

La frequenza degli incontri casuali √® ossessionante. Forse √® voluta per far s√¨ che il giocatore abbia la nausea a osservare i caratteri Hiragana (sono loro i mostri che si affrontano nel gioco) affinch√© se li stampi ben bene in testa, ma dal punto di vista del gioco √® poco divertente. Anche perch√© nelle varie locazioni i caratteri sono sempre gli stessi, propri di quelle locazioni, per cui si affrontano tanti combattimenti di seguito con nemici/simboli tutti uguali: non so se la frequenza sia un aspetto positivo, perch√© l‚Äôunica cosa che entra nella memoria del giocatore √® il pattern ripetitivo della forma dei simboli che appaiono sul terreno di scontro a ogni battaglia. Una volta riconosciuti 2-3 pattern di base √® possibile andare a memoria, meccanicamente, e risolvere i combattimenti. 

In pratica la battaglia si svolge cos√¨: ci sono due o tre nemici che hanno le forme dei simboli Hiragana e il giocatore deve colpirli riconoscendo la loro pronuncia/il loro nome. Il danno arriva solo se si becca il nome giusto dei simboli, altrimenti √® sempre zero (quindi di base il sistema RPG √® di tipo ON/OFF, ovvero √® molto povero). Quando vedrete una formazione che si ripete, sceglierete le pronunce giuste solo perch√© eravate abituati a farlo, non chiedendovi pi√π cosa sia quel simbolo. Peggio, a volte le formazioni uguali si susseguono in sequenza e i comandi rimangono quelli precedentemente memorizzati (anche se l‚Äôopzione nel men√π √® disabilitata), per cui la battaglia si vince senza nemmeno scegliere i nomi dei simboli.  In altre parole: √® tutto talmente ripetitivo da non risultare pi√π istruttivo, bens√¨ solo meccanico, alienante, da linea di montaggio.

Io dopo ore di gioco ancora facevo fatica con l‚Äôassociazione simbolo-nome (perch√© molti simboli hanno forme similari) e guardavo in continuazione sui miei appunti solo per distinguere la loro forma. Era la mia unica preoccupazione durante gli scontri. Non solo, quando si devono realizzare gli attacchi appare un men√π con una lista infinita delle possibili pronunce dei simboli, tra le scelte di attacco, e bisogna scegliere quelle giuste: davvero scomodo dal punto di vista dell‚Äôinterfaccia grafica di RPGMaker (sapete, no? Se avete una lista di 100 oggetti, per scegliere l‚Äôultimo dovete scorrervela ogni santa volta fino alla fine), che per queste cose √® davvero pessima. Verso la fine i simboli sono sostituiti da vere e proprie parole in Hiragana e bisogna attaccarli con la loro traduzione in inglese (quindi conviene scrivere su carta anche ogni parola imparata durante il gioco) e questo √® gi√† pi√π interessante.

Non basta, parlavo RPG scialbo: √® possibile usare anche le abilit√† dei singoli personaggi, ma √® davvero tutto inutile, basta spammare in continuazione gli attacchi fisici della vostra truppa per terminare le battaglie in massimo due turni. Due turni massimo, perch√© basta salire di un paio di livelli in quelle stesse locazioni e acquistare le armi pi√π potenti per instankillare i nemici.

Lato RPG: pessimo. 

Cos√¨ come pessime sono le mappe: 

‚Ä¢	graficamente sono un lavoro davvero basico, forse utilizzando solo asset gi√† esistenti del software RPGMaker (la sensazione √® quella) nonostante i ritratti ben disegnati di tutti i personaggi e degli NPC;
‚Ä¢	dimensionalmente si tratta di mappe davvero piccole, oltre che poche in numero. Quando sono pi√π estese di una paio di schermate si tratta comunque di labirinti monotoni;
‚Ä¢	lato esplorazione il gioco √® zero: non c‚Äô√® nulla da cercare e da scoprire. L‚Äôinterattivit√† con ogni oggetto dello sfondo √® zero, tranne che per gli NPC e i negozi;
‚Ä¢	i personaggi che si muovono sulle mappe sono affetti da tarantella: schizzano come missili. Ed √® possibile anche farli correre! Sembra di vedere un film in avanzamento al quadruplo della velocit√† base. Provavo fastidio alla vista. Posso capire che lo fai per non fare annoiare il giocatore durante gli spostamenti, ma a questo punto realizzate una visual novel, no (ma l√¨ per√≤ ci vuole la storia, e qui non c‚Äô√®)?

Rimane la questione dello scopo culturale.

Ammetto di avere imparato pi√π di qualcosa, i caratteri base, che sono tanti, e qualche parola al volo. Durante il gioco vengono introdotti parecchi elementi per√≤, per cui si tratta essenzialmente di impararli a memoria senza sapere come si usano. Il gioco per√≤ non sfrutta questo meccanismo a suo vantaggio, tranne una manciata di volte. 

Mi spiego meglio: mi si insegna come si dice ‚Äúpenna‚Äù usando i caratteri Hiragana. Ok. Ma che me ne faccio? Devo mettermi allo specchio e ripetere la loro sequenza a memoria? Il gioco non insegna nemmeno questioni di grammatica se non verso la fine e solo per dovere di cronaca, perch√© non nelle meccaniche di gioco. In rarissime occasioni viene chiesto di comprare un certo oggetto, scrivendolo in Hiragana, per cui al negozio bisogna stare attenti ai caratteri che formano la parola dell‚Äôoggetto (‚Äúportami la spada kotoro (nome a caso)!‚Äù e nel negozio devi capire di che spada si tratta solo dal nome in Hiragana degli articoli). Questo √® un meccanismo interessante, ma sfruttato quasi per nulla.

In altre parole, anche se prendete appunti, alla fine del gioco avrete una lista di una sessantina di parole e una sessantina di simboli base di cui non avrete nessuna utilit√†, se non per piacere personale (a meno che non abbiate davvero intenzione di imparare il giapponese, ma seriamente e iniziando un corso successivamente). Verso le fasi finali dell‚Äôavventura (una decina di ore in tutto, circa) verranno insegnate alcune frasi di utilit√† mediante i caratteri imparati in precedenza, il che non √® male, perch√© sono frasi riciclabili alla convenienza. Ad esempio, ‚Äúposso prendere questo libro?‚Äù pu√≤ essere utilizzata come frase generica per qualsiasi altro oggetto. Naturalmente permane il problema di imparare a memoria i singoli vocaboli.  Questi passaggi, per√≤, non sono funzionali al gioco, ma sono pi√π che altro intermezzi culturali indipendenti. 

Sul forum ho letto qualche critica ad alcune leggerezze (ad esempio alla pronuncia delle parole), ma per chi come me non ne sa un‚Äôacca non penso che sia un problema, almeno per sapere cosa √® un dato simbolo e come si legge.

Dai, visto il prezzo basso e il valore didattico (anche se molto basico) mi va di dargli una sufficienza. Il gioco sottostante, come RPG, per√≤ √® davvero pessimo. In giro con RPGMaker c‚Äô√® molto di meglio, anche gratis. 

Perch√© mi soffermo troppo nella critica al gioco? Beh, perch√© proprio gli sviluppatori lo strombazzano. Infatti, nella pagina dello store affermano ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt just educational software ‚Äì this is a full-blown RPG specifically designed to keep you engaged.‚Äù Lasciate perdere, dategli solo il valore educativo che come RPG fa molto ridere.

6/10 (anche perch√© ho scoperto come si scrive Tokyo e ora il mio gatto lo chiamo Ne-ko)

author: {'steamid': '76561198108270275', 'num_games_owned': 825, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 1816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1816, 'last_played': 1566128940}
review:
Le mal√©fique sorcier Noburo tente de conqu√©rir le monde, mais tout particuli√®rement l'archipel japonais. √Ä l'aide de ses puissants guerriers Hiragana, il d√©cime toutes les forces se trouvant sur son chemin. Toutefois, un groupe de jeune survivants, aid√©s de leur fid√®le sensei, vont se mettre √† sa poursuite. Seul probl√®me √† l'horizon, les arm√©es de Noburo ne peuvent √™tre vaincus que par une ma√Ætrise compl√®te des Hiragana.

Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle est avant tout, comme son nom l'indique, un jeu d'apprentissage niveau d√©butant qui introduit le joueur au syst√®me d'√©criture japonais. Premier d'une trilogie, le jeu va ici nous enseigner progressivement les caract√®res Hiragana japonais √† travers une s√©rie de courtes le√ßons nous permettant de ma√Ætriser peu √† peu le syst√®me d'√©criture et leur prononciation, mais √©galement d'apprendre un peu de vocabulaire, des r√®gles grammaticales et des phrases utiles au pays nippon.

Pour mettre en pratique ces enseignements, on va affronter les terribles soldats Hiragana √† travers les √Æles du Japon dans un JRPG classique rappelant les premiers opus de Final Fantasy. Mais ici, pas de combat acharn√© avec des armes o√π de la magie. Non! Le seul moyen de survivre √† l'ennemi sera rendu possible par l'association des Hiragana √† leur traduction (ou vice-versa). Notre meilleure arme restera donc notre m√©moire, ou de nos fid√®les papiers et crayons qui nous accompagnera tout du long.

Le jeu n'est pas en soit tr√®s difficile ou trop long. Les combats sont simples et ne demandent pas un grand fan des JRPG. On est avant tout l√† pour apprendre. Les combats ne font ici office que d'un syst√®me tr√®s bien pens√© pour mettre en pratique chacune des le√ßons √† force de r√©p√©tition au cours de petites escarmouches. Il faut simplement faire des associations justes et l'ennemi va dispara√Ætre au bout de deux coups. Aucune prise de t√™te si on suit correctement les le√ßons et que l'on prends des notes.

Au fil de notre aventure, divers personnages vont √©galement nous lancer sur de courtes qu√™tes nous permettant d'obtenir encore un peu de vocabulaire, mais √©galement d'apprendre un peu plus de la culture japonaise.

Graphiquement, le jeu est tr√®s mignon, un univers l√©g√®rement pixellis√© nous rappelant encore une fois les premiers Final Fantasy sur NES, mix√© √† une musique entra√Ænante pour les combats et notre visite des diff√©rentes villes nippones. Le jeu est relativement court et se compl√®te en 10-12 heures, variant sur notre capacit√© √† m√©moriser le syst√®me Hiragana et du d√©sir du joueur √† mettre en pratique chacune des le√ßons.

Seul petit b√©mol qui pourrait rebuter certains: le jeu est tout en anglais, mais ne demande pas pour autant une grande ma√Ætrise de la langue de Tolkien.

Donc, si vous avez toujours voulu apprendre le syst√®me d'√©criture japonais ou que vous vous int√©ressiez un tant soit peu √† la culture nippone et que vous ne vous √™tres jamais lanc√© dans l'aventure, c'est un jeu parfait pour faire le premier pas!

review:
hiragana battle is a great game to start with learning japanese characters.  story and gameplay are pretty simple, learning worked pretty good and fast for me and some of the games npcs even tell you interesting things about the japanese language and country.
the story isn't really long so you can easily play it a few times to make sure you remember all the characters.
5/7 would buy it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998404426', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1565495100}
review:
LEARN HIRAGANA TO SURVIVE - 4/10

Quick Summary: While an ok learning tool for Hiragana focusing on repetition, it's focus on repeated non-random battles, cliche and dull story, barebones mechanics and superfluous information make me sad to say I can not recommend this to people learning japanese. If your SOLE focus is to learn to read Hiragana or you have focusing problems than this game might help but I think if you're truly planning on learning there are much better (free) resources out there.

LHtS is an old school focused Japanese RPG similar to the early final fantasy games featuring top down movement, sidequests, levelling up and turn based fighting. It's very clear that the gameplay takes a back seat to the learning so I won't delve on the gameplay for too long but suffice to say it's lackluster at best. The mechanics are simple, equipment upgrades are simply purchased or found within the mandatory dungeons you visit and overall this isn't meant to be a complicated game because it's focus is on teaching.

The story follows Claire and her friends on a mission to defeat a wizard named Noburo who (for no particular reason at all) unleashes "Hiragana Warriors" across the world and because they came to your town for 13 seconds, Claire sets out to track them all down. However they can only be defeated by learning their true names so a visitor from Japan named Misaki aids you and your friends in studying these characters to defeat them.

Let me state before I continue that before playing this, I already knew how to read Hiragana but I bought this game before I studied and ended up playing this much later as supplementary material so I am not the intended audience.

The game implores you to get out a pen and paper to write your lessons down (and you should, you won't be able to remember them if you don't). Learning works like this:
1. Before each quest, Misaki will teach you a set of Hiragana including stroke order, sound and spelling
2. Afterwards she gives you a small quiz to see what you have learnt
3. During the quest, the enemies you fight will be Hiragana enemies
4. To defeat them, you need to "attack" them by selecting the right answer in your attack menu to do damage
      So, instead of attacking with a standard attack, you select the correct answer depending on them enemy. Selecting „ÅÇ for "a" will then deal damage to that character (damage is based on weapon and level). So, it's a pretty simple RPG but there are an enormous amount of flaws. However, let me talk about the positives first.

During your lessons, you'll be able to get all you need to each Hiragana including pronunciation, stroke order, the amount of strokes etc. You'll also get some extra tips on how to write them which I found pretty handy and didn't know before. The game also does a good job by separating each quest into certain Hiragana warrior so the enemies you fight will mainly be focused on the Hiragana you just studied instead of much older (or new ones). This way by fighting the forced repetition you'll learn all you need to know before moving onto the next quest. 

But now I need to list some of the various problems:
- Enemies are almost always faster than you for no reason. Claire always got the first hit in a battle, but all the Hiragana warriors then had their turn before the rest of my party could move. No matter how much I levelled this never changed and became frustrating because my party would ALWAYS take damage.
- Enemies aren't randomized. During each quest, the Hiragana warriors you fight will always come in the same groups, in the same order. So the first fight you might fight "ga", "ka", "ke" and "ge", then second you'll fight "ki" and "ku", and the third you'll fight the first lineup again. This meant instead of remembering what you've studied, you remember simply because you fought the exact same enemies before and you remembered which ones they were solely because you just defeated them.
- The encounter rate is RIDICULOUSLY high. Every 3 steps you'll run into an enemy. Once I got halfway through the game I just ran from every enemy because there is no penalty. You can complete sidequests to get points to level up so you don't even need to fight and still be on par with the enemies.
- You still have to fight Hiragana you know. Selecting the right attack for the right Hiragana doesn't mean they die, they just take damage until they do die. So not only do you have to select the right Hiragana, you have to do it multiple times every fight. If an enemy dies before your next in line gets to attack them, and you selected the now deceased Hiragana for them to attack, then they'll attack another Hiragana and do 0 damage because it's the wrong one, and the only reason is because you just killed it.
- The more Hiragana you learn, the more bogged down your attack menu becomes with answers/attacks so you spend more time scrolling for the right one rather than being able to pick it at a reasonable pace, artificially padding game time.
- Spells are useless, and I never used them except in the final fight where they made the fight impossible to lose.
- Halfway and beyond you'll learn some grammar, what some words mean and so forth but it's all irrelevant until the very final battle.

Otherwise, the general story writing is bad, the storyline is bad, being forced to fight every 3 seconds is annoying, the soundtrack is very average and honestly it really pains me to not be able to say you should buy this.

If you NEED to have interaction to learn something (maybe you have ADHD, or a super low attention span) than give this a go for sure. You have nothing to lose. But there's no point in ONLY learning Hiragana and if you need a game to study something than you're probably not ready to learn anyway. If you DO really want to learn Hiragana, there's plenty of (free) places where you can probably learn faster (I recommend Tofugu for Hiragana and Katakana) and still have fun.

Props to the developers for making an educational resource however. I wish more developers did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102027126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1564620040}
review: I've tried many ways to learn Hiragana is this, so far, is the one that has me recognizing the symbols in Japanese words out in the wild, not just being able to correctly guess them through multiple choice and process of elimination. However, I have a disability that effects my hands and I can't even hold a pencil correctly, so I don't even write in English. I type. I find it very annoying and tedious that the game forces me to sit through instructions on how to write each character. I wish that were skippable. They play each slow animation twice and give you a tip before allowing you to move on. I wish I could just opt out of the writing altogether. I'm playing this game for memorization only.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844501667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1562645399}
review: Honestly, at first I thought the idea was funny and probably would be interesting to dabble in because I'm already learning hiragana. But this game is so much fun that I got a little addicted after learning a few lessons, and I learned basic things I didn't know before! This has gotten me more motivated to memorize the characters, even at first I didn't want to bring out a note book and pen but it helped me take useful notes and I can look back at it if I have trouble remembering what character I'm fighting against! [b]Get this game if you want to learn more and have a fun adventure while memorizing![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197994157506', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1562825156}
review:
Great game for learning Hiragana.
Really helped me memorize the characters. Repeated identification of the individual characters after learning really helped me lock them in my memory.

In terms of gameplay, there's definitely room for improvement.
Wished there were an editable battle speed, as the battles progressed too slowly for my tastes as I progressed.
Also, this may be a limitation of the tool used to develop the product, but each hiragana being listed as "Answers" made it difficult to sort through by the end. Could have benefited from some sort of sub selection system.

As a learning tool, would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198444967389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1563067993}
review: Downloaded this game on a whim and already I'm having fun learning all the hiragana! I'm pretty big fan of tropey JRPGs, so it's nice to actually learn something while I'm grinding. You do have to take notes, though, and it's probably best to supplement this with another Japanese learning resource, like this one: http://www.guidetojapanese.org/learn/

author: {'steamid': '76561198146244966', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1559779278}
review:
This game is exactly that: a game. not some palyful learning as most learning games. 
I knew Hiragana already and I still had a lot of fun playing this. The story is fun and surprising at times (no spoilers). Since the main point is to learn the writing system the gear (armor,weapons,items) and the fighting system is relatively simple. You have some minor magic and can only use one type of weapon. You will have to upgrade them though. 
The learning side has introductions and informational dialogue. you see how characters are written - however you do not have to write them yourself. The main focus is on recodnition. You see a Hirgana and you need to know what it means/how it is pronounced. 
Some small vocabulary words are also introduced. 
I am very happy about this game and recommend it to everyone who likes to play and learn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202470721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1561924732}
review: this is really damn helpful if you're a beginner like myself. not only does it allow you to learn at your own pace, but it keeps you interested at the same time. i honestly love the battle system because it helps you make the connections easier and let me tell you, making connections with this language is hard as hell unless you play this game. its use of sidequests to teach you a few misc phrases here and there are really nice. it also makes for a great incentive for 100% completing the game. i also like that it gives you vocab every few hiragana lessons. but yeah, if you're looking for a good way to teach yourself japanese, dont hesitate to buy the bundle like i did. (do that before jun 9, 2019 because it's at a crazy low price right now)

review: I have a lot of trouble with languages. I've taken Japanese at least twice, and forgotten most of it. It feels like this is really helping, since I'm already gaining back a lot of the familiarity I lost. It's also cool that I'm starting to recognize the characters and what they sound like before thinking of their English equivalent, which has never happened before. It's been "what does this sound like in English?" for the longest time...
