author: {'steamid': '76561198299871123', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2115, 'last_played': 1570697669}
review:
lovely idea. but the game system is rather annoying. you can't avoid your enemies, and what's even worse is they're OP and armor + weaps, are too expensive, so when you gotta fight an army (as in hiragana attacking enemies 3in a row) you always gotta start over most of the time.

moreover, your skills+boosts are really useless too, because those hiragana monsters just spam you with OP atks as soon as you used your boosts/skills and makes the use of them completely pointless and a waste , hell they often kill your entire team.
overall I like the idea and the story but "katakana war" is 100% my favorite one of those japanese studying games-
kanji war is very amazing too, basically only hiragana war is a pain to play through. but worth it tho as you better your japanese skills a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113389508', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1559764972}
review:
It is an entertainting game plus it teaches some Japanese, which if the one playing it is learning it helps remembering the kanas.

The battle system is well done and an excelent idea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059973338', 'num_games_owned': 460, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1560934249}
review: Although the story and the characters are really boring and the game gets (sometimes annoyingly) grindy, this game is a fun and unique way to learn hiragana. I only wish there was a way to revise what you have learned after completing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037440090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1702407014}
review: Very Cool

author: {'steamid': '76561198030688474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2147, 'last_played': 1577988078}
review:
It's a solid choice for beginners or people who want to refresh their skills after a longer time, less for memorizing already learned hiragana..

The game's JRPG style is fun enogh to not make learning a chore, but the menus and fighting system are somewhat clunky.
Without the learning aspect I honestly wouldn't want to replay it.

The game has no elegant way to train hiragana reading after completing it, so you will probably be back to standard exercises after finishing it if you want to be able to read them fluently.

Still, I recommend it for beginners who want to learn some Japanese language basics in a game setting for a fair price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022285349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1559043409}
review:
If you're planning to study Japanese (or get back to it after a long break), this is a great tool to help you review and stay on top of your hiragana.

It's incredibly straightforward and easy to get into, and helps you to slowly build up your hiragana knowledge, while having a bit of fun. It's almost like you're playing a game

author: {'steamid': '76561198003450322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1596800800}
review: You may think is just about learning hiragana characters, but it's trying to learn you everything about hiragana and other stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257745804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1625552678}
review:
Got this game for free.
When I first saw the videos seeing your characters fighting some hiragana characters.
I was like "what". but I still decided to give it a try.
For an RPG game, it might be simple but it is indeed educational.
Using the right words to beat the enemies. it works.
I'm not really interested in learning Japanese. but this might change my mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140975636', 'num_games_owned': 2826, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1561356910}
review: Was hoping for a harder challenge. Still a good educational game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035462656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1530445824}

author: {'steamid': '76561198084030140', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1568166973}
review: arigato.......

author: {'steamid': '76561198069016284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1149, 'last_played': 1650067656}
review: If you're planning on getting this game thinking you'll be fluent in Japanese by the end, don't. The game only gives you an understanding of how the Hiragana system works, as well as teaches you a few words, many of which are typically written in Katakana or Kanji. If you're looking for a charming RPG and are interested in learning some Japanese in the process, you might want to give this one a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970185746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1497857368}
review: This was helpful for practicing the pronunciation, learning the stroke order of writing the characters, and acquiring basic vocabulary. It's a cute idea to battle the characters as another method of drilling with flashcards, but it still largely relies on memory and rote learning.

review:

Fun little JRPG style game with a very generic story, but it works and keeps you interested through the learning process. Which this game is meant for.

You'll learn all Hiragana syllables, including dakuten and handakuten. 
You'll learn some honorifics and their purpose. -san, -kun etc.
You'll learn some language structure.
You'll learn some basic japanese words like „Å®„ÇÇ„Å†„Å° & „Å∞„Çì„Åî„ÅØ„Çì
You'll learn to read hiragana. Use online sources for reading practice. Helps a ton.

review:

UPDATE: this is a good tool for beginners to learn hiragana. if you want to get anywhere in Japanese, though, you're gonna have to look a LOT farther than this game. Still, it's a good way to start.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967605168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1561060864}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027217274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 855, 'last_played': 1562131275}
review:
Took me around 13 hours to finish this game, and by the end of it I am feeling fairly confident in reading hiragana. I did have a bit of prior knowledge through my school but it has been about 6+ years since I had done anything really hiragana related. 

Another thing I did that may have helped was, as I was learning new hiragana I would write it down in a book a few times as well as anything else I thought would be good to write down such as how the dakuten and handakuten affected the hiragana.

There were a few times were I had to grind some areas just to get up a few levels but it wasn't that bad as it helped me get use to reading the characters. I started the last mission with a party level of about 20 (though I also did all of the side quests and had what I think was the best gear). 

I tend to not like JRPGs, but this game was a fun way to learn hiragana. I will be continuing with this series. Though I will wait for a sale for Katakana War and Kanji Combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198885505847', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1567992776}
review:
Aunque el juego este en English lo compre asi aprendo los dos juntos.
Lo jugue por 50min y me encanto pero me gustaria que tuviera mas opciones de juego y Logros.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025265034', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1560010510}
review:
played it 20 minutes

intro is cute
lesson (first five letters were introduced) is well

but when the actual fights (learning repetition) happens, the game is WAAAY too slow.
you should be able to skip fighting animations and accelerate the text speed.
even Pokemon RPGs allow you these simple things

I just quit because I needed to answer the same question four times to solve it.

Round 1:  "it's the letter a"
Round 2:  "again? it's the letter a"
Round 3:  "eehhh... a"
Round 4:  Ragequit

absolutely reduces efficiency and multiplies the boredom and time consumption to an unacceptable amount

author: {'steamid': '76561198880841987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1559829268}
review:
It's fine. If you already know hiragana, it honestly just kind of drags on. I'm not going to not recommend it, as it seems like a cool way to learn hiragana for beginners, just as the game says. But the combat is far uninteresting enough to keep someone interested who already knows it. It kind of has the mid 2000's final fantasy psp remake flair to it, which I do like.

So, buy this if you like JRPGs and don't really know hiragana, but not otherwise.

review:
There aren't many games like this one to learn hiragana. 
Even though this game has some problems like
-After a while it's pointless to fight enemies and you can't avoid them.
-Would like to see some speed up of fight, it feels really slow.
-Few skills / useless skills

Story is fine, nothing special.

On thing that i really liked was when i had to buy correct item written in hiragana. There are not much of this in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024597825', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1557386288}
review:
the repetition does make you identify the characters faster the more you do it.
the story is kinda shallow but it shows you are going places 
associates words to what you see over just being a concept

Over all game play does require some rpg knowledge as Eric is a little slow putting more agility on him will help him attack before the hiragana characters do.

bad things would be that the audio reading the text is VERY FAST, almost inaudible
game play is kinda slow and theres no skip function
the encounter rate is RIDICULOUSLY annoying some times. Like i just want to explore. please. ive answered this same set 5 times flawlessly, leave me alone.
Again the repetition does help you learn but theres a point where you kinda stop paying attention to learning and go through the motion. i guess its working then? idk. just kinda gets me sometimes like damn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198176549735', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1560968070}
review:
well um, it's an educational game and has served its purpose.
it's the same beginner course we study at college
now as for the "should i buy this game?"
well if you know so little of the japanese writing system, then heck yea go for it
if you already passed that level then don't,you can learn something more rewarding from youtube
it's an rpg maker with rpg maker's sprites and assets, but that doesn't change the fact that it was made by actual japanese teachers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073868152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1561603782}
review: A great way to learn the Hiragana characters. I see other people complaining about how the game is too lengthy or "grindy", but that's not necessarily true. If you're learning a new language with characters you aren't used to, repetition is key when it comes to learning it. So for me, going through the frequent encounters really solidifies my knowledge; I have to memorize them to speed through the annoying battles and learn them in the process. I think the story is okay so far, not extremely interesting but not bad either. I think the game does an excellent job at teaching you, and if you're a fan of RPGs, this would be a great way to learn. If you aren't willing to go through an RPG experience, go to Duolingo or something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159034621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1500115039}
review:
So this was the game that taught me Hiragana back when I purchased it in 2017. I'd been having a hard time trying to memorise all the characters and I was getting overwhelmed with the idea that this one only one of the Japanese scripts I was gonna have to learn. But then I found this game and thought hey why not?

Best Decision Ever.

I picked it up super quickly, and the lessons included were amazing. Sure the story isn't amazing but obviously if you're playing it, you aren't looking for a particularly riveting story. However the trouble I had with it was the gameplay itself would sometimes be so frustrating. I could tell you all the hiragana characters on the screen but because I'd spent more time revising hiragana than I had grinding to get good equipment to beat said hiragana enemies quickly, any knowledge I had obtained was useless because the enemies themselves were wiping out my party super quickly which made continuing a bit tedious. I feel as though the RPG Maker side of things could have been better balanced to meet the needs of an educational game so that an amateur could still enjoy it regardless of their proficiency with RPGs. 

Anyway, despite those difficulties, this was still the game that taught me Hiragana and it took less time than I thought. If learning through games like this is more your style than flashcards or plain old studying, then give it a go ^^

author: {'steamid': '76561198155209334', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1555485183}
review: This is game crap and waste of money. The game is super ugly and story is far away from interesting. Everything is used from free RPG maker without any effort from Sleepy Duck. And ofcourse there are other more interesting and entertaining way to learn Japanese. For example free app in google store - TakosJapanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054130365', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1555300408}
review:
It's like Rosetta Stone, but if you had autism.
Seriously make more language games like this. The grinding of old jrpgs works perfectly for memorizing the hiragana characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033388937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 294, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1555478558}
review:
I'm actually remembering the hiragana easily now, and it's fun :)
Game mechanics are simple, but work well.
Fight hiragana characters, level up, learn new skills, get new equipment!

Recommended for beginners, or those looking for an entertaining way to practise and get tips.

Very useful for learning the correct brush (pen) strokes for writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005640638', 'num_games_owned': 2067, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1554645925}
review:
Lo he jugado ya despu√©s de saber hiragana. Y lo cierto es que... una maravilla no es, pero no puedo darle un pulgar abajo a una idea con tan buena intenci√≥n.

Tomemos la parte mala: Yo no habr√≠a elegido RPGMaker como base para un juego educativo. Al avanzar, uno encuentra que el grindeo de niveles se vuelve una barrera completamente opuesta al aprendizaje en s√≠. Adem√°s, con un poco de ganas, cualquiera con inter√©s por el idioma japon√©s (aunque solo sea movido por afici√≥n al manga) puede aprender hiragana y katakana en apenas unos d√≠as con ayuda de un librillo de mnemotecnia. Con este juego como √∫nica fuente, sin duda es m√°s lento.

Para los que est√°is leyendo esto, hispanohablantes, adem√°s hay que considerar que est√° de base en ingl√©s.

¬øPero tiene parte buena? S√≠, porque la verdad es que para estar encajonado en los l√≠mites de ser un JRPG cl√°sico, es una idea que se sale de los esquemas t√≠picos, envuelta en una aventurilla ligera para todas las edades. Tambi√©n sirve de buena motivaci√≥n para animarse a estudiar el idioma y no se limita exclusivamente al silabario, sino que por el camino va presentando algunas frases de conversaci√≥n b√°sica en japon√©s y notas culturales. Puede ser una buena base inicial, siempre que el ingl√©s no sea un problema para el jugador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047377281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1554709338}
review: As an intro to hiragana, i think this doesnt work well. Even when i have the correct answer for all 4 enemy hiragana on the screen, one of them will attack before i can answer, and just decimate my team because i didnt grind enough early on. But since this is a language, i shouldnt need to grind. The fact i know the sounds each hiragana character makes is my progress. I dont want to play this like a regular old RPG if its goal is to teach.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012401727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1584287188}
review: Game won't start. Tried repairing, running as admin, compatibility mode etc. Started once. Fine. Took me a while till I had time to play again. Won't start. Nothing helps. Same for the 2 sequel. F*ck it. Can't give them back because I bought them too long ago. Can't recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092312756', 'num_games_owned': 1201, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1554286291}
review:
No for me. The first few hours were fun. But the monsters get much tougher to beat and spawn in 3s and 4s. You'll spend most of your time running away from battle. You also have to consider where to spend your currency (whether to buy weapon/armour and whether to buy the lower tier one or save up for the higher tier) and whether to level up the whole party with 'bonus points' now or save them for later. The characters you learn per hour decreases, kinda going against the main reason why people would play this game.

So basically I've learnt like half of the characters and I have to choose between playing through the dull battles to finish the syllabus or abandoning this game with half the syllabus.

I hope there's an easy mode where monsters die in one hit and appear less often so people who want to learn but aren't as interested in the RPG portion can finish the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083835349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1615087298}
review:
Excelente para aprender un poco de Japones.
Llevo un par de horas y consigue su objetivo.

I came to this after watching a full video lesson on hiragana, I made notes from that, and I made notes from this. I'm also using doulingo on my phone as another refresher.

This is good for it's purpose, but if you're serious, don't use this alone. Doulingo is free, youtube is free , put the effort in and you'll get there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992885335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1260, 'last_played': 1553830852}
review:
This game took a lot longer to get through than I had expected, since I was mainly after a refresher. The game plays like an old school JRPG, and knowing this I should have realised it wasn't something I'd beat in a couple of hours. Hiragana Battle is certainly not the most efficient way to learn or revise, but the game does ask you to get a pen and paper out to practise - which I did. The game does a good job of hammering the characters into your head through repetition.

There is one exception to this; the final boss battle. The game goes beyond just learning hiaragana writing and how it is pronounced, and includes some basic vocabulary and phrases too. Those might require a tool like Anki to help you memorise those, as you'll need to know a bunch of vocabulary to beat the game. Having said that, vocabulary is probably easier to learn than new characters for a lot of people.

As you would expect from an RPG, there are optional side quests that result in giving you even more XP (and extra vocabulary not used in the main quest). They didn't go stingy on content.

There are a few things I didn't like about the gameplay itself. The battles play out as follows: You have four characters, and there will be 2, 3 or 4 enemy hiragana attacking. On your turn, you need to decide the moves for all of your characters and execute them all at once. Hiragana warriors (the enemy characters) have health points, and you don't know how much health or precisely how much damage you will inflict per successful attack (where attacks are always successful but only if the correct romaji was chosen). No two hiragana characters on the screen will be shown at the same time. Additionally, you don't know the order your characters and the enemy hiragana will attack in - and sometimes it's a mix. eg. Two of your characters, then all of the enemy characters, and finally your last two characters.

Herein lies my biggest problem with the game; if two of your team members are attacking a hiragana warrior and the first one defeats it, the second one will send his/her attack to some other random character on the screen, which will always fail. since the answer was specific to the one now defeated. You'll get the message on the screen that the character was wrong and you did 0 damage with that attack, despite giving the correct answer. I would rather the unit simply guard, or even rather s/he did absolutely nothing and just stood there, rather than launch an attack which is guaranteed to fail and have the game tell you that you got it wrong.

The menu to select characters is also frustrating at times. The answers are presented in two huge columns that can require quite a bit of scrolling to go through to find the answer. If you have highlighted a column on the left column and press left again (or nudge left more than required on your gamepad), it will wrap to the right making selection accidents easy. However if you are at the top of the list and need to select something near the end, you cannot wrap vertically around by pressing up - you have to slowly scroll down the entire list.

Luckily the game remembers what your character had selected previously, and as you advance, hiragana warriors will more often require an answer from the end of the list. However if you selected something like `n` (a the end of the list) one turn, and then healed an ally the next turn, the turn after that will start you back at the top of the list again.

There are more little quirks of the user interface that I found annoying. For example, running (mapped to the right trigger on my SteamOS controller) only seemed to work if the mouse cursor was not at the edge of the screen - I always had to make sure the mouse cursor was completely visible. Fade-in transitions didn't work correctly and only partially covered the screen (I was running 2560x1440 in full-screen). This might be because I was using SteamOS and Proton (see the discussion forums on how to get that working as unlike the Katakana and Kanji games Proton does not work with this game without a work-around) but it's hard to say as I didn't play it any other way.

On my SteamOS controller, the Back key was mapped to the right menu arrow (normally reserved for in-game menus and the like) and both A and B seemed to be mapped to Enter. The left thumb pad did nothing, so you need to use the left thumbstick. The right thumbpad controlled the mouse cursor, which is completely unnecessary when using the controller anyway (but bumping it can move the mouse to the edge and cause running to fail). It's probably possible that this could all be changed through Steam, although I didn't spend the time to investigate. My point is that this game was not designed with controller support in mind, which is a shame because that's much more convenient when playing such a long turn-based game. Having said that, it can be made to work and that's how I played.

Equipping weapons, armour, etc. on characters was also slightly annoying, as each character can only use one weapon type. Since this is a fixed limitation of the game, upgrading weapons could have been made easier than it is. It doesn't help that there is also another quirk in the Equip menu whereby pressing back after equipping something backs you all the way out to the main menu, instead of just back one step to the equip character selection screen.

There isn't much of a story, and there's not a lot of depth to the characters. That's okay since the focus is on learning Hiragana, but also Japanese culture and lifestyle. It's great to see NPCs talk about different drinks, Japanese weapons, types of manga, explanations of what a traditional inn and hot spring („Åä„Çì„Åõ„Çì) is like, how to call people, etc. A lot of what was explained went well beyond Hiragana and was very interesting to learn.

The game music was actually pretty good (although that music on the main screen feels out of place IMO). The pronunciation audio quality unfortunately seemed very poor, and probably due to this, I had to question at least once or twice if the audio actually matched the text perfectly. There is a reasonable amount of reading in this game, and I only encountered a single typo throughout (and I 100% completed the game and all side quests). The text is often written in a way that aims to be entertaining.

I could go on, but I'll cut to the chase. Do I recommend this game? While it's not the most fun experience, it was enough to hold my interest and I wouldn't have spent so much time studying/revising Japanese if I wasn't playing this, so I'd have to call that a win. If you don't know any Japanese at all, I think this game could be a good starting point. I purchased the game very cheap at the 2018 Christmas sale, so I easily got my money worth. It won't teach you as fast as something like Duolingo, but it's more fun and more interesting. If you see it on sale, pick this up without question. You'll then be in a good position to continue on your studies using apps like LingoDeer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034678933', 'num_games_owned': 1849, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1662290846}
review:
I've enjoyed this game very much, learning Hiragana a bit now, but always hadd issues perfectly remembering all the Hiragana correctly - maybe now I will be able now.

One minus - because of the Hiragana fighting method, I'd prefer to first say which Hiragana warrior is which, and then have my characters fight them: having to pick a syllable for all 4 characters against one enemy is a bit of a stretch.

Also, the syllable answers could be  taking less space, so we don't have to scroll down so much late game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111153146', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1550628998}
review:
There are faster ways to learn Hiragana, and the gameplay is not engaging enough to justify the expense.

I learned Hiragana in around 3 days (via Duolingo), and thought this game would be ideal for cementing it further.
It is too slow - the main issue being the turn-based fights with Hiragana characters. You'd expect once you get their english letter correct they'd disappear. Instead you have to hit multiple times? I don't think that lends itself to learning, just mashing enter repeatedly.

I get that the devs have tried to simulate an RPG experience, but unfortunately it is lacking. They should focus on why people will get this game: to learn Hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085620334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1291, 'last_played': 1548799232}
review:
I've been learning Japanese for a few months now, and I'd learnt most of the hiragana characters, but I wasn't very fast at recognising them (when I read hiragana it was "blocky", there were long pauses between each syllable where I was furiously working out the next one) and there were a few characters I found difficult to differentiate between (e.g. nu, ne, me...). I bought this game as a way to improve my speed of recognition, and therefore reading, with the intention of buying the katagana version of the game if this one was good.

I can honestly say I'm really glad I bought this game. Not only was it, in my opinion, low-priced, it was a really fun little game that delivered its intentions, which is to teach you all the hiragana characters, and more. Not only am I quicker at reading this alphabet, but I have also learnt lots of interesting things about Japanese culture, as well as many useful words and phrases. I have created notes that I can use to study whilst I am learning katagana and kanji.

As someone who was using this as a tool for hiragana revision from a very basic level, I would 100% recommend this game for anybody who is seriously interested in learning Japanese. 

As for someone who is starting to learn the alphabet from scratch, I can't 100% be certain because I wasn't completely new to it, but I'm fairly certain it will be just as beneficial. I enjoyed this game so much, I will be buying the katagana version, and I will be playing this one completely foreign to all the symbols. I have no doubt that I will enjoy it just as much, it might just take a bit longer to complete, which is not a bad thing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088973402', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1592621606}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047707626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1547132444}
review:
DO NOT GET THIS GAME TO LEARN

I picked up this game over a long break visiting family in order to review the kana.  I had just picked up RPG Maker, and like to see what people have done.  With those aims in mind, this game was great.  It's simple RPG filled with silly asides and generic RPG characters.  Battle are simple, slightly tedious, but the game has a leveling mechanic to help.  The game is split into a Lesson>dungeon>lesson format.  Honestly, both the lessons and the dungeons can drag out.    To the makers credit, the lessons do have good stroke order illustrations.  However, each lesson you have to click through, and then there is a quiz. The dungeons play like slandard RPG dungeons, item here, random encounter there.  It's good for what it ise

If you want to learn the language though, this will not do it.  The Kana appear in set groups, and while the groups might be random (say 4-10 groups in an area) the kana within that group never very.  So that if I encountered "Ha, Pi, and Fu" in one encounter, then "Ha and Ho" my next encounter might be either "Ha, Pi and Fu" or "Ha and Ho" but never a random group of kana that is leveled against the party.  Some of the sound, on vocab words not kana, are off.   

Definately not worth the cover price, wait for sale on the bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274530592', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1533150074}
review:
If you are buying this to learn Japanese, don't.
It's freaking boring.
Really
DON'T
BUY
IT.

Ok. I know how hard it is to make a learning-a-language game that goes out of the language cell phone app model, I'll give you that. You tried to make a game that put together RPG fun with Japanese. But it just did not work. It's very repetitive and boring. 
You have to fight with words in turn-based battle style and you have to select the right meaning of each word/syllable to do damage in the enemies (THE WORDS), you have to do that tons and tons of time and it goes on and on and on.
You'll forget all you learned in an hour.
Refound please.

author: {'steamid': '76561198237018508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 840, 'last_played': 1582847997}
review:
I was very skeptical of the effectiveness of this game and expected it to be rather boring but I decided to give it a go any way and buy Hiragana Battle during Christmas sales on Steam. I have to say that I'm positively surprised at how effective this game is. I am personally a visual learner with somewhat of a photographic memory so as far as remembering/ recognising all the hiragana goes - the game has been very effective for me. I generally did not need to repeat levels more than once and don't make mistakes however I still practice writing in an actual notebook. I feel like this step cannot be skipped just by playing this game unfortunately. 

The story is simple and kind of silly but still enjoyable. I actually got into it quite a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107695212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1546759185}
review: I have only played my first night of it and I'm already loving it. It keeps a great pace to learn something new and somehow keeps my tiny attention span locked on. I recommend this for anyone who wants to take their first steps at learning Japanese and never knew where to start. Thank you Sleepy Duck, ill be excited to try out the others in the future!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141212665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1521177308}
review: Really helpful game! I didn't end up finishing it just due to time and using a textbook, but I thought it was pretty thorough overall teaching hiragana symbols. I tend to need to review things over and over so this was was great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089700547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1610319323}
review:
I have mixed opinions on this game. It sets out to do one thing and thats to teach you Hiragana, and it does it well. It presents it in an easy to understand, step-by-step manner that was broken up into evenly spaced sections. as for a game though it's not best. The enemies are terribly overpowered and not because I didn't know the correct character, they hit like a truck and there isn't much you can do to prevent it. the Escape Combat system is broken to the point where I found myself running from battles more then I'd like .And the story is lack-luster at best

Despite this I'd still recommend this series if you're trying to learn the language as it's an amazing study guide that I find myself engaged to and eager to return to

author: {'steamid': '76561198041102932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1546427141}
review:
It's a  very good albeit slow way to learn Hirigana; but with Hirigana being a very simple building block of the language, you'd learn it much faster just by taking a couple of days with a study book and devoting a bit of time to it.

Still a better RPG than Final Fantasy 15, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145135923', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1466867853}
review: Really good game! It helped me memories Hiragana letters and did all that I expected it to do. 10/10 for studying, 5/10 story, 7/10 gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169157549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1547617904}
review:
Want to learn the basics of Hiragana? This will help you very well, especially if you are the type who likes old school JRPGS and or RPG Maker games. As a learning tool, I give it a 10 out of 10 because it gives you exactly the correct information to study. The combat also helps you to keep remembering each symbol. They even add in a few vocabulary words and phrases.      

Ok, now for the other stuff.      

Gameplay is basic. Very basic. It's not bad. It's just not that fascinating either. There's no encouragement for exploration. The towns I've seen so far are small and boring. Clicking on random things don't earn you any interesting dialogue nor random items, except for a rare treasure chest. The battles are simple and turn-based. You can't attack the enemy as you would in a normal JRPG. You have to search the menu for the proper phonetic sound that matches each symbol. The dungeons, at least as far as I've played, are uninteresting. The random battles trigger way too often, but at least you can escape most of them at will.      

The story is incredibly, incredibly bland and even stupid at times, but that's okay. The point of this game isn't to tell you a good story. It's to teach you Hiragana.      

The graphics are basic RPG Maker MV assets that come with the engine. I'm not mad at it. I'm not an artist. I understand completely why they were used. I also happen to think it's pleasing to the eye. However, I do wish they had taken the time to use the engine's ability to use multiple expressions for each character. Having a character have the same bland smile all the time, even when the story's scene isn't happy at all, is just ... well ... lazy. And I own a copy of RPG Maker MV. I've personally taken the time to add multiple expressions to characters. I've even added plugins to make them blink! It's not difficult at all to do. Making them blink requires a free and simple to use plugin. Adding multiple expressions requires no plugins at all. It's a simple process provided by the engine itself.      

The sounds are basic RPG Maker sounds. I have no problem with that. I do wish they were a bit creative sometimes, though, like using a slightly unexpected sound effect for certain actions in the menu, but whatever. It's nothing bad. Oh, there are also recordings of each phonetic sound in the language in each lesson. I don't think they came with the engine.      

If you want a video game that teaches you Hiragana, then here you go. If you want a grand, artistic JRPG with a complex story, stunning original artwork, and clever gameplay and exploration, then you'd be asking for too much. I'd imagine this might be the developer's first RPG Maker game, and hey, it's a solid game for what it's intended to do. Go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118941487', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1545760161}
review:
Just finished this game, after almost exactly 15 hours according to my last savegame. I started this whole endeavour 23 days ago mainly for fun, but by now I've found other resources and it took me a while to actually decide to finish this after the hiragana studying itself had been done :P

Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle goes like this: You get a few lessons, always hiragana characters (one of the three Japanese writing systems) and sometimes vocabulary or grammar bits at the same time, then you get a main mission to do. Depending on where you are you can also get side quests by the people there, such as using the correct greetings towards others. Only towards the very end do you actually get grammar lessons, and they're rather short, but since this is primarily about writing and reading hiragana and not about sentences that is all fine by me. It does make you understand simple sentences, which is quite important.

It definitely helped me get into Japanese easily, as its 5 characters per lesson are a comfortable number while still making you learn something substantial each lesson. I do wish there was more vocabulary and that reading words instead of single hiragana was required more often.
I also liked the way it teaches dakuten and handakuten (the little marks in the top right corner of some characters) directly with their normal counterparts, that makes the task of learning the entire hiragana system a lot less daunting.

All in all, Hiragana Battle was a great experience and is generally quite a nice game. You might want to have an online dictionary open in the background so you can look up unknown vocabulary that appears sometimes, but generally it explains everything you need to know very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105044910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1538346181}
review:
Es entretenido. 

A ver, que es un rpg simple, con una historia simple, pero que te da pronunciaci√≥n y forma de escribir hiragana. No tiene mucho misterio, pero tampoco es el descubrimiento del siglo. 

Como todo, si no lo practicas por tu cuenta/complementas con clases de japon√©s, no es que te vaya a servir de mucho m√°s que de un entretenimiento.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011453696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1586724176}
review: For someone who is actively studying hiragana, this game is a fantastic memory tool. I found the story to be compelling with decent character progression. The ability to level up your characters along with new armor and weapons kept me intrigued. I also found the side quests to be useful and fun. My only critique would be the high frequency of the hiragana "attacks" when a user is in a combat area. Although I understand the idea is to aid in repetition, I found the constant attacks to be a little annoying at times. Otherwise, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking to improve their Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019821651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1612647490}
review: Just finished the game 5 minutes ago! It was absolutley a fantastic way to learn. I did a lot of writing on the side to really learn all the Hiragana. The game gave me great incentive to beat it so I had no choice but to learn all of the Hiragana. I was really impressed by this and I will get Katakana Warriors next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038040945', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1523439494}
review:
considering I didn't finish the game, I learned a good chunk of Hiragana so yeah this game works if you put in the effort. 
I can guarantee that if I were to go back and finish it, I will have learned it all.

so if you want to further your descent into weebhood yeah this is good.

edit: by the way if you do play this game, you probably won't instantly just learn Hiragana by way of just rushing through, you'll need to treat this like a learning experience. so grab some pen and paper and stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988371092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 3326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1545630886}
review: This is a pretty good way to brush up on some hiragana. You still need to have a notepad handy to write on though. So far this is covering all the stuff that my books are, and in a far less sterile way.  I'm not sure why I hesitated to pick this up for so long, but I recommend this as well as the other two games.  When it goes on sale the whole bundle is like $9.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021789545', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1544051641}
review: You need a pen and paper. Practice, Practice, Practice. I have a lot of trouble learning languages. I'm just bad at it, its like my brain ignores all that isn't English and passes it off as a symbol and nothing more. So learning this way is helping and I've learned more in 40 minutes than I have in five years of watching Anime. Grab a pen, grab a notebook and take notes. Study, practice and maybe you'll learn Hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073401688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1662, 'last_played': 1587300030}
review:
GG. I haven't played JRPG games ever before, but I believe this was the most fun I've ever had while learning. In the last chapters there are puzzles. You solve the puzzles by stepping on the green tiles. Yellow ones make you teleport and brown ones aren't active yet.
EDIT: I had previously bought Influent, because I don't get a nerd-boner from low-res graphics. However, romaji always felt like a crutch to me, and I believed I could get much more out of influent, if I could play it with actual japanese text.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056003605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1029, 'last_played': 1588206489}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996276780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1578550761}
review:
Perhaps not the fastest or most efficient way to learn Hiragana but surely one of the most fun ways to do it! Great graphics? No. Deep story? No. But it does not matter. You have a decent story, you get to play an rpg game and learn something while doing it. If you have trouble forcing yourself to study then this method could help you get started and keep going.
Just make sure 1:you actually write stuff down, 2: try your very best to come up with the answer without checking the answer or randomly guessing and 3: repeatedly practise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065425259', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1541629271}
review:
Started Japanese classes a few weeks ago at university and needed something to help me learn hiragana, bought all 3 knowing I will need others in the future and so far the first one has helped so much already! it's fun to play, you can pick it up when  you have a spare half hour or so and it's really helping to remember the stroke order and sounds for the symbols, looking forward to starting words and then sentences.
Would definitely recommend for all beginners.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116808852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1541043195}
review: Pretty good game for learning hiragana and some basic words. The music and artwork is nice, but gameplay can be a bit boring/annoying especially when you encounter mobs every 2-4 seconds. It's nice that it gives you time to actually write out the characters and words, but audio barely works when it comes to learning the vocab. For just learning the characters, it's pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102252359', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1540238239}
review:
Absolutely a great way to jump start yourself in to learning Hiragana. I feel like this let's you get a feel for it and decide if it's a language you want to invest in while making things fun along the way. 

I'll agree there are better ways to learn Hiragana itself, but if interactive is what you need, I'd recommend this game 100%.

Very fun and enjoyable, would recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198258961223', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 1080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1699766119}
review: I just wanted to play a older style jrpg to see if I still could enjoy them. This one was on sale so I gave it a try and if I had to learn Japanese to beat the game, so be it. So, it took about 15 hours to beat the game and it was fairly easy to do. Seemed like the first Final Fantasy with SNES graphics for similarities sake. I can now read Japanese Hiragana fairly well now too, actually nearly perfectly. I still don't know what most of the words mean but I can read them solidly. I am not sure what I can do with these new powers now, perhaps I can order older rpgs from Japan with confidence I would be able to get through them easier now. The rpg part of this game was satisfactory if not a little basic but I suppose that is just the mechanism for teaching. In hindsight, I should have learned everything at school thru this method as it was easy and somewhat fun. It is a well made game for what it is. Valuable to those wanting to learn Japanese, anything under ten dollars is a good deal. You CAN learn Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262862967', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1538935725}
review: This game is great for learning Japanese. You absolutely need a notebook and pen if this is your first time studying Japanese. I already know hiragana and katakana, so this game took me 7 hours to complete it all. If you're just starting out, it'll take you however long it takes to memorize everything.  Make sure to level grind before the final boss. And save often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198859894610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1589291722}
review:
Hiragana Battle is a game where you need to fight hiragana characters to save Japan. This game is the first of three games in a series of games from developer Sleepy Duck, the art style and game play feel reminds me of the old final fantasy games and the turn based play style they used, only not as refined or as deep.

The story is simple, your country is invaded by an outside foreigner and you must fight your way across the land with the aid of your friends and Japanese hiragana teacher who will teach you the language to defeat the enemies. The game is broken up into ten chapters, each chapter featuring a new set of hiragana to learn and as you progress you will need to search your vocabulary inventory to find and use the correct letter to defeat the current enemy. The vocabulary inventory is poorly layed out; this is a problem that is fixed in later games but in this version it can make figuring out where the correct hiragana to use a bit overwhelming.

I bought this game in a bundle with the other two games in the series and paid on average about ¬£5 per game and after playing each game I would say that you can complete each game in about 12 hours if it's your first time and much less than that if you know what your doing.

The biggest problem I have with Hiragana Battle is that there is nothing to do when you complete this game other than start a new game and begin again which is definitely this games biggest mistake, this however is something that was fxed in later games.

The real question you want to know is; Did I learn anything? The answer in short is yes. If you are serious about learning the japanese hiragana alphabet and are willing to put in the time then I highly recommend this game for you, if you looking for a deep combat game in the style of old final fantasy games and don't care about the language learning part then this game will come off as a bit of a gimmic and I'd suggest looking somewhere else.

In short, this game looks good, the game play and story are simple and easy, the price is about right for the time invested and finally but most importantly this game will teach you if you let it. It has it's flaws but it is still a good indie game and if your interested, try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029013723', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1471529230}

author: {'steamid': '76561198326372873', 'num_games_owned': 32, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 691, 'last_played': 1528991742}
review:
Yes. I know you can just "go on memorise" or find some other random place to study the Hiragana. And yes I know some people only take 2-4 hours to remember all the Hiragana. But that's boring as hell and so textbook. Once you've learned Hiragana and Katakana you're going to be spending most of your time with your face inside of a textbook, so why not enjoy the first few weeks of studying Japanese?

It's been almost two years since I first started studying Japanese and I still remember the fun I had when playing through both Hiragana Battle and Katakana War. Not that JPN isn't fun--because I find it a lot more enjoyable than wasting time in competitive gaming--but you're going to have a hard time finding anything else that hasn't been "gamified" that isn't Hiragana or Katakana. 

Anyway, enough about Japanese--lets talk about this game. 

It's not that good to be honest, well compared to Katakana War at least. If this is your first Sleepy Duck game then you won't notice the difference of course. If you've already played Katakana War then this game is going to be pretty disappointing because this game isn't even half as much fun as that game. But, it's a start. And it's still fun. So if you haven't played any "Learn Japanese to Survive!" games, then definitely pick this up. 

To be honest, even though Kanji Combat's characters aren't memorable at all, I still feel like I remember the characters from there better than here. Though it has been over a year since I've played this game so it's understandable but I still remember characters from Katakana War so then again, maybe it's not. 

I mentioned that I still listen to that soundtrack that plays during lessons which I put into a one hour loop and I still use it to this day when I'm studying JPN. I heard this soundtrack in another game but I can't remember which, so I think it's one of those royalty free soundtracks. Either that, or the other game I played stole the soundtrack from this game and used it in theirs. Nonetheless, I've uploaded a one hour edit of that soundtrack onto a site--just ask me if you want it. 

I'm going to end this the same way I ended my Katakana War review. If you're looking for the most useful "Learn Japanese to Survive!" game, get this game. If you're looking for the most fun "LJTS" game, get Katakana War.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000476709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1087, 'last_played': 1567076198}
review: a really nice way to finally memorize Hiraganas!

author: {'steamid': '76561198172112959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1535501206}
review:
The Good:
- Well made instruction for for to read and write the characters
- A large variety of Japanese vocabulary 
- Repittion of the characters through gameplay really helps with memorization

Neither Good nor Bad:
- It's a JRPG (Get it? it's a Japanese RPG!)
- A lot of reading, There is no spoken instructions it is all text except for the Vocabulary and Character Pronunciation
- Took me only about 13 hrs to complete (which can be good or bad)

The Bad:
- The font used when showing the characters is next to impossible to replicate when writing it yourself

My Opinion:
Overall a fun and well made game that effectively acheives the goal of educating the player in how to read and write the Hiragana characters as well as giving the player a decent size of vocabulary.

Recommendation:
If you are interested in learning Japanese I would recommend the Learn Japanese To Survive! series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129188230', 'num_games_owned': 1565, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1536326321}
review: I'm a Japanese major in college and decided to buy all three of the games to help me study. I've been playing this a bunch today since I have a hiragana quiz tomorrow, and it's really helping!! The game itself is really useful and educational while still keeping RPG mechanics. The cast of characters are really nice too!! If you want to begin learning Japanese or are taking courses for it, this game is honestly really good to have!

author: {'steamid': '76561198282202944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1505, 'last_played': 1660410495}
review:
This is a really fun way of putting your lessons of Hiragana to the test.  
One thing I do recomend is not using this game alone. This game is no substetute for a real Sensei ;) 
Tools I'd recomend. A chart of all Hiragana characters and a small drywipe board for writing practice. 
Pracice writing the characters without the game And without looking at your printed chart, then play this game to test how well you've done. 

If you're just looking for a gaming experance, then I'm getting my critic hat on so hold tight. 
The RPG elements in this game I think actually hurt the quality rather than further it. 
Enemies in this game only take damage if you use their uniqe and specific weakness. Their name. 
I'm going to describe a 4 v 4 battle to you, then a 3 v 4 battle. This will get complectated but I think it's imporant to read so you understand what I'm talking about. 

„ÅÇ -(A) „ÅÑ -(I) „ÅÜ-(U) and „Åà-(E) are attacking.  
You tell your team to attack „ÅÇ with A, „ÅÑ with I, „ÅÜ with U, and „Åà with E. 
Your attacks Are correct. Therefore, you Should pass them just like any written exam. 
But the enemies are higher levels. So you run the risk of losing, even though you did nothing wrong. 
We'll say you win this fight, but your team are all 1 hit away from fainting. 

Here's the next battle. 
„ÅÇ „ÅÑ „ÅÜ Are attacking your 4 man team. Again, you tell your team to attack.
Keep in mind that this is a turn based battleing system, so you have to make descisions fisrt, and Then the attacks happen. 
Person 1 and person 2 attack „ÅÇ with A. 
Person 3 attacks „ÅÑ with I. 
And person 4 attacks „ÅÜ with U. 
Right so. 
Person 1's attack kills „ÅÇ in one strike, so person 2 defaults his attack to the next Hiragana in line by attacking „ÅÑ with A. Which is incorrect, so no damage is delt.  
Person 3 attacks „ÅÑ with I, but it turns out „ÅÑ is a bit stronger than the others, so it takes 2 hits to kill it. 
Person 4 attacks „ÅÜ with U and „ÅÜ is defeated too, leaving only „ÅÑ remaining. 
Now it's „ÅÑ's turn to attack. And it does something that hurts your whole team, killing all of them. (Not likly, but possable) 
So this means that even though YOU as a player correctly itentified the Hiragana Characters, you still lose the battle.

The enemies don't show their HP stats, so you have no idea who you can kill in one hit and who you should focus your attack on. 
If this inofmation was visable like in Pokemon games I'd care less about this and move on to my next point.
Unfrtunatly by the nature of this game, every enemy is ammune to all but 1 of your arsenal of attacks. You're basacally shooting a watergun at a tank if one in your party defaults to someone else. 

So in this reviwer's opinion, Every single enemey should die in one shot if hit with the correct answer. 
The point is to learn Hiragana. If your attacks deal any damage at all then you have learned Hiragana enough to know who you're fighting. 
The RPG stuff like levels, money, magic, armor, and weapons should all be removed. 
The lore of the game is you're Saying the sounds, so holding a spear as you say it won't make a diffrince. 
In Pokemon this leveling system isn't an issue because the whole point is to grow and be the best like no one ever was. 

A better system (Keeping all the elements in play) would be to have the player select each enemy and itendify them Before descidiing to attack. Then the player just tells the party who should attack whom, and since you identified the Hiragana at the start, if you're correct the attacks will always hit even if someone swaps targets. 
Right now the comand order is Who attacks, With what, and agaisnt whom. 
Where as it should Attack whom and with what, Then we move onto Who attacks them. 
The attacks are innerchangable if you make a mistake, but if you did right the battle will be over in one round anyway. 

So ff the game makers are by chance reading this, try a syetem where the player's party can take 5 hits each before fainting, and make it so enemies can only hurt you IF you get an answer wrong.
This will make the game less about grinding levels, and more about educating yourself about the launguage, which is the entire reason people buy this game. 
You have potential for spin offs if you havn't alteady. Kanji and Katakana. By then I hope the enthesis is more on learning and not on leveling up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121671652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1264, 'last_played': 1551998962}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive Hiragana Battle is fantastic for those wanting to learn how to read Japanese.

The game itself is very simplistic, as you learn how to write, read, and pronounce 5-10 Hiragana characters per lesson and then you must choose the English equivalent when you go to various areas around the map to fight them. You also learn around 50-75 Japanese vocabulary over the course of the game, as well as some beginner phrases such as how to say your name or introduce yourself. You can revisit lessons at any time as well.

One thing I really like about the game is that you can save at virtually any time, and the fullscreen mode is more like borderless fullscreen. I found it seemless to alt-tab into other applications while playing this game.

I noticed a few comments complaining about certain aspects of the game so I will address them here:

Graphics - A lot of people don't like the basic graphics, but I found them to be quite charming, especially considering the incredibly low price for the game. The graphics don't in any way subtract from the main point and attraction of the game, to learn Hiragana.

Music - You'll find the same music almost everywhere in the game. The same learning theme music for all 20ish lessons, the same battle theme for all fights in the game except the last dungeon, and the same theme when walking around the world map. However, I really liked the music, and I didn't find it repetitive since I didn't try to rush though the game or play it all in one sitting.

Combat - There really isn't much to combat other than choosing the correct English equivalent. Each party member has unique abilities, mostly defensive ones, but these are practically useless since attacking the Hiragana warriors is the best way to avoid damage and end a battle quickly. Once again though, it doesn't take away from the game since you don't really buy the game for the combat; the point is to learn Hiragana.

Grinding - Even if you fight every battle you encounter, you'll probably have to grind a bit. Each lesson you complete introduces harder enemies with more health, damage, and stronger abilities, and even if you know the English equivalent you might find your party members losing 3/4 of their maximum health per hit. Luckily, by completing side quests you can gain bonus points that can give your party instant level ups, which is incredibly useful, and if your party is a high enough level the enemies will deal 0 damage. Grinding a little bit is good thing to help you memorize the characters anyways. Another strategy to avoid grinding as much is simply escaping battles. Unless the enemy gets the upper hand, which is rare, you can instantly escape from any battle without taking any damage. So if you know the set of characters in that area well and want to move on, simply escape from each battle as you progress through the dungeon. When you get to the next dungeon, the characters might hurt since they will be harder and you didn't grind as much, but you will have to grind less now since the newer enemies give much more experience.

All in all this is a truly fantastic game. You can beat this game in around 8-10 hours as many have done, but if you really want to learn the Hiragana characters, the vocabulary, and the beginner phrases well I would recommend keeping a notebook and writing down all the lessons. A more realistic game length would be around 15-20 hours if you do this, as I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140308190', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1240, 'last_played': 1533297238}
review:
If you want to learn japanese, I recommand to buy it on sale, but...
- Choosing answers is painful (because they are sorted in two columns, so you'll end up with more than twenty rows, which is long to go up and down to pick the right answer. It is not much for selecting 1 answer, but you'll have to repeat it a lot which makes it boring very fast)
- Even if you pick right answer for an ennemy, it won't always oneshot him (which should be the case, since the purpose of the game is learning hiragana, not playing a j-rpg, and I would even say that since you'll just select the same answer on next turn it's just boring to hit the enemy multiple times)
- Some of your characters don't attack before enemies (so when exploring a new zone you'll always take damage, and you might have to get back to the inn to recover, which just makes time longer before next lesson without really helping you to learn)

I think Sleepy Duck didn't focus enough on the fact that we're learning japanese. If you want, you can build a game system to wrap the learning, but it mustn't be taking too much importance, and every game design choice must be in the most efficient way for learning Japanese.

However, during lesson sessions, you'll see in depth how to draw Hiraganas, hear pronounciation and you'll learn vocabulary too, so this game is still better than free smartphone apps if you want to learn japanese correctly.
