author: {'steamid': '76561198037366772', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 942, 'last_played': 1531687369}
review:
This game is basically for people who already have some degree of Japanese anime/gaming culture in their lives that want to legitimately learn the language. It does basically what it sets out to do, but the "game" is rather shallow. That's fine, I didn't need some elaborate plot to take me out of the learning experience and make me forget I'm learning. I just wanted it to be more interesting than a basic textbook, and this definitely does that. It's set to feel like a traditional retro JRPG with breaks of textbook studying. The story is kind of cringeworthy at face value, but if you treat it as a metaphorical stand-in for traditional magic shenanigans, you can reasonably appreciate the world it's setting up. As long as you go in accepting that the presentation is kind of a joke in itself, it's fine.

The gameplay doesn't serve any special function but to drill what you've learned into your head for the purpose of memorization. The spells here do not really mean much. It takes up most of my energy to do anything more than the basic healing. By the time I might have afforded to exercise some tactics, I had already earned the most powerful weapons/armor to the point that most attacks literally did 0 damage against me. Granted, this was with me taking all the sidequests along the way and almost never running from an encounter. The "game" part of this could've been fleshed out a lot better, or at least have the magic system ripped entirely.

However, I do feel this is a fine middle ground. Making the "game" more relevant takes emphasis away from memorization. Removing those unnecessary game elements would remove vital parts of the presentation. This game knows it can't really take itself seriously, but it's not Deadpool, either. There's just enough presentation here that someone interested in its kind of culture can feel comfortable without so much immersion you forget you're learning. I did appreciate the various references it makes to "otaku" culture.

For the price, this was a fine introduction to Japanese. As I already had a lot of anime exposure prior to this, I feel like I'm seeing a lot of it in a whole new light, and I'm ready to take the next step forward.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041620786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1354, 'last_played': 1537311278}
review:
TLDR; 
+ Game does its job to teach Hiragana characters of the Japanese language. 
+ Education pacing is good; little fear of information overload
+ Lessons are good in showing you how to pronounce and write the Hiragana characters,
+ Opportunities to learn vocabulary
+ You can review what you have learned
+ Battles allow you to retain your newly gained knowledge; interactive way to memorize the Hiragana
-  Execution is lacking though. Don't expect mind-blowing plot, drama, graphics, battle strategy, etc.
===================================================
Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle is pretty much what you expect from the tin: you learn how to read, write, and pronounce the Hiragana characters in the Japanese language, and you fight battles involving said Hiragana characters.  

The game consists of three parts: overworld (where you travel outside of lessons and battles), lessons, and the battles. 
- 

Overworld: 

Overworld is where you can move your character Claire to places and interact with the NPC characters where you can either just get some general dialogue or receive miniquests.
-

Lessons: 

Lessons are where you learn about the Hiragana characters in the Japanese language in sets (i.e. ka, ki, ku, ke, ko / ra, ri, ru, re, ro / etc.). These lessons teach you on how to read, draw, and pronounce the character. After you finish the lesson (~5 minutes), you are then given a basic quizzed on what you learned and directed to the next plot-relevant location (namely there is bad-guy activity here, go investigate / stop it). 

These lessons do occasionally have vocabulary sessions where you learn 10 words in Hiragana (not necessarily exclusively to the ones you‚Äôve learned up to the point) and in Romanji as well as the English translation. They help to shake things up for variety and for you to learn some words to apply your Hiragana knowledge. You are not quizzed on these‚Ä¶..at least immediately, but more on that later. 

You can access these lessons later if you want to review them. 

The aforementioned miniquests do a similar function, either immediately dispensing the words or after a minor search-and-recover mission taking place at a plot location. These miniquests are unlocked as the plot progresses and offer special equipment (well "special," but not particularly OP) and/or money.  You can review your vocabulary with these quest-givers later on.

Battles: 

Battles are where you are tested on your knowledge in Hiragana by battling these Hiragana Warriors, enemy entities that take the form of a Hiragana character and can only be damaged by choosing the romanji associated with them in the attack menu. These battles happen spontaneously at random in the overworld at a non-safe location (namely anywhere that's not a town hub).  

You have four options in these battles: attack, magic (buff spells, status effect removal, and heals), items (basically spells without a resource bar), and escaping. If you do defeat the enemy, though, you will earn experience points which allows your characters to increase their stats and money to spend on equipment and items. 
----------------------------------
With that said, here is my opinion of the game: 
-
Immersion:
A little bit of humor here and there in the dialogue of NPCs, a nod or two to Japanese culture (i.e. recycling), but there isn't really any world-building or sense of urgency to save your fictional home country and Japan from the big bad. You do not really see any signs of the conflict upon the world.

Lessons:
Lessons are alright. My only complaint is that you are not tested to draw out the Hiragana characters (stroke order, appearance, etc.), but I suppose it is to be expected for a game at this price to not have that kind of interpretation technology on it. 

Plot:
Bad guy wants to conquer (for generic power reason), go and stop him. That‚Äôs it. There is one twist, and it‚Äôs minor, and it‚Äôs basically the same generic bad guy with a different sprite who becomes irrelevant. Other than that, there is hardly any drama, and for the one time there was, you‚Äôll quickly forget as you advance the plot.

Characters:
Not much characterization, save for a few personality quirks in dialogue. There are no individual motivations (aside from beating the bad guy), no bonding, etc. They are just‚Ä¶kinda there as combat meatshields. You have only four to "manage" (including Claire, your character), so you don't have to do any party member juggling.  

Graphics:
Simple, but it does its job as background fluff. 

Music;
Overworld music. It's alright. Battle music.....gets old really fast.

Length:
Roughly about 10 hours. Plot sections are about 30-40 minutes each to complete. A little extra time spent on buying and selling equipment. And the rest on miniquests and overworld travel. 

Pacing:
Plot missions are about 30 minutes each. Not too bad. Roughly 45 minute play sessions if you include gearing up and learning the lessons. Enough to feel you've learned something, but not too much to have information overload.

Battles:
Strategy is not a focus in this game. Gearing is mainly straight upgrades in stats. Min-maxing isn't really an option. Almost no interesting decisions in party composition, items, and equipment due to no offensive spells and crowd-control.

Items are nearly useless due to ineffectiveness of enemy status effects (low duration) and battle length (~2 minutes). Buff spells are hardly worth using due to battle length. Healing spells mostly supercede healing items for the most part and will carry you throughout the mission.

Typical strategy is mostly the same - just gang up on one Hiragana warrior and move on to the next one. Heal if someone's low in health points. Rinse-and-repeat. 

Battles are not responsive. You just kind of just sit back and watch after you assign your attacks until the combat round ends which can be a huge problem. If an enemy dies and you have an attack assigned to them, you cannot change it, causing you to miss. If your characters gets ganged up, you cannot do anything to respond. If you make a mistake, well, better have your IRL notes ready....

Except for the final boss mission, the battle music is always the same. You will get sick of it if you play in a marathon. Breaks are recommended, for your sanity, and to space out your learning to help retain your knowledge. 

Battle spawns can become really annoying though. You can literally move only three square tiles, and boom, a battle begins. This can happen again and again, further excrabated by maze-like level design and backtracking in the level.

...on the plus side, Hiragana warriors are not exclusive to the lesson; you will be reviewed of previous characters, albiet a bias to the current lesson. Encounters are pre-set though; you will see the same pattern of Hiragana characters in a given encounter. 

That being said, the game designers try to add some variety by switching the Hiragana Warriors with Romanji versions of themselves, forcing you to choose the Hiragana characters they represent to deal damage. And much later on, vocabulary words, but that will really take you off-guard as you weren't forced to review them beforehand. 

Battles are fast though; do it right, they should not take more than 2 minutes each, and you should have just enough money to buy some upgrades after you complete your mission. Grinding isn't really required in this game.....at least if you finish the miniquests as well.
--------------------------------------------------
All in all, this game does its job in teaching you the Hiragana characters of the Japanese language. Despite my complaints, it's fun as it is an interactive way to learn the language, and the attempts in variety by adding vocabulary lessons and miniquests is appreciated as well as the Hiragana Warrior swapping. However, its execution is a little....lacking, though I suppose you can argue the focus is in the learning and not the battles or the story itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056386070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1606074988}
review:
So, I played the game for about 33 hours, according to steam, and beat it twice. I can say that I have learned to sound out the 46 symbols of the Hirigana, and recall them for the most part, but the game did little to reinforce the symbols. 

Ex.: after you get done with the first set "A, I, U, E, O" it isn't brought up through the rest of the game till around the ending where they throw EVERYTHING at you. Including words that were brought up once during a training session. Be prepared with your notes! 

The problem with not reinforcing the symbols along the way is at the end you get them mixed up COMPLETELY with other symbols that look alike. For example: Re, Wa, and Ne. The only difference between these three symbols are the tail ends. Tucked in, normal, or flicked out. So, without reinforcement these are a lost blurr.

However, they have fixed this in the second game that is Katakana where they bring up previously shown symbols all the time. Along with the spreadsheet of symbols when going to attack. It's not all muddled together now, and each set has it's own distinct line. So, it is easier to find the symbols you want, unlike in Hirigana Battle. These are the only two things that bothered me with "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" that they fixed in "Learn Japanese To Survivie! Katakana War." There is one other thing that may bother players. It's the Hiragana itself. When fighting them the letters take on the more fluid nature of a brush stroke, and the answers you have to fight back are almost blocky. Ex: Fu which looks like „Åµ on the answers, but the attacking „Åµ looks all conntected. They say as long as you know the brush order you'll be able to make the characters out, but it throws people off who are just learning it. Though, I came to appreciate it, because like in everyones writing- it is all different upon the person.

Otherwise, this was a good game and it did as it said. It showed me how to read Hiragana. Now, as for understanding what I am reading...that's not what it says it does. Though it does teach you a few words, about 60 to 70 words, a handful of introduction phrases, and how to count to 10. It also teaches you about particles and what smaller symbols in a setence of larger symbol means. Usually including the Y's (ya, yu, and yo) and Wa, Ga, O, E, and No.

    Overall, this was an enjoyable game and I'd recommended it to anyone who is just learning the very basics of Japanese writing.

review: This ia a very good game to pick up if you want to jump into learning Japanese. Just bring a notebook, pencil, and a willingness to learn and you'll do good.  „Åå„Çì„Å∞„Å£„Å¶! (Good Luck!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198073363463', 'num_games_owned': 818, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1530829254}
review:
This game is not for everyone. This game feels like school with better break times. If you are not so fond of the way they teach you stuff at school, don't buy this game. I'm OK with how schools teach, I don't get bored easily, but I didn't feel that way with Japanese so I just searched hiragana on youtube and watched the first video showed up. I highly recommend it.

I can't really say this game is the fun way to learn hiragana. The way it shows you the hiragana characters for the first time isn't enjoyable but then it makes you fight with those characters which helps you to shift away from the 'How am I supposed to remember all of these?' part of learning hiragana and focus on just playing a video game.

This game can teach you hiragana if you're ready to practice writing and study (play) on a daily basis. However, it is not perfect. I haven't played much but literally the first dialogue you see is faulty. Ha is pronounced as wa when used as a particle and they don't mention that, also the very first Japanese word you see is „Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„Çè but this 'wa' is a particle so it should have written as „Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ. Lastly, don't pay full price unless you're absolutely sure that this type of learning fits you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080599829', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1530572727}
review:
This is a very solid game for Beginners. It tackles the basic alphabets, and bit of vocabulary, Japanese culture, and grammar as an added bonus. I already knew the basics, but bought it anyways to see if I'll learn something new and still enjoy the game (and I did) Game can be completed in about 9-10 hours (or less) depending on your skills and how long you want to study. 

‚úî Good game for anyone who is debuting, but highly recommended to find various sources to increase your knowledge. It will not teach you [b] every [/b] basic thing you need/should know. Genki Book series, Tae Kim, NHK, Japanese Lesson, and Tofugu are all good sources I recommend checking out.
‚úî Optional guidebooks for the Hiragana Chart and Vocabulary in gameplay in case you forgot and/or want to revision what you learned. 
‚úî Keeps you on your toes for the correct word usage during a battle. You cannot deal damage to the enemy or win battles if you use incorrect terms.
Tip: try not to make guessing a bad habit. flee the battle and revision what you learned and live to fight another time to have the knowledge stick.   

‚úò RPG combat is too tedious. You don't know who's turn is it next unless something pops up like "Your party has the upper hand"  you get to attack first (and will most likely win) VS "Your party was surprised" which means the opposite. (paraphrasing a bit but you'll get a better understanding if/when you get the game) which was a pain in the ass.
‚úò Mixture of Romaji and Hiragana during lesson breakdowns. It makes sense if the game did not teach you a certain alphabet yet along with a vocabulary, but it is a bit silly to show you "„Åàn„Å¥„Å§" instead of "„Åà„Çì„Å¥„Å§" for example. If they did not teach you the alphabet "„Çì" the vocabulary should've been taught in a later time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120474264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1530374452}
review:
The idea is great, the execution is not. - I don't want to hate on this game, this is not what I'm trying to do.
I have not completed the game. I wanted to, I wanted to enjoy it. I wanted it to be that no budget, cute game that wins you over with its charm, but I got too bored and frustrated. I wanted to write a review as I paid for this game and want to encourage children who may not have as much money not to buy it. 
Currently in game about to leave for Japan.
The story is extremely basic, I failed to care about any of the characters or plot. This stopped me enjoying the game enough to force myself through the grind.
The RPG gameplay was useless from a game design perspective. It didn't matter what class the character was, what equiptment they were using or what spells they learned. After a while the most effective strategy is to just use two attacks on one enemy so a party of 4 can beat two hiragana a turn. Spells do make it easier to win but you waste a turn setting up and it doesn't matter you can't really loose. I didn't die once.
The level design artificially extends game time by making most levels if not all into mazes. It's not fun it's frustrating as they are not hard to navigate but when you try get all the items littered around a maze the amount of encounters is too much. I eventually gave up and started fleeing all battles to see if the game gets any more fun.
"Side quests" taught you new words but had no way to solidify them in your mind. Just had them read to you and that's it. They could have been fleshed out and had you doing tasks relating to the words.

I wanted to like this game, the idea was such a good one and there was potential for it to be great.
If they couldn't come up with a good story the gameplay could still have been easily improved.
Dakuten could have been stronger versions of the Hiragana.
As you learn new words they could have been replaced in dialog to help learning the new words.
I found myself craving flavour text as this game is so empty. Clicking on a box that simply says "this box is empty" and replacing some text with learned words could have gone a long way to give the player a feeling of achievement when they start to read and understand things.
I believe the encounters should have been scrapped for fixed position fighting, like trainer battles in pokemon. This way they could be tailored to in game characters. The trainers could have used certain groups of characters that made words without you knowing so you become more familir with Japanese. Have us fight the word Katana as a final battle before getting it as loot. Or some NPC chef could battle you with su and shi then some other food.
My issue is you just go about like a zombie battling Hiragana hoping repetition will ingrain them in your memory. Maybe it will but doesn't make the game fun. 
I wanted to feel like learning the language was as much an adventure as an RPG is. Slowly learning the language at a slow and effective pace preferably in line with a good story. What I felt i got was a lot crambed in in a short space of time. There are so many simple words made of the Hiragana that the game could have been longer and more in depth and still been more enjoyable than the current state.

Not to be hateful to the devs as I'm grateful someone is attempting things like this. I'd rather this be taken as constructive critism. I think we'd have been better off if this game was more like an existing game, like a rip off of Pokemon as there'd have been less pressure to do good game design and just find places where you can gimmick Japanese into it. Like I said with the trainer battles or having the HiraganDex(Pokedex) for hiragana you encounter as yu search for them all ors some dumb thing like that. It's cheesy but at least you remember cheese as it adds an emotion to the learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028928472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1530155662}
review: The Japanese in this game is a little off. Konnichiwa is not written Konnichiwa, it is written Konnichiha in Hiragana. This is the most basic of beginner pitfalls and the fact that the very first sentence of Japanese shows such a basic error doesn't leave me hopeful for the rest of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142136131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1529708171}
review:
If you can buy the game on sale, you might as well see if it works for you. For me, the lessons and gameplay were so incredibly tedious and stiff that I turned the game off and resolved to learn hiragana on my own (which I did! ^_^ http://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn-hiragana/). If buying this boring game for a couple bucks ultimately inspires you to get serious about learning hiragana, then why not? 

It would, I think, do well with kids at school with free time in a computer lab.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320923356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1528176349}
review: This game is fun. I played through the whole thing and took my time. It teaches hiragana, in small, digestable doses (lessons), to players. After finishing a lesson, players can immediately use new hiragana characters to attack enemies and continue the storyline. By the time I finished the game, I knew every hiragana character which makes studying much smoother.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045401832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 191, 'playtime_forever': 1800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1569170729}
review:
The Good
-Learn the Hiragana characters and basic vocab in a fun way. Includes how to write and pronounce.
-Revise lessons.
-Grinding is better than flash cards.
-Very creative and innovative way to learn.

So So
-The calligraphy is too hard to duplicate when writing.
-No mnemonic devices to help you remember.
-JRPG, so yeah, you actually have to level up and buy equipment and follow the story.

I recommend this game, but also use https://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn-hiragana/, http://www.csus.edu/indiv/s/sheaa/projects/genki/hiragana-timer.html, and https://realkana.com/hiragana/ alongside it for every new character column.

Be sure to play and practice every day until you have all the characters memorized 100% without looking. It's the only way to remember.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313456430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1587599669}

author: {'steamid': '76561198066421524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1526622231}
review:
I'm an intermediate Japanese student now, bought this when I was just beginning but shelved it because I went and learned Hiragana using a book. For kicks, thought I'd revisit this game.

It's quite excellent, through and through. I enjoyed it even though it would have been nice to skip or fast-forward the tutorial on the actual Hiragana characters, especially if you already know how to write them and what they mean.

Music in this game was top notch, and I liked the retro gameplay and graphics.

I really enjoyed the vocabulary battles late-game and the final boss was a fun fight. I already know Katakana but I'm looking forward to playing Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War!

author: {'steamid': '76561198126197481', 'num_games_owned': 675, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1610625777}
review:
There are better ways to learn Japanese, this isnt one of them, though it is fun!

review:
je recommande mais vais essayer d'√™tre objectif dans mes explications :
J'ignore pourquoi, mais le nombre d'heure jou√© n'est pas correct, j'ai avec mon steam sur 2 pc diff√©rent (2 sauvegarde diff√©rent) et ca a pris la sauvegarde la moins avanc√©. J'ai en r√©alit√© +- 10/15h de jeu.

Je n'ai jamais pratiqu√© le japonais avant de jouer √† ce jeu.

1) Les "ennemis" (des hiraganas) sont en √©criture un peu artistique, du moins pas exactement comme l'√©criture qu'on verrait sur un ordinateur ou dans un journal. Du coup quand on pratique un peu sur le c√¥t√©, c'est l√©gerement perturbant. 

2) Dans les donjons, on rencontre trop souvent les m√™me groupe d'ennemi. Il y'a trop peu de vari√©t√© de groupe d'ennemi par donjon. Plusieurs fois de suite vous vous ferez attaquer par le "ro" "ru" "re" et √ßa lassera un peu votre apprentissage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121161049', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1515941776}
review:
[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Do's what it promises to: Teaching you the whole japanese Hiragana alphabet!!
+ makes the blunt memorizing of the different symbols much more enjoyable and entertaining
+ teaches you a good handful of useful vocabulary
+ cool & refreshing gameplay twists at the later half of the game
+ includes basic RPG systems and content, like an overworld, dungeons, npcs, shops & sidequests
+ low price for some fun >10 hours of learning through playing

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
~ just scratches a tiny bit on the topic of grammar or word order in a sentence
~ okay, though generic story, but it wraps the learning process up
~ flat characters with low character progression, but I didn't expected it anyways..

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- technical implementation could be better (but as a budget learning-game, the RPG-maker framework has to do the job I guess..):
besides the low resolution, missing quit button in main menu (like wtf?) the menu and player are really clunky to navigate/move around
- reaaaally repetitive fighting music. Had to mute it halfway through the game..
- fighting concept is very simple and repetitive (through the nature of learning vocabulary, there are not many options arguably, though I think a bit more would be possible)
- the RPG and game aspects pretty weak: difficulty curve is unbalanced, dungeon-design really dull, random enemy encounter rates are frustratingly high
- enemies in an group build-up consist always of the same 3 to 5 enemy types, more "free" randomness would have been apreciated

[h1]All in all[/h1] a really enjoyable learning experience, as well as entertaining as a "game" if you don't let yourself get annoyed by the fighting repetitiveness and lack of a deeper narrative. Just keep in mind it's more of a learning software than an actual game and you will have fun with it!
„ÅÇ„Çä„Åå„Å®„ÅÜ„Åî„Åñ„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô for such an awesome game, SleepyDuck!

author: {'steamid': '76561198087805916', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1518675569}
review: This is a really good way to start learning Japanese! It's a decently well-made game and enjoyed my time playing it! Some of the systems are a little bit annoying (constant random encounters, not seeing their health bar), but all of these were fixed in the sequel. But this is still a great place to start!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000016600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1623437504}
review: Nice and useful game for learning hiragana. As a RPG game, it's quite simplistic and has some issues such as user inferface being a bit cumbersome to use. Also the story and other gameplay elements are pretty superficial. Still, it beats using flashcards and other memorization aids by wide margin, which is the main idea I think. For short periods at a time, it can actually be quite fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198337214950', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1524147907}
review: Great game to learn the basics of the Japanese language (namely, 1 of the 3 alphabet - Hiragana, Japanese words and some grammatical structures.) Everything is very simple, clear and visual. Suitable even for beginners, never before is not studying languages. JRPG part is also made at the highest level, liked the fighting with hieroglyphs. The plot is simple, but it is always interesting to know what will happen next. In General, I recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198273899625', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1585170713}
review: This game is a really good start to learn the japanese language. It also soent cost 100's of dallors to learn. I'f you are planning on learning Japaneese, and (or) how to read it, start with this. This is the easiest to learn and the first thing they teach how to read at schools. there are three sets Japaneese charectors in the Japanese language, Hirigana, Katakana, and Kanji. This set is the easiest to learn with only 46 charectors. you dont need to learn katakana just yet because that is how they spell non japanese words, not important yet. kanji is and advanced form of hirigana, which holds 2,136 of common kanji that they teach in the japaneese schools.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093777063', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1298, 'last_played': 1559154974}
review:
Now that I have completed the game 100%, I decided to write a review about it, expressing my thoughts.

Short version:
I highly recommend this game for anyone who wants to learn Hiragana and doesn't mind the turn-based and rpg aspect of the game. You don't need to have any previous Japanese knowledge in order to play and enjoy the game.
---
Teaching: Outstanding 6/6 - The game did its job, I can name or write every Hiragana without much thinking (1-3 sek).
*** Every other category below didn't really matter to me but I will give my oppinion if people do want my oppinion. ***
---
Story: Good 4/6 - The story was prety basic and somewhat predictable, (for an educational game, it was good, as it progressed the practicing of Hiragana).
---
Graphics: Very Good 5/6 - The character images were an outstanding 6/6 for me, really well made, the character sprites and the overworld were a good 4/6, pretty standard for an RPGMaker type of game.
---
Music: Very Good 5/6 - The overworld/town/area music was different so it never got stale, I enjoyed listening to it, the combat music was also good, I really liked the victory theme (after the jingle I usually continued, never letting it play, because I assumed it will be a loop).
---
Gameplay: Good 4/6 - The combat was pretty standart, the only skills your party has are support/buff skills, only the enemy had debuff and special attack skills.
---
Overall:
As an educational game: 6/6
As a turn-based RPG: 4.5/6


Long version:
This review will consist of 2 parts, a long part looking at the game as an educational game, and a short part looking at the game as a turn-based RPG. 
***I won't go much into the story to avoid spoilers, though some minor spoilers might occur.***

As an educational game, the goal of "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" is to teach you Hiragana. In the end, you will know how to read, write and pronounce every Hiragana. As the game suggests, do have a notebook and a pen ready so you can take notes and practice.
- Lessons:
At the start of each lesson, the game shows you (with minor exceptions) 5 Hiragana characters and tells you one by one,  how to pronounce, read and correctly write each of them. In those lessons, you can take your time to repeat the pronunciation and practice how to write each character in your notebook. Some characters were easy to write and I needed only 1-2 tries to copy the animation, some characters were more difficult and took me up to 6 tries. Now practicing to "perfectly" write every Hiragana was just for my satisfaction and is in no way required to progress through the game. In the end of each lesson, there is a small quiz showing you the Hiragana and you need to choose the coresponding sound in English and then vice versa.
Some lessons also include useful vocabulary of comonly used words. You can see the word written in Romaji (with English letters), then written in Hiragana (only the characters you've already learned, the others were in English syllables) and finally the translation what the word means.
At the end, there are also lessons of some sentences like introducing yourself, how to thank people etc.
- Revising
After passing the small quiz, it's time to start revising/practicing the Hiragana characters you just learned. This is done by going into different places (following the main story quest) which are overrun by Hiragana. When you meet them, you have to choose the right English sound to match it with, if you chose correctly, you'll do damage to the Hiragana, if you choose the incorrect sillable, you do no damage. Later in the game, you'll also see the English syllables and you need to choose the correct Hiragana to match them with. [spoiler]At the very end, words formed of Hiragana will attack you and you have to choose the correct word. The final boss battle also had an unique battle style for the game.[/spoiler]
At later stages, you might not only find the Hiragana you just learned from the lesson, but also find some older Hiragana, that way you can practice newly learned Hiragana and revise the ones from previous lessons.
A minor complaint I had with the battles was, that the different Hiragana characters were put into "sets" and before every battle, a set was randomly chosen by the game. On occasions this led to having to fight the same set of Hiragana 4 times in a row where all the Hiragana were positioned the exact same way.
- Extra Learning
The game offers additional learning content in form of side quests. I highly recommend doing them, as it teaches you aditional words and phrases after completing the sidequest. Those quests reward you also with Bonus Points, you can exchange 10 of them for a free instant level up for the whole party (completely optional). If you are purely playing for the educational part, I would suggest using them, as you will be overleveled, meaning you will be outspeeding the Hiragana and defeating them in one hit. "But won't this make the game too easy?" - I hear you ask? Well, not really, because if you choose the wrong syllable, no matter how overleveled you are, you will do 0 damage for getting it wrong, the only other point is the Hiragana will be unable to defeat you because of your high defence and life points. For me it was just "Ok, I got the right sound, enemy should be defeated so I can move on" or "Oh, I got the wrong one, let me try again".
- Conclusion
I am really satisfied as how the game teaches Hiragana, I am totally recomending it, the developers did an outstanding job! I already got me "Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War" and will get me "Learn Japanese To Survive! Kanji Combat" when  it releases.

===

I won't review "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" as a turn-based RPG that deeply, as I am not the biggest fan of the genre, but I don't really mind playing them either. You'll have (soon after the beginning) a party of 4 people. The plot is pretty straightforward, a bad guy wants to take over Japan and you need to stop him.
- Know your Enemy
Before going out to fight your enemy, you get some lore about their only weakness, namely you understanding their name (a la Rumpelstiltskin). If you get the name of the enemy correct, they take damage, if not, you can't harm them at all. 
- Get stronger
By defeating the enemy, you get experience and money. By leveling up, your characters are getting different special skills, although, the only skills your party gets are support and buff skills. The enemy on the other hand gets debuff and special attack skills.
- Side quests and gear
By doing the optional side quests, you get some money or items and Bonus Points, by collecting 10 BP, you can trade them in for an instant level up for the whole party. It really depends if you want to have a challenge or to be overpowered, so only use them if you want. The local shops also offer a variety of equipment and items to help you on your quest.

The only minor complaint I had was when viewing your character stats, when viewing one, you couldn't switch to the other char by simply pressing left or right, you had to go back to the stat menu and manually choose the other character (funny enough, in the "buy" screen in shop, pressing left or right did go to the other characters). Another minor complaint was the order of the 4 characters, one of them is so slow, the order was always 1, 2, 4, 3 (you do get some speed modifying gear later on though).

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
All in all, I played the game for its educational part, I am really satisfied, the price is right, I will most definitely play the other 2 games of the same developer involving Katakana and soon Kanji.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

author: {'steamid': '76561198068976995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1055, 'last_played': 1526940120}
review:
This game makes the classic gimmick of "play and learn" that most kids hated when it was forced on them for school, and it's definetely focused on just making you learn japanese symbols, and it's only sprinkled with JRPG's details to be presented in such a format that atracts a diferent demographic... yet... it managed to capture this certain charisma and grace on it's ridiculous plot to a point that it's enjoyable, funny, and even interesting (if you learn to take it less seriously at least).

The game presents itself with the plot of a traditional turn based JRPG, as a, per say, a 2D Final Fantasy, with a main character living in a forgotten town where some day a villain arrives trying to conquer them, and our character is the unsuspected hero that's up for beating badies, until they find out that the enemies are.... japanese symbols inmune to all damage unless you know their meaning!... the usual, right?... and so the game stablishes a mechanic that forces you to learn if you want to advance, and has all quests revolving around this, adding a new set of symbols slowly so you don't get overwhelmed, and some grammar details and sugestions that help you understanding.

The artistic concept is rather simple and not very impressive, but provides with a distinctive apearance for each character you play, areas, npcs and everything else in a good measure. As for the plot story, it isn't very original or creative, but does just enough to work with a character that fights written symbols for a living.

At the end this game delievers what it promises, it will teach you basic japanese, and if you go with the flow and don 't cheat your way through, you'll be obligated to learn the full set of Hiragana characters, the numbers, some basic phrases and nouns if you want to be able to beat it. [b]IT'S VERY BASIC[/b] so if you have already learned this, this game has not much else to offer.
Do I recommend this game?  „ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÄÄ I'd give it a„ÄÄ „Å™„Å™ „ÄÄout of„ÄÄ„Åò„ÇÖ„ÅÜ

author: {'steamid': '76561198088368277', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1484097561}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063609706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1614898329}
review:
I use this in conjunction with Rosetta Stone and a couple phone learning apps.

Starting with this game really helped me jump into the learning with Hiragana visualized in my mind instead of our plain old letters.

It is plain old rote learning with a few fun cultural tidbits tossed in to spice it up here and there.

Leveling your party and keeping them geared make things move faster so you can one shot enemies instead of ga gu gaing them to death slowly (by slow I mean two hits but it really does get tiring seeing that same damn letter you know and needing extra hits to vanquish it)

Speaking of seeing the same letters the fights aren‚Äôt randomized enough. The enemies seem to come in pre made sets. So sometime you might want to get practice on „Åô but „Åï„Åó„Åù show up 6 times in a row. So by the time the stage is over you can‚Äôt remember SU and you have a hate for SA SHI SO.

That is really my only complaint. The second game added in more voice to help you learn the correct pronunciation and I wish this one would be updated to that caliber but it is still a nice learning tool.

Get both games and to learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005562528', 'num_games_owned': 653, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1520149748}
review: What a brilliant idea for learning an amazing language such as Japanese!  This game is a lot of fun and teaches you one of the three alphabets of the Japanese language, Hiragana!  Do you like traditional turned based JRPGs?  Would you like to start learning how to recognize letters from the Hiragana alphabet, learn some Japanese words, and learn how to write the hiragana language, all while playing that same turn based JRPG?  If so then this game is for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968082807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2814, 'last_played': 1545705016}
review: Intertaining way to learn hiragana.  Very enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100151313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1558042767}
review: Definitely worth the time and money if your trying to learn Japanese.  If your expecting an epic RPG you will be disappointed, but for what it is as a tool to learn the language it was very good.  The lessons were clear and concise with several optional paths to learn more vocabulary and the repetition of the RPG style battles really helped to learn and memorize some of the characters.  The whole thing took me about 12 hours to play through and I was able to read and grasp a lot more than I expected by the end of it.  In fact I would love a continuation of it to learn more vocabulary.  The one knock on it that I have is that it ended just when you were starting to get the hang of it instead of trying to push you a little bit further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163107074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1288, 'last_played': 1519686274}
review:
It works! And it's pretty cute. I learned to read and write Hiragana in a month. (Of course practice is mandatory)
The second one looks even better!

author: {'steamid': '76561198078333110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1519490074}
review:
The idea is a good one, to mix gaming with learning, but the battles become tedious, and the RPG element is really limited, although well executed. After about 6 hours, I was only about 20% of the way through the characters, whereas when I tried another much simpler app on my phone, I was memorizing and drawing Hiragana with a stylus at the same time.

I really hope the developers keep at it, but I can't recommend this game. Buy another RPG, and download a touch-screen app for learning, or just use good old fashioned flash cards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198347380343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1519493130}
review: It's a great way to learn and practice hiragana and some vocabulary, and it's a fun rpg too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198400796095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1523849736}
review:
This educational game is enjoyable. But the lessons can be intense and overwhelming. But that's just how the japanese language is. 

Hiragana is the most basic levels of their language. It doesn't prepare you for everything, but it's a great place to start. Then follow it up with Kanji. The Japanese educational system states that in order to be literate in Japanese (or Nihon Go), you need to know at least two-thousand characters. Kanji was formed using Chinese characters to reduce the need for large banners and signs in Japan. During each lesson, you have some practice to do first. I highly recommend not skimping on the practice if you're serious about learning Japanese. And daily review is critical. As the saying goes, "if you don't use it, you lose it." 

Just think back to something you used to do well but haven't done in a while (years). You'll find your skills to be rusty at best. Even if you just look at the characters once a day and say the sounds & words out loud, you'll keep it fresh in your mind, at least enough to pick it up when you get involved with Japanese again.

I would most certainly recommend the game. Practice makes perfect and it can help a lot. And not just learning Japanese.

As of this post, the same game but with Kanji, the main written language in Japan, has yet to be released, but when it does, get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198321410889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3414, 'last_played': 1526544756}
review: I got this game to help me learn Japanese.  I have also taken a course in Japanese, very basic instruction.  This game helped me with memorizing and writing the Hiragana characters and I will replay it for a review, before I go on to Katakana Battle, which I just purchased today.  I would recommend this for any beginner wanting a fun way to become familiar with Hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085019852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1498210949}

I will be forever greatful to the developers of Hiragana Battle for that. Now I can confidently say that I know all hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091092927', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1517115838}
review:
===[ Is a Sequel Coming?]=== 
‚òê No
‚òëÔ∏èYes, Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War is the sequel, you should learn katakana after hiragana.

===[ Audience ]=== 
‚òê Kids
‚òëÔ∏èEveryone
‚òê Teen

author: {'steamid': '76561198108634563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 908, 'last_played': 1697338822}
review:
Alright, so this game is actually really fun, well if you are really dedicated to learning Japanese. The game is what you make it. I am writing notes like crazy and learning so much! Now I have read some comments saying how there is to much rpg and it takes away from the lessons or what you are learning. I highly disagree.... one of the best ways to drill something into your head is getting distracted and looking it up again with your notes. This game has made me forget so many times, so I keep rereading my notes. You study and then you go on with your life and forget stuff, that is what this game does, makes you forget so you can learn it again, it stays better that way. 

Every battle I get into, if I have to look at my notes for a character I do lines of that character and its meaning. If you are serious about learning Japanese and are at a beginner level as I am, I can not recommend this game enough!!! 

Arigatou gozaimasu developers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049945843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1521690245}
review: A fun, helpful way to learn hiragana. It beat duolingo, which helped me work on my French.

author: {'steamid': '76561198405866402', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1518038131}
review: The characters are anime-like and cute but the most important thing about this game is that it really helps you learn Hiragana. Even though I started playing it knowing all the characters, it helped me revise them in a pretty good way. I also learned some new japanese words. The story is interesting too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116602699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 932, 'last_played': 1517855083}
review: That cliffhanger doe lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198170418237', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1503741062}
review:
Bought the game, Polytechnic started and I signed up for a Japanese module, memorised Hiragana and Katakana within 2 weeks, never played the game.

I'm assuming a 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198394019730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1569781196}
review: Whilst it does not have a great story or a very interactive battle system, the game in itself does help you learn the Hiragana characters. I really enjoyed playing the game, although I must say that it can get very boring for some people. Also, the game does not teach you the contracted sounds for Hiragana, so look that up yourself if you end up playing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281043961', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1975, 'last_played': 1569781130}
review: Literally the only thing that helped me learn Japanese, i remember not knowing where to start so i bought this game on a whim and honestly... im impressed. Im not fluent yet but this definitely got me started on the right track. Books and apps are boring and arnt interactive. This game helps you get involved and drills the japanese youre trying to learn into your head untill you cant help but remember them. Right afer completing this game i went to test my hiragana memory and got everything correct, im super confident in my hiragana and i definitely could not have done it without this game, Thank you devs as well as those that crowdfunded the sequal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201157027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1532861791}
review:
Just finished clearing this game. It was awesome! Really enjoyed it. Alright agreed that the gameplay of this RPG is very basic but the quality of the teaching is top notch. I tried Duolingo to learn Japanese but they don't explain much whereas Hiragana Battle's strength lies in its simplicity to teach Japanese with sound easy to understand explanations. It really is a great basic course to Japanese. This is the first edutainment game that I played and I admit it was fun to learn and play an RPG at the same time. I myself have to started to learn RPG Maker because of this as well.

Thumbs Up!!!! Looking Forward to play Katakana War soon InshaaAllah.

review:

review: jogo muito bom pra quem quer aprender hiragana, a logica do jogo te obriga a memorizar os simbolos e seu som, ou pelo menos a manter seu caderno do lado quando for jogar, caso contrario nao sera possivel derotar os guerreiros hiragana facilmente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012127280', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1517034880}
review: This is a great Japanese learning tool for those who enjoy JRPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062197146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1609729699}
review: Really fun. I am a huge fan of old school Japanese RPG's as l grew up on them with the SNES. The music is great as well. I was surprised the high production values for a learning game. My Japanese is rusty but it is good starting point. My kids are into this as well. Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118937188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1515540215}
review: I really enjoyed this game. It made hiragana easy to learn and i thank you for making this, and i hope the Kanji version comes out soon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198103563191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1525981643}
review: It's amazing! You not only learn but you also have fun. The music and battle system keeps things interesting. It feels like a pokemon battle and when travelling its like FFVII so its very nostalgic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201096703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1298, 'last_played': 1515358530}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045740708', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1515106517}
review:
Its a lot more faster to just learn by yourself than it use playing this game. It takes too much of your time and there is more RPG than here is actual learning really. For example:

Why do I need gear to fight characters?
Why do these characters not die instantly when I get a correct answer?

Another thing that I dont like is that there doesn't seem to be a choice for option to have words in the game set to whatever  preference of kanji or romaji. So I am stuck looking at words in romaji when I would much prefer trying to learn with Hiragana. Maybe the game is not meant for people like me, but there are surely flaws to the game that can be question as to ask "how did they think this was a good mechanic to a game." So in conclusion, if you want to learn quickly without any distractions to interfere with your learning, well this game is not for you, I would advise just learning some basic way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198430471028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1539801902}

Eu acho at√© bom, pois no texto aparece a fonte tipo de m√°quina no exemplo de como escrever que amostra a ordem dos tra√ßos de cada letra aparece a fonte tipo escrita √† m√£o.

author: {'steamid': '76561198350925000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1520706362}

author: {'steamid': '76561198307780137', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1510343273}
review:
Ich m√∂chte nun auch mal mein Review abgeben:

Ich lerne aktiv die Japanische Sprache und kann daher, meines erachtens nach, relativ gut einsch√§tzen wie gut dieses "Spiel" ist.

Wer keinen Plan von der Sprache hat jedoch interessiert w√§re diese zu lernen, kann hiermit schonmal nichts falsch machen.
Hier lernen wir die Japanische "Hiragana" Silbenschrift und einige Vokabeln welche hilfreich einen einfacheren Start in die Sprache gew√§hren und das auf Spielerisch einfache weise. F√ºr jemanden der gerade erst anf√§ngt sicherlich verlockend und gut, ein Fazit welches 'ich pers√∂nlich' jedoch geschlossen habe ist, das es mit B√ºchern und einer entschlossenen Einstellung weitaus schneller funktioniert.

Sch√∂nes Konzept und gut gemacht! Aber f√ºr mich dann doch etwas zu langsam und zu oberfl√§chlich.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025327708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1514851021}
review: Very helpful Japanese learning guide for beginners!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058961285', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1513941892}
review:
If you're wondering if this game manages to teach you something the answer is yes. At the end you will know all the Hiragana characters plus several words and expressions. I recommend it to anyone who wants to start learning the basics but especially to anyone who needs an input, some sort of push to start studying because it really worked for me. Don't expect too much because a game will not teach you a language and be ready to take notes.

In my opinion, the gameplay is just a nice touch accompanying the lessons but it does have positive aspects. In general it's an average JRPG, but when you think you've seen about all the gameplay this game has to offer, it changes intruducing a new mechanic. There are several sidequests, that I suggest to play, that will teach you more expressions and words and if you complete them all you also get a discount code to use on the devs' website!

So if you're interested in Japanese and you want a way to learn the basics while having fun, give this game a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058143723', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1554175810}
review: Fan of pokemon and the japanese language? Then you'll love this game. It's got a strong pokemon gameplay vibe to it, and surprisingly amazingly fast tutoring of hiragana. I knew 15 of the 46 characters within about 15 to 30 mins of game play. A whole lot more than I learnt in my compulsary indonesian class :') Which reminds me! The addition to gameplay helps me retain the information much more than a lame traditional text book! Highly recommend this game to those wanting to learn japanese and love games; particularly the pokemon games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198198517386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1617425525}
review:
I studied Japanese in my free time back in college and have been looking for an affordable way to study the language on a serious level. The format used in this 'game' to teach users the Japanese language really helps the information stick. I have only played this game for a few hours, and I can now fight most of the Hiragana Warriors with no problem. I don't think I'll ever remove this from my Steam Library. If you're into learning new languages and have a knack for remembering, buy this. Get it on a discount if you can, but it's definitely worth the full price.

10/10
Would pay full price if I ever deleted it from my Library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155097545', 'num_games_owned': 1114, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1524661232}
review:
I never gave a wrong answer during a battle, because I already know most Hiragana from my Japanese classes.
Still the enemies kill you if you dont use the easy areas to level up (and buy armor and weapons), which kinda is a chore if you already know the easy Hiragana by heart anyway.
So: NOT YOUR KNOWLEDGE, BUT YOUR LEVEL MATTERS DURING FIGHTS.

The game is probably more rewarding for people who start learning Japanese from the scratch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219449433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1631, 'last_played': 1514352698}
review: Good game to learn Hiragana. I already knew Hiragana and Katakana before I played this game, and I still learned a lot more about the characters and the culture. Very simple RPG. And a very good learning tool if you have either just started, or need some additional support with Hiragana. Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301896992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1537191007}
review: This is game built for people who don't have the motivation or are to lazy to learn stuff on their own. Its set in way that it slowly introduces the basics of the Hiragana writings along with some vocabulary to help improve your knowledge in Japanese. The RPG aspect of the game is fairly okay just that there is alot of backtracking in the game which makes it very annoying / frustrating for me and the menu to choose the correct Romanji to use is very 'messy' for me as i have trouble moving around to find the correct one. Other then that the game is not too bad i would say. Just do some practise on your  own to help better remember some concepts too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074350441', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1635251584}
review: It is great if you want to have a gamified introduction to the Japanese writing system!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076552618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1541648313}
review: I wanted to learn Japanese. This is helping, and it's fun. Seriously though, I really feel this has helped me learn the characters better and easier than other programs I've tried. The gameplay may be a little repetitive if you need to grind, but it's helping me memorize, so I don't mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975018756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1630872866}
review:
Really cheap and really good game, easily one of the best RPG I've played. Not because it has some amazing graphics or gameplay, heck, it can be a bit slow... not fast paced at all. The difference is that unlike the vast majority of games... this game is actually useful!!!! You're doing something productive with your time! Granted it's japanese, which is not a very useful language... but hey, if you can put on your CV that you can speak japanese, it will always make you stand out and look a little bit better (unless you go to china or something, because they hate the japanese). 

This game makes it easy to learn japanese and it's a fun RPG... leveling up, exploring, fighting enemies... simple to play, easy to pick up, I wish all games were like this.

WE NEED MORE PRODUCTIVE GAMES. Games that teach us USEFUL THINGS!!! I can't stress this enough. How many times have we had our parents tell us about how we waste our time on these addictive, unproductive games?

That's how I try to learn italian... same way I learned english. Through games! Make learning a fun process, not a boring annoying one like it feels like at school! This is the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062496904', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1513979541}
review: New to the game, but from what I have played so far I have actually learned a bit. Wish they could make one of these for spanish and russian as well.

good story
now i can speak little japannese and can write hiragana!

review: The game itself is pretty easy, but it's good as a learning tool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045173388', 'num_games_owned': 52, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1519494752}
review: Learning Japanese is too hard for you ? Trying this game !

author: {'steamid': '76561198077618439', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1560710507}
review:
[h1]La propuesta del juego es interesante, y deber√≠amos ver m√°s juegos que intenten ser herramienta did√°ctica, pero considero que [u]es una compra que no facilita aprender japon√©s realmente, aunque es muy buena forma de motivarte para empezar con el estudio del idioma, o herramienta de pr√°ctica para aprender el hiragana.[/u] [/h1]

[b] Como estudiante de japon√©s desde escasos seis meses, este juego no me parece ni cerca la mejor forma de aprender el silabario b√°sico del japon√©s (hiragana) [/b], debido a que lo ideal es aprender el silabario en un mes o menos para un curso m√°s serio, pues es lo m√°s b√°sico. Entre las formas principales para aprenderlo puede ser con fichas de los caracteres, escribiendo palabras en espa√±ol con hiragana hasta memorizarlo, o si se sabe de antemano ingl√©s se puede usar la app de Dr. Moku, que ayuda a aprender el silabario de una forma bastante did√°ctica. Para maneras r√°pidas que cuesten menos o nada se pueden escribir varios p√°rrafos.

Sin embargo, antes de empezar a estudiar formalmente japon√©s, compr√© este juego, y fue el que me motiv√≥ a aprender el idioma, siendo que con la pr√°ctica no es tan dificil en realidad, y pude seguir de una forma m√°s intensiva. Ese es el punto fuerte de este juego y en el que se basa: quitar el formato de clase y ense√±ar sin hacerlo tedioso o m√°s f√°cil de dejar de lado. Antes de jap√≥n√©s, aprend√≠ ingl√©s por obligaci√≥n escolar, e intent√© aprender franc√©s, alem√°n y catal√°n, pero siempre los dej√© de lado y no continu√© por desidia y pereza. [strike]PERO ALG√öN D√çA LOS RETOMAR√â, LO PROMETO. [/strike]

Pero despu√©s de unas lecciones se puede notar que se avanza muy lento, lo cual a algunos les parecer√° perfecto, pero no es mi caso. En las clases de idioma que tengo, son tres horas a la semana, y en un mes nuestro sensei ya quer√≠a que supieramos este silabario y el katakana, el silabario que se usa para palabras extranjeras, y la verdad no era tan dificil si se usaba un m√©todo como los que ya mencion√©, y este juego en serio me parece que avanza lento en cuanto al aprendizaje.

Las lecciones consisten en las que son para ense√±ar las nuevas s√≠labas, que suelen venir con notas sobre vocabulario y cosas que son como el dakuten, o la pronunciaci√≥n de los tsu disminuidos, que son lo que en espa√±ol ser√≠a como la pronunciaci√≥n de una tilde o acento, pronunciaci√≥n de s√≠labas con "ll" o "ch", entre otras cosas. En ocaciones habr√°n lecciones extras con cosas como vocabulario o esa "ortografia" del japon√©s. Despues de estas lecciones, se pasa a el juego de JRPG cl√°sico, y se pueden repasar todas las lecciones.

Respecto a la jugabilidad, el sistema de juego es como el t√≠pico RPG japon√©s como Final Fantasy o la saga de Chrono, y tiene una historia simple que cumple con su cometido. En esta fusi√≥n con el RPG y las lecciones v√≠ que la idea suena muy bien, pero b√°sicamente s√≥lo se van respondiendo preguntas sobre qu√© significa cada s√≠mbolo, y ya. Ese es todo el sistema de combate: responder qu√© significa el signo del enemigo e irle haciendo da√±o hasta debilitarlo. Esto no s√© si verlo positiva o negativamente, porque es cierto que el practicar es la escencia del estudio de un idioma, pero se me volvi√≥ tedioso, y m√°s en partes que simplemente no alcanzaba a avanzar r√°pidamente al final del nivel, y al no matar a los enemigos a tiempo, va bajando la vida gradualmente hasta agotar los suministros y se complica mucho el juego.

Sin duda es importante que existan m√°s juegos anhelando como m√≠nimo lo que aqu√≠ se logra, m√°s  all√° de los juegos infantiles para ense√±ar a sumar y restar, que en verdad sirvan de material did√°ctico a personas de todas las edades. El juego dista a√∫n de ser una manera de entre las mejores para aprender hiragana, pero s√≠ puede ser de las mejores para motivar a empezar con el estudio de un lenguaje de una cultura tan interesante e importante como la japonesa. Como sea, cada qui√©n aprende una lengua a su manera.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203395756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1510789320}
review: This is actually a pretty legit way to learn Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067359292', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1512605753}
review:
Nice idea, terrible execution.

Sorry to say but trying to make learning a game is viable but definetly not in the way it was tried to be done here, while I can appreciate the effort put in the lessons and educational part of the game, trying to use RPG maker to make it was a mistake, the RPG part takes too much of the game and I dont think I should feel forced to grind with useless battles constantly of characters I already know until I am high level enough for the next part of the game.

The RPG aspect gets in the way far too much to be enjoyable, not to mention the gameplay part is horrendus.

I gotta say, good intentions, but badly planned.

Honestly you are better off using Duolingo or any other web resourse and study the characters at leisure instead of having to deal with the monotnonus RPG sections of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080341336', 'num_games_owned': 1527, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 914, 'last_played': 1512397260}
review:
Well, if you follow the instruction and take some notes, you really learn Hiragana, and even some words and phrases.
Kanas are well drawn and all is very well understandable.
I did a try at learning hiragana some years ago but I didn't really had success. Now I feel the accomplishment. If you want to to learn Hiragana with some fun, this is the way to go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198300194654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1505697766}
review: I love this game! while it lacks a little as a game, lots of grinding and lots of grinding, not much ability to build the characters as they all have their own equipment... the story is good and it definitively has its use, learning hiragana. by the end of the game, you'll have no problem recognising them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198187089942', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1498991563}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970523219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1527191990}
review:
It's a fairly simple, straightforwards RPGMaker-esque game at it's heart - balanced, progressive, steady story, that kind of thing.  What makes it stand out, though, is the combat system it utilises.

You gradually are taught Hiragana symbols - 5 or so at a time - and you encounter monsters that look like those symbols.  You 'attack' by choosing the correct phoenetic pronunciation of the targetted symbol, or else your attack misses.  There's something about the environment in which this act of recognition and repetition occurs that actually makes it an effective memory tool!

I'd advise playing through it in a few long sessions, rather than a little bit here and there, to optimise the retention process.  It's a fun way to learn!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056951643', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1510534587}
review:
Let's get my one and only gripe about the game out of the way. The battle system is a little too slow, but on the flipside of that I can see why it is like this as it gives you more time for the translations to sink in during the attack.

Other than that if you know nothing about Hiragana coming in then this will teach all the basics you need to know. The encounter rate is fairly high, of which it needs to be, and should give you enough encounters per area to memorize each set of characters. Once you reach a certain point of the game some of the characters that are introduced will stop appearing in favor of newer ones. Use the wrong translation and no damage will be dealt. Fighitng every battle will let you breeze through the game so long as you also did the sidequests.

When each of the lessons are presented the stroke orders of each of the characters will be, as well as sounded out, drawn out and then further allowing you to hear, and see, the sound and stroke order as many times as it takes. Some of the lessons will even give you some introductory grammer lessons in how they are used as is the case with „ÇÑ, „Å§, „ÇÜ, and „Çà as well as a few others.

As with any learning endeavor, the journey does not end here just because you beat the game.

Final rating is 5/5
