author: {'steamid': '76561197965743021', 'num_games_owned': 432, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1509941285}
review:
Honestly, you're better off with flash cards. Instead of playing Hiragana Battle for half an hour, I'd rather study flash cards for 10 minutes and play a good game for 20 minutes. I was hoping this would be a more interesting, fun, and engaging way to memories the characters but the slow battles and repetitive encounters just make it frustrating. There's no way to speed up the battle animation or customize the encounter rate.

As far as gameplay, the game plays like a typical jrpg / RPGMaker game. Your "attacks" are any of the characters you know. Enemies take 0 damage from attacks that don't correspond to their picture. There's the normal items like heals and revives, and you earn money and upgrade equipment. It's not bad, just... boring.

All that said, this is a good choice for kids that don't have access to other games, such as in a school computer lab.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152268387', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1550020565}
review: I bought this fun looking educational game to help me learn how to read and write Japanese. The game is a grand idea as in this RPG game. You learn how to write the Hiragana and memorise it by completing battles and lessons. However it is essential that you remember the Hiragana correct as you will have to get it right to win battles. If you get it wrong. You could lose the battle. Also in this game. You will learn how to write the Hiragana as well, so its quite a fun and interesting game to play if you are new to learning Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140180833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1509987765}
review: This game is awesome! If someone is at all interested in learning Japanese and they don't know hiragana, this game is an excellent, relaxing way to learn. There's some suspense, but it's mostly a good time throughout. It's kind of like Pokemon, but with hiragana letters. You don't just learn hiragana and pronunciation, but vocabulary, too. The levels and challenges give you a good sense of progress, which I think actually reflects your level of learning as you go pretty acurately. I definitely plan on playing Katakana, next.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987482655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1547519874}
review:
I've been learning Japanese for a while, but this game got me to learn hiragana in about a month. That's pretty amazing. The RPG part of the game isn't super duper, but it's just the vehicle to get you to learn hiragana. It really blew my mind how well it worked, what a great concept! I can't wait for the next installment.
This game is a MUST if you're trying to learn japanese, even if you hate these old school kind of RPG's.

author: {'steamid': '76561198344674029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1662488094}
review:
Amazing! This game helped me to learn so much. I had no knowledge whatsoever of how to read Hiragana, but this taught me in such an engaging way!
If you already know a lot of Hiragana, this game probably isn't for you, since it felt slow sometimes. But, if you are learning from square 1, this is the perfect pace! The side quests are fun and teach you even more, and it feels very fulfilling when you finally defeat Noburo. Can't wait to play Katakana War!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085128151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1509636484}
review: Learned hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094541874', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1509018013}
review:
Recommendation: Wait for sale

Hiragana Battle is a helpful tool for learning Hiragana for the first time, in an interesting and engaging way. Unfortunately, it has plenty of shortcomings, but I think it's still a worthwhile pick-up if you're looking for something to spruce up your studying a bit.

The game introduces you to Hiragana characters in sets of 5 and then you go on to "fight" them in various locations. In order to deal damage to an enemy Hiragana, you just need to provide the correct sound that Hiragana corresponds to.

Pros:
- Decent RPG with most of the basic elements you would expect (equipment, stats and skills)
- A kinda decent story, which is a welcome surprise given the game's purpose and subject
- A few cool music pieces
- Good in-game lessons and study guides
- Some vocabulary and phrases besides Hiragana are also provided

Cons:
- Bugs : I had a memory leak occuring around every 30 minutes. Extremely annoying, game would crash. Couple that with the game not having an auto-save feature and you can lose several minutes of progress at a time. Save as often as you can. 
- The game tries a bit too much to be an actual RPG which sometimes gets in the way of learning. Fall a bit behind in equipment or levels and you'll have trouble progressing, which can be annoying if you feel you've already learned the current set of Hiragana already. Thankfully it doesn't take too much to grind yourself back up to where you should be.
-  Another huge problem I had with the game is that the Hiragana that you fight were not really random and mixed-up. Each fight you get into is more or less against the same Hiragana in every region, making it very hard to learn all the Hiragana properly. As new Hiragana are introduced, you almost never fight any of the older ones, making it really easy to forget them. This should have been the best part of the game for learning and yet it's not there.
- Some Quality of Life improvements are really missing. Why is there no option to return to base immediately while in a dungeon?

Overall, it's an okay game but there's several improvements that could be made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250942048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1708784585}
review: The game play is SUPER boring, but, it does keep you focused enough to do the job you buy it for. Learning Hiragana. So if your question is "will it help me remember hiragana?" then the answer is yes. Just don't expect it to be as fun as you want it to be simply because it is made into a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015263866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1508822773}
review:
Want to leave this one mixed but no option,

While it does a good job re-inforcing the characters for absolute and total beginners, battles are copletely tedious because of it.

If you are _not_ a beginner, this is magnified and becomes unbareable to continue because you know its going to be so slow.

Good effort to help people, perhaps think of ways to make battle faster and make it more focused on learning instead of trying to also make it a JRPG. I think its ok for it to be cheesy and too easy if the point isn't a challenge but rather learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006591809', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1508612823}

review: Don't understand the bad reviews. This "game" is here solely for those looking to learn Hiragana in an easy way. If you're not interested in learning hiragana or japanese, don't buy the game. I went from knowing absolutely nothing about Japanese to being able to read Hiragana and having a small amount of vocabularly memorized after completing the game. $6.99 is a fair price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034211569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1505280640}
review:
Love this game. It's a fun way to learn Japanese, in a RPG form with the classic pixel style of "Secret of Manna".
This paired with the Duolingo app and flashcards app, i should be able to master Hiragana easily.
I started with Duolingo, but there are no explanations to grammar or the sorts...it just starts using words and building sentences before ever explaining how to actually build them or deconstruct them for your understanding, so i'm very grateful that this game actually goes into more detail.

The only negative thing I'd have to say about it is the amount of battles you get into. You have more battles than steps you take! (obvious exaggeration)

Can't wait to finish up and get to the katakana game and i hope you bring out a kanji game as well! Take my money!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055089474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 1473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1473, 'last_played': 1504608735}
review:
[b]As a learning tool[/b]
The game does a fairly okay job at introducing the player to each hiragana character, though with some problems.
It introduces the characters in sets, showing each one to the player and providing the sound and how the character would be written on paper. This would be fine, if it were not for the very poor choices in fonts which don't even remain consistent in the game, switching between caligraphy styles and more web-safe fonts.

Other than that, having to 'kill' each character repeatedly over the course of the game is a solid way of giving the player the chance to memorize each character's associated sound. The game also provides minor side lessons on actual words which help show how the characters would sound when pronounced together.

[b]As a game[/b]
This is where everything falls apart. You have to REALLY enjoy retro JRPGs to wade through this incredible mess.
The game is blatantly a very poor RPG maker product, including all the out of the box issues with no added quality of life enhancements.
Moving around is a pain, everything looks bad visually, battles are incredibly tedious and frustrating, the game demands you grind for levels, and worst of all: Featureless maze based dungeons.

[b]Together[/b]
The issues [i]Learn Japanes to Survive! Hiragana Battle[/i] presents as a game, seriously hinder the quality as a learning tool. The point of a learning game is to make learning interesting and fun, and this game did not do it. Battles were the main flaw, though wandering through empty mazes  while being battered with random encounters helped bring everything down.

The idea of the battles was fine. Fight hiragana characters by attacking them with the matching sounds. This was a good idea. The issue a culmination of having a long list of sounds to search through everytime you want to hit something, not being able to click directly on the character once you have the selected sound, then having to do this for each member of your party even if there's not enough characters to go around, possibly multiple times during the battle if you're not strong enough to kill the characters in one hit,  and then waiting for the battle to play out.

It would have worked much better if each fight was always 4 characters lined up, one for each party member, selecting the sounds for each, and then having it all go down at once with one-hit kills. Incorrect selections would of course result in party members taking damage, and any surviving characters would need to be attacked again, [i]but only by the party member they were lind up with[/i].

Hell, even a fast forward button for combat might have made it a less mind-numbing experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080980446', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1559, 'last_played': 1504635402}

Le seul point noir que j'ai relev√© assez vite √©tait le fait de ne pas pouvoir aller directement √† la partie de la le√ßon qui nous int√©resse, ce qui oblige donc √† revoir toute une le√ßon juste pour un truc parfois.

Bref en tout cas j'apprends bien, le fait que les le√ßons soit courtes et concises est un vrai plus pour retenir les choses petit √† petit, ce qui contraste beaucoup avec la r√©alit√© o√π on a l'impression que son prof va nous fourrer son cahier dans la bouche si on apprend pas toujours plus et plus vite.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031779570', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1721, 'last_played': 1503914431}
review: There are a few improvements that could be made but, overall, this is a really great way of learning Hirigana. It is especially good if you get the flash cards that they sell on their website to go along with it!   I will certainly be using the next game in the series to learn Katakana and I hope they come out with a Kanji version soon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018732341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1503781606}
review:
Fantastic introductory "course" with a significant focus on learning, I recommend combining it with other learning tools. Personally I took the Hiragana courses in the Duolingo app while playing the game.

Don't expect too much depth from the RPG side of the game, it's very simplistic and the most effective strategy will often boil down to kill - kill - kill. It's also easy to get significantly ahead of the power curve, allowing all of your characters to always go first and one shot most enemies until very late in the game.

That said, if you're here you probably care more about what the game offers in terms of learning, and it offers quite a lot. If you follow the games' instructions, not only will you get some great knowledge of Hiragana, very basic vocabulary and grammar, but you'll also end up with your own Hiragana guide, with some vocabulary sprinkled on top.

The game takes about 10-12 hours to 100 %, depending on how much time you spend in the learning sessions, and whether or not you grind experience.
Finally I just want to add that the game will seem very easy initially, but rest assured, if you have no knowledge of japanese and hiragana, there'll be plenty of challenge in the game if you just keep at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037510879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1503350358}
review:
Very creative teaching mechanism that works quite well! If I had to crunch down on papers and paragraphs of strictly academic learning, there's no telling how much I'd lose focus and how much more drained I would feel after studying.

Throw in characters, gameplay, sidequests, and buying new weapons and armor, and things are suddenly more interesting. Grinding to level up doesn't feel like grinding, it feels like studying.

After 10 hours of gameplay, 9 of which is actual studying, I've got most hiragana memorized. Due to the fact some are more memorable than others coupled with the fact that some appear in the game more often than others, there are a small amount that take me a few more moments to remember.

In any case, I'm very impressed with how effectively this game taught me. It probably helped me that I took two years of Japanese in high school some years ago, but by now I had completely forgotten most hiragana.

I definitely recommend this if you want to learn hiragana in a fun and interesting way!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004715298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1373, 'last_played': 1500257319}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053237029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1506806266}
review: If you want to learn Hiragana (first japanese alphabet you probably want to learn if you are going to learn japanese) then this game's a pretty good resource to start with, though you will need multiple resources for learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119342164', 'num_games_owned': 1191, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1502797029}
review:
A really nice idea, combining the familiar RPG maker format with hiragana practice. The lessons are very nicely done and well explained, and grinding repetitively actually has some point to it!

The learning is pretty slow paced compared to good old drilling with flashcards, no mistake. There's just too much gap between characters turning up in battles. But while I'm concentrating on drilling katakana, it's an enjoyable way to keep reinforcing the hiragana. My 4 year old, a big fan of RPG maker games, is using it to reinforce his English reading *and* learn characters with me.


Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075029764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1467436540}
review: An educational language game with an actual story to it.  Combines learning with a colorful cast and a wonderful fantasy setting.  If you want to learn Japanese while enjoying yourself, this is a game to sink a wealth of hours into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026637992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1692, 'last_played': 1565158618}
review: Excellent implemention of how game theory can be applied to educational purposes, pacing for each lesson was well placed and practive was fun rather than tedious and boring. Storyboard was good, but the RPG elements for the game would've been better if the characters had dynamic expressions that changed to fit the situation rather than statically smiling with the same portrait reguardless of what the character was saying or reacting to. I've really enjoyed this game, I actually was surpised at the scale of travel within the game and how easy it was to just play for hours. Great game, would definitely recommend for anyone interested in learning Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077987889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1501, 'last_played': 1502031571}
review:
TL;DR makes learning Hiragana fun and compelling, can be a bit grindy. Buy it if your primary goal is to learn japanese.

Throughly enjoyed the experience, teaches the basics of Hiragana in a fun and compelling way to keep us hooked and learning. The game can get a bit grindy at times, which while it inforces the concepts of Hiragana can be tiring and keep us away from the game. Plot is pretty thin, bad guy is trying to take over japan, you need to learn japanese to stop him. Get this game if your primary goal is to learn Hiragana. Menu system is abysmal and thankfully fixed in the sequel Katakana War. Get a pen, paper a drink and most importantly have fun! .Hiragana battle is a fantastic tool to helping you learn Japanese. And I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010241108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1502059403}
review:
This is my second japanese game, after playing Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana Battle. I'm glad I played that one first, because I don't think I would have given it a shot if this was my introduction to the series.

There's too many frustrations to enjoy the experience. On the learning side, the "how to draw" segments are painfully ambigious for some characters, making it hard to tell when a stroke is actually connected. I wish they would show us the font's rendering of the character during these segments, so that I can tell how to *actually* draw it. Additionally, vocabulary is almost always "here's the word, next" rather than any reinforcement learning.

The gameplay itself, though, is painful. Without a lot - a lot! - of grinding, basic encounters will shred your party. This makes for a very frustrating gameplay loop. I wasn't actually able to finish the game; I got to a point where there was a gauntlet of encounters without healing between, and I couldn't pass it without committing to a lot of grinding. I did cover the entire alphabet before tapping out. The encounter rate is very high, and the map design requires a lot of back-and-forthing, making combats a nuisance. Eventually I just started running from most of them, which probably contributed to my under-poweredness. Enemy encounters were frustratingly non-varied; most areas seem to have only two different sets of enemies, rarely going back to earlier characters.

I recommend this series' Katakana battle, but you're probably better off learning Hiragana somewhere else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137450965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1601679913}
review: Incredible, I loved the game. Easy to study Japanese in a fun and practical way. Super recommend it. Money well spent and with the purpose of expanding knowledge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057370688', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1511694781}
review:
Se voc√™ quer aprender japon√™s, leia o que vou dizer do jogo e algumas dicas sobre como faze-lo da melhor maneira.

A hist√≥ria do jogo √© simples: um cara invade uma vila e quer domina-la usando seu ex√©rcito de Hiraganas, ent√£o o que voc√™ tem que fazer √© duelar contra as letras, escrevendo seus significados, e controlar toda a situa√ß√£o.

O interessante do game √© que ele te ensina realmente o b√°sico: como √© composto o alfabeto japon√™s, para que serve o hiragana e as diferen√ßas dos alfabetos. 

O jogo trabalha com o sistema de decorar: voc√™ entra no mapa, fica andando por ele at√© aparecer uma letra X, duela com aquela letra e ganha pontos. Fazer isso 100 vezes faz voc√™ decorar aquela letra de forma n√£o t√£o r√°pida, mas bem divertida e recebendo pr√™mios no final.

O que acho ruim √© que, como gosto muito de idiomas, sempre aprendi a n√£o focar em muitas coisas ao mesmo tempo. Exemplo: se estou aprendendo a ler um s√≠mbolo, se torna in√∫til aprender a escreve-lo, j√° que meu foco deve ser APENAS para aprender o que √© o simbolo. Isso faz sentido pra voc√™? Se n√£o, vou te mais um exemplo: quando voc√™ √© crian√ßa e n√£o sabe escrever, isso te impede de falar? De entender o que √© dito? N√£o. Acontece que, n√£o precisamos saber escrever ou saber gram√°tica para falar um idioma, precisamos apenas aprender o idioma no geral e o resto √© uma consequ√™ncia de outro tipo de estudo. Estou dizendo isso porque no jogo, no meio da explica√ß√£o, ele te ensina palavras soltas e ensina a escrever, o que na minha vis√£o n√£o √© t√£o √∫til assim, j√° que eu n√£o posso perder meu foco em entender o que um simbolo X significa para tentar aprender uma palavra inteira ou at√© mesmo escreve-lo num papel.



Hiragana Battle √© um excelente jogo pra quem est√° come√ßando na lingua japonesa e, digo j√°, compre a vers√£o Katakana tamb√©m.

author: {'steamid': '76561198198275063', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1498861664}
review: Fast and easy way to learn Hiragana! The game mechanics need a little tweaking, but other than that, great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198207728292', 'num_games_owned': 44, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1501515256}
review:
I recommend getting this game if you are interested in progressing your Japanese and you have yet to completely mastered your Hiragana. This game brings some solid training which I enjoyed a lot. But before talking about the pros and cons, let's be clear that this isn't really a "game game", despite it's RPG format, in essence it falls closer to a "reaction-based flash game" that trains your language recognition.

pros: I am not a strong learner when it comes to reading off a book. I need various stimulation and hands on involvement to learn well. This game brings you just that, it forces you to think back and relate repeatedly. I find it vital to build that eye-mind recognition. And by a few hours you will have a pretty solid foundation to actually start learning applicable Japanese.    

cons: 1.The enemies come in a pre-set team composition, it would be much better if they are randomly generated. 2.Maybe it's the equipment used but the pronounciation of the materials could be done better, 3,When multiple Hiragana are put together they are pronounced differently then on their own, the game does not provide enough coverage on this.

But overall it is a nice game to get started with learning Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134461456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1500781899}
review:
I finally finished the entire game. It was a grindy adventure that I decided to play over a longer period of time. Hiragana Battle is a great game to test your hiragana (as the title of the game suggests). It does get repetitive (but that's the point of the game...learn by repetition) but sometimes I think the battles proc too often when I walk around.

I enjoyed the little portal things that make you hop around from room to room. I also like how the bgm changes near end game. I was surprised they had phrases and vocabulary included with the hiragana lessons. Overall the game wasn't difficult, I knew most of the vocab and phrases from watching anime. That's how simple it all is, which I won't complain about since this game really is beginner level. If you want to practice your hiragana, then this is totally the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969671154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1500586670}
review:
Great way to learn the Hiragana alphabet and the very basics of Hiragana grammar. Had zero experience with japanese and played from start to finish.

Production-wise it's basic RPG Maker stuff, but the educational content is great and well-paced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047524156', 'num_games_owned': 672, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1500489108}
review: I like the concept, but the game aspect is lacking polish. Backstory for characters I couldn't care less about and clumsy menus make the game drag. Can't say I would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171608855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1500490508}
review:
Este es un buen juego de aprendizaje, talves no el mejor pero consigue lo que promete.

Si eres de esas personas que les gusta aprender desde cero, este es tu juego, es cierto que podrias aprender los kanas en internet, pero el saltarte cosas importantes como pronombres y reglas gramaticales te dejaran lagunas mentales.

Lo recomiendo si quieres perfeccionar tu ingles y al mismo tiempo comenzar a aprender japones.
Lo mas importante es ser constante.

Como nota adicional, los desarrolladores escriben en repetidas ocasiones „Äå„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„Çè„Äç (konnichiwa) sin tener en cuenta que esta es una palabra compuesta con la part√≠cula "wa" „ÅØ, y su escritura correcta es „Äå„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„Äç (konnichi wa).

author: {'steamid': '76561198348467848', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1500229288}
review:
What a great way to be introduced to a new language!
It's great fun, and easy to comprehend. It's not that long, so playing it small bit by small bit is definitely the better way to learn through it, and probably accompany it with additional lessons on the side.
A more interactive use for the vocabulary learned may help more but as a way to learn the characters themselves, it's absolutely amazing.
You can't do much more, since barely any grammar is taught within the game, but it does arouse your curiosity enough to find ways to learn more (at least for me!).

review:

O jogo no geral √© f√°cil, voc√™ junta grana e compra os itens de ATK e j√° era, mas nada √© jogado, tudo tem uma hist√≥ria, um motivo de estar acontecendo e um motivo pra voc√™ aprender, e de tanto enfrentar esses monstros voc√™ vai acabar decorando. author: {'steamid': '76561198349237094', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1569156192}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039977517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1500116272}
review:
This game is amazing for people who need a little push in learning hiragana. It teaches you a set of hiragana at a time and makes you fight "Hiragana Warriors" with their sound. For example, you will see "„ÅÇ" and fight it with "a." There are certain segments of the game that reverses this and makes you fight "a" with "„ÅÇ," but unfortunately, you cannot revisit those sections--they're a one-time event.

The biggest downside to this game is that you cannot use this game to practice all the hiragana it teaches you. While you can revisit areas of the game and fight the same "blocks" they assigned, they never toss all the hiragana together outside of boss battles that you cannot revisit--hence why I'm about to link you to outside practice. The downside that you don't see when you don't practice all the hiragana together is that there are several hiragana that can easily be confused that are never presented together, so you might never realize it's a problem unless your practice.

I will always appreciate the devs for making the game and the enthusiasm they have for Japanese, but I would recommend You Can Kana for a straightforward experience of learning hiragana and being able to practice it all in one place:
https://store.steampowered.com/app/1031900/You_Can_Kana__Learn_Japanese_Hiragana__Katakana/

author: {'steamid': '76561198079495477', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1241, 'last_played': 1500080937}
review: It looks stupid yet it works, the classic RPG random encounter system works surprisingly well for constant exposure to newly learned symbols. However, the game tends to repeat the same symbols instead of varying them in order to remind the player of previous ones. Despite this, the player can always go back and explore the charted areas to battle earlier symbols. Overall, it does a great job of presenting the concept to beginners

Dank anst√§ndiger Final Fantasy manier, kann man die Schriftzeichen auch schon ordentlich fr√ºh verkloppen und erlebt den Lernfortschritt direkt mit, wenn man f√ºr das Erkennen nicht mehr auf den Notizblock schauen muss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136671120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1678299680}
review: "I play it for the story"

author: {'steamid': '76561198154504945', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1499660986}
review:
„Çè„Åü„Åó„ÅÆ„Å™„Åæ„Åà„Å™TAVE„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

This was wonderful. I just finished the game a little bit ago, and I've already purchased Katakana War. I was using Duolingo on my phone, but honestly, this game had me learning and speaking Japanese much faster. I can highly recommend this game for anyone wanting to learn the basics to Japanese. We all have to start somewhere!

+ Makes learning Hiragana simple
+ Battle system is easy to understand and gives much nostalgia to anyone who played JRPGs in the 90's
+ Very easy to view previous lessons
+ Side quest that teach you new words
+ A quick look into sentence structure. It's basic, but I believe it'll help me a lot.
+ No grinding required, but if you wish to, grinding is fun because you're learning the whole time
+ The soundtrack is surprisingly good and catchy. Wish I could get a download of it

- No real end game content. I was hoping for a place to battle that would help learn new words.
- Can be kind of too easy at times. But if you find it too easy, you can just run from any battle (except bosses)
- A few cities on the world map you can't visit. It's a small complaint, but it was leading me to believe there were more side quest and end game content. Nope lol.

All together, I'd give this game a 9/10. Great for learning, fun to play, and the story is simple but isn't boring by any means. Ready to see what happens next and learn Katakana on the way!

author: {'steamid': '76561198302739209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1062, 'last_played': 1664991792}
review:
OK This Game Is Awesome!!!!!
First of all for anyone who is starting to learn japanese, Go for the order Hiragana-Katakana-Kanji (Hiragana First).
second, This Game should take you from 15-20 gameplay hours depending on your focus level ( I took like 17.5).
Thirdly, This Game Isn't That Fun as you'd expect but not dull AT ALL!!!, the story was actually awesome, the finale was perfect and the way the game allows you to memorise symbols is clever and intuitive!
Side Quests give the game extra fun and more multi-tasking and finishing all of them will get you a reward ;)
After you finish this game "immediately" you should be able to:
1- Remember minimum 40 Hiragana (46 Total)
2-Read Hiragana (slowly but surely!)
3-Write Hiragana(not perfectly but surely!)
4-Understand very little basic Grammar notes
5-Know at least 10 japanese words (if you focus truly you can know like a 70!)

Drawbacks:
1-Game shouldn't cost more than 5$, my problem is that i live in Egypt where 1 dollar = 18.5 pounds so 2 dollars cause a huge difference
2-Combat can get boring especially when you get the same exact scenario twice in a row(3 times once!)
3-Some Maps will have Combat Encounters every 3 sec which sucks if you want to avoid them because you insured that you remember the Hiragana
4-Some Places on the world map aren't meant to be visited and will always be locked which can turn off the player after he finishes the game
5-Glitch where if you go to the ship (Won't Spoil) manually as of to the place you find it first at you will turn to a ghost
6-No AutoSaving System (Not really a problem unless you forget) BUT THEY REMIND YOU SO FORGET THIS ONE
7-You Can't Skip lessons when you review them which sucks when you forget like 1 of the symbols from a set
8-Can't customize players which isn't really a problem to be honest.


IF YOU WANT TO LEARN HIRAGANA, BUY THIS AND DON'T HESITATE!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198080486293', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1512653207}
review:
Im sorry, I have to say the game is really bad. For a B2P game.
I've played other FREE games to learn japanese with better quality than that. 
And NO.. you cannot say "Well its a RPG." There are WAY better RPG's out there for free... And im not even talking about the 3d ones. 

Only good points:
-Story is cool
-Characters are funny.
-Good for memorising Hiragana.. (IF you dont lose your cool over this HORRIBLE game system.)

The rest is sh*t (sorry):
-The menu is one of the worst ever
-The controles are HORIBLE..
-The combat system is HORIBLE and frustrating.
-The sidequests are sh**ty AF and at the first 10lvls they are almost INEXISTENT.
-The quest log is... ONLY for Sidequests... SERIOUSLY? SERIOUSLY???? 
-Cant skip the writing example when its not even needed to complete the game.. Wow.
-Map designed like labyrinth and its REALLY frustrating.


The game is NOT learning-Friendly AT ALL
This RPG was made for the skilled HARDCORE RPG players:
-No [Easy,Normal,Hard] mode choices.
-You have to go back to the main town to know what is the MAIN objectives.
-You CANT avoid enemies when there are "side activities" that are tied to the main progresion of the game.
-Health in this game is almost inexistant. 

Im not saying that a hard RPG is bad, I LOVE hard RPGs.... But WHAT THE FUCK? Its a LEARNING game.. 
And im not saying that Super easy game to learn language is better.. ITS WORST... 
And I think the one who made this game is a bit more on the RIGHT path to make a GOOD learning game.
But honestly.. 99.9% of Learning games i've played are all TRASH.
Seems like those who makes learning games.. either think, I can do the game.. so its a good game.
OR, The game is way too hard for a 1yo child. Gotta be easier..
Seriously I just dont get it... Seems like its IMPOSIBLE to have just the RIGHT learning game.
With money or not. I found one on my phone, and its way better tho.. I think its the best learning game ever made. 
I wont tell the name here cause it would be really sh*tty of me, but yah.. Just that..
Learning game dont know "Perfect middle". Its either stupidly hard (Like this one) Or Stupidly easy.
Both are not worth playing IMO. 
Whit that said, Id say this game would be "OK" with a dificultu system. But not worth 8$. Not at all. 
The story itself is the best part, and the only reason Im not gonna take a refund on this. 
But if you want to learn japanese.. this is not for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120990457', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1499101197}
review:
A fairly good study tool. It's good when paired up with old fashioned pen and paper. I recommend printing off some trace sheets to help make sure your characters are properly proportioned. The tips on making sure the kana are properly proportioned are definitely welcome, as are the animations, and have helped me tidy up my own handwriting a bit.

The game also includes some vocabulary, which is welcome. It's worth taking some notes throughout the game, as you'll be quizzed on them at the end!

As a side note, „Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ is repeatedly misspelled as „Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„Çè in-game. Do be aware that the former is the correct spelling.

I recommend it to anyone who's interested in studying Japanese. Just don't neglect using the traditional methods, too.

Overall good. Would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025215501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1501981204}
review:
This game is nice to learn Hiragana, but the game mechanics are pretty bad.
The fighting system plain sucks. You have to pick an action for all characters before the round starts, but you won't really know if the enemy you want to attack will still live, when the character finally gets to do his attack. If he already died, your move is wasted. The Guard action seems to be completely useless. You have to grind levels very early, or you will just get fucked over (even if you don't do any mistakes). The enemies you will fight against are not really randomized... it will happen pretty often, that you will fight the same ones over and over and over.... which really sucks because you have to grind.

The RPG is pretty basic and sadly just annoying. 

The learning part is well done. The pacing is nice and you get so see how the Hiragana are correctly written (stroke order) and how they are pronounced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148723607', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1506916981}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996838808', 'num_games_owned': 114, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1500688838}
review:
If you enjoy RPGs, you may enjoy this game. As a learning tool, I'd say do yourself a favor and skip this game. Instead, get Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War, which is much more refined and a great learning tool. Hiragana Battle had me chugging potions left and right, with me unable to keep my characters alive through simple battles. I think this game should be skill based, where I do well in the game if I am learning the Hiragana characters. Instead, it is grind based, where I do well only if I sit through repetitive battles with Hiragana characters I've already mastered, levelling up my heroes to a point where they can actually endure the enemie's attacks. Zones are long, with poorly randomized enemies. For example, the same three Hiragana characters will show over and over in a zone, and it takes away from learning individual characters, instead optimizing learning a set of unrelated characters.


One of the most frustrating aspects of the game is the combat system. If I have four of my heroes attack one Hiragana character, and the third attack kills the Hiragana, the fourth character will send his named attack to a Hiragana that is still alive, which is the wrong name, ineffective and a wasted attack. There is no way to tell how many attacks a Hiragana character needs to take in order to die, so this problem happens over and over again. Again, Katakana War fixed this problem completely, which is why I don't recommend Hiragana Battle. I'd say use something like Duolingo or Ankiweb for learning Hiragana, and use Katakana War to learn Katakana. This game is just a waste of time because of the grinding that doesn't scale with my actual knowledge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972269783', 'num_games_owned': 854, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1498422184}
review:
Learning a new alphabet is difficult, and it needs you to do a lot of repetition. I've tried several ways to approach learning hiragana, just for the sake of entertainment and not as a serious endevour.
Learn Japanese To Survive had an actual good approach to this, integrating repeating a hiragana character over and over until it stuck by making it an integrated combat mechanic. The problem is, that they wanted to fit the Final Fantasy-esque combat ontop it so bad, that it makes the combat extremely boring. Combat is basically this: A Hiragana character can only be damaged by choosing the equivalent English sounding word/letter. Damaged, not killed. So this means, if you know the character, you have to click the same sound multiple times to kill it. So you think for ~2 seconds what the sound is, use ~6 seconds to plot it in (multiple times) and wait ~20 seconds for your choices to resolve. Repetition is key to learning a language, but instead you end up using the majority of the time just finding the sound and waiting for it to resolve.

If voice recognition is good enough, a better approach would be a voice-controlled Guitar Hero-like game where you could get past the thinking aspect and just get the letters out on reflex. Learn Japanese To Survive instead wastes time on waiting and the wrong kind of repetition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000631340', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1597804220}
review:
[h1]Who said educational games had to suck and be uninteresting?[/h1]
It is kind of overwhelming when you get to learn a new language. Especially with such a complex language like Japanese.
I have just started playing/learning, and I am happy so far with this.
This game is more than just that, besides engaging into the story itself, it also serves it purpose without being too overwhelming with one thing at a time. Yes, there are free websites where you can learn Hiragana and such, but personally I need something to keep myself motivated into continuing on learning, and "Learn Japanese To Survive: Hiragana Battle" does that with the interactivity it offers, being a game made with RPG Maker. Plus said "free" websites usually start spitting complex words on you without even telling how is each letter/character pronounced.
One example, when I tried Livemocha, the first word they gave me was "Otokonohito" (man). How exactly is every letter in "„Åä„Å®„Åì„ÅÆ„Å≤„Å®" pronounced?! Is it Kanji, Hiragana, Katakana?!
Instead, "Learn Japanese to Survive: Hiragana Battle" started with the basics, with a simple lesson on vowels; how are they pronounced, how are they written and such.

Like I mentioned, I'm just getting started myself, but so far I can say I recommend this strongly to anyone that wants to learn Japanese from its basics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967430647', 'num_games_owned': 1648, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1494084500}

author: {'steamid': '76561198070484353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 318, 'playtime_forever': 3113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1562169758}
review:
Oncelƒ±kle Selamun aleykum.

[i] '' Bƒ±r kotu adam gelƒ±yor ve bƒ±rseyler yapƒ±yor. Oda ne! Degƒ±sƒ±k semboller!! Bas karakterlerƒ±mƒ±z koylerƒ±ne gƒ±der ve orada bƒ±rƒ±sƒ± Bu Japon alfabelerƒ± der. Ve artƒ±k sunu anlarlar [b] [u] Hayatta Kalmak ƒ±cƒ±n Japonca Ogren! [/u] [/b] '' [/i] 

Oyunun ƒ±smƒ±nden de anlayacagƒ±mƒ±z uzere Japonca'nƒ±n 3 alfabesƒ±nden (Hƒ±ragana, Katakana ve Kanjƒ±) [u] Hƒ±ragana'yƒ± [/u] ogrenƒ±p dunya'yƒ± kurtarmaya calƒ±stƒ±gƒ±mƒ±z bƒ±r [u] RPG oyunudur. [/u]

Hƒ±kaye, Grafƒ±k, Egƒ±tƒ±cƒ±lƒ±k gƒ±bƒ± unsurlardan cok basarƒ±lƒ± oldugunu dusundugum gƒ±bƒ± eger yakalayabƒ±lƒ±rsenƒ±z ozellƒ±kle ƒ±ndƒ±rƒ±mlerdende alƒ±rsanƒ±z gercekten parasƒ±na tam hakettƒ±gƒ±nƒ± anlayabƒ±lƒ±rsƒ±nƒ±z. (Ben dayanamayƒ±p ƒ±ndƒ±rƒ±msƒ±z aldƒ±ydƒ±m)

Gelelƒ±m oyunun ƒ±cerƒ±gƒ±ne bƒ±raz;
+RPG Tarzƒ± grafƒ±kte gerceklesen uzun bƒ±r hƒ±kaye ve ƒ±stege baglƒ± yan gorevler.
+Bƒ±rseyler yapmamƒ±z ƒ±cƒ±n Japonca ogrenƒ±yoruz ve her ders etkƒ±lƒ± olup ƒ±stedƒ±gƒ±mƒ±z vakƒ±t ƒ±stedƒ±gƒ±mƒ±z dersƒ± tekrar acabƒ±lƒ±yoruz.
+Yan gorevlerƒ± yaparak bƒ±r takƒ±m ƒ±fadeler (Selamlamalar, Yƒ±yecek/Icecek, Mevsƒ±m/Sayƒ±/Hayvanlar vb...) ogrenebƒ±lƒ±yoruz.
+RPG oldugu ƒ±cƒ±n epƒ±c fƒ±ghtlarƒ±n yanƒ±nda bƒ±rde boss battle'ler oluyor kƒ± oyundakƒ± ƒ±tem sƒ±stemƒ±ne dayalƒ± olarak hasar verƒ±yoruz veya skƒ±ll kullanƒ±yoruz.

[u] [b] Oyunda Senseƒ±'mƒ±zƒ±n verdƒ±gƒ± derslerden Japon alfabesƒ± ogrenƒ±p ƒ±lerlemek ƒ±cƒ±n savasƒ±rken o alfabelerƒ± bƒ±lmenƒ±z gerekƒ±yor. [/b] [/u]
Ornek olarak ''a'' harfƒ± karsƒ±nƒ±zda Hƒ±ragana yazƒ±lƒ±sƒ± duruyor ve sƒ±zde Romajƒ± yanƒ± ''a'' dƒ±ye cevap verƒ±yorsunuz ve dogru bƒ±ldƒ±gƒ±nƒ±zde Harfƒ±n canƒ± gƒ±dƒ±yor ve yok oluyor. Ilerlerde daha farklƒ± oluyor.

Oyunu ogrenƒ±rken dƒ±ger kaynaklardan da egƒ±tƒ±m alƒ±yorsanƒ±z anlamanƒ±zƒ± pekƒ±stƒ±rebƒ±lƒ±r veya daha da gelƒ±stƒ±rebƒ±lƒ±rsƒ±nƒ±z. Ders esnasƒ±nda [u] defter, kalem vb. malzemenƒ±z [/u] olursa onlarada yazƒ±p baska yerlerde tekrar goz gezdƒ±rebƒ±lƒ±rsƒ±nƒ±z (Sahsen ben 1 defterƒ± o amacla kullanƒ±yorum her sayfaya cƒ±zƒ±mƒ±nƒ± yapƒ±p acƒ±klƒ±yorum). 

Neyse bƒ±raz uzun oldu, buraya kadar okuduysanƒ±z ve memnun degƒ±lsenƒ±z kusruma bakmayƒ±nƒ±z. Eger oyundan memnun kaldƒ±ysanƒ±z bƒ±rde serƒ±nƒ±n devamƒ± olarak [i] [u] ''Learn the Japanese to Survƒ±ve- Katakana War!'' [/u] [/i] 'ƒ± da deneyebƒ±lƒ±rsƒ±nƒ±z. Onada ayrƒ± ƒ±nceleme yazarƒ±m bƒ± ara. Gorusmek dƒ±legƒ±yle...

review: I've spent like an hour and a half to 2 hours playing this game and I'm already capable of actually reading basic words in Japanese! This game is interactive and fun, the instruction is set at the correct level for absolute beginners, the artwork and style of the game looks great as a typical JRPG. author: {'steamid': '76561198065797714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1502162971}
review: What an amazing way to help you start learning a language. I firmly believe more games should do this. It's totally takes away any feeling of studying and makes you really enjoy learning, The game can also be surprisingly difficult, don't think you can just walk through these Hiragana Warriors. You need to make sure your characters are equipped with the right gear, make sure they are the right level, and have plenty of health potions on you! The game's storyline can go fairly quick, but you can replay any area to keep practicing. I can proudly say I can read all of the Hiragana characters now because of this game. Thank you! Now on to the sequel, Katakana!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997373039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1499515506}
review:
I haven't finished the game yet, but I find this to be a very good tool for learning hiragana.

The plot is there just to give you an excuse to go on, and it successfully manages to push you forward.

The game is almost too easy if you manage to quickly memorize the characters, but I suspect it doesn't aim to be punishing to not discourage learning. When your enemies are hiragana warriors, learning is fun. Teehee!

My biggest gripe with it was when in lessons the characters were showing up written a certain way, but usually were shown a bit different when it came to writing practice. But I must commend that the game mentions that the characters can be written differently in different fonts, and is generally quite educational about it.

The music can get a bit repetitive and the graphics are boring, but I guess that doesn't really matter for its main purpose.

I do recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077447212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1523593859}
review: This is like playing Pokemon but you can learn japanese instead of catching em all

author: {'steamid': '76561198028721033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1498523891}
review: My friend bought this for me as a joke, and when I went in I expected it to be a shitty RPG Maker game with no value. As it turns out, though, it's actually a great teaching tool that's finally pushing me towards learning Japanese, something I've wanted to do for years but never got around to. Now I legitimately want to buy the other Japanese learning games by this developer. If you legitimately want to learn the language, this is a great place to start.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049076233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1498356529}
review:
I honestly thought this was going to be a joke game that I would only play for 20 minutes. 

I do plan on going back to it, the game is actually amazing. If you didn't play it yet, you wouldn't understand.
You do have the basic rpg elements and you would think, "oh great, another RPG maker game," but its more than that! The elements of learning Japanese are actually very fun to use and learning the language actually seems enjoyable. The game does a good way of easing you into the language and using them in battle is a very fun way to study.


Don't judge this game at first glance. I did, and I was wrong. This game is F a n t a s t i c .

author: {'steamid': '76561197967431545', 'num_games_owned': 1384, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1498309837}
review:
I recieved this game as a gift and decided to see how it handled teaching kana with JRPG mechanics. I have already studied the language, and am rather fluent at it. So I would like to warn that I am not the intended audience.

Here is a list of the things that the game could have done much better:
- Better combat animations: Animations such as in old Final Fantasy games would not have been difficult to implement.
- Allowing you to type instead of selecting from a list
- Making the list from which you select answers in 5 colums with a seperate for the "n". Maybe they do this later, but it should have been like that from the start.
- Not have the first word that is thaught be "sushi", that is just shallow.


Things it does well:
- Early weapons remind me of Dragon Quest: First shields are pod lids. Heck the first polearm is a post (original and funny)
- Immidiatly teach how kana pronounciation can change by adding one of the two kana modifiers.
- The reward for my first battle (to the death I imagine) was 78 yen, I laughed

Maybe there would be more things that I would add, but it is not a game for me

author: {'steamid': '76561198035810296', 'num_games_owned': 1694, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1498127782}
review:

Unlike my other past attempts at learning, this time I actually feel like I'll stick to it. Kudos to the devs, I'll certainly be moving on to the Katakana War sequel next. Not only to move on with the learning progress, but I'm honestly interested in seeing the story progress as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126689861', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1497642860}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007413658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1497625555}
review: This is a great way to learn Japanese Hiragana, in my opinion.  It can be boring learning out of a book or class.  This combines my desire to learn and RPG games.  The actual game itself is extremely easy if you pay attention to the lessons.  So if you find that the game is too simple, it means you're learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012682054', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1497294796}
review:
Basic explanation:  the Japanese language has 3 different writing systems. Hiragana is the one you want to start learning first. This game will teach you Hiragana, as in you'll get to learn the symbols, much like you would learn an alphabet. Do not expect to learn anything else; vocabulary is limited, grammar is non-existent.

However, learning a few symbols by heart is easily the least interesting part of learning Japanese, and this game accomplishes its reasonable goal quite nicely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137220971', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1497456847}
review: This game makes you to learn and remember Hiragana characters as well. If you're trying to learn Japanese and also love to play Rpg games. This game is waitin for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075058897', 'num_games_owned': 114, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2927, 'last_played': 1497679164}
review: I do reccomend the game however I'm at a point where I've learned all the hirgana taught to me so far and even the phrases from the bonus quests. But now I'm losing every fight because the mechanics are dumb. Nearly every fight the hirana go first and if they attack immediately without giving me the option to run they essentially get free hits. It would be nice if there was a way to skip fighting and keep learning as you go (maybe there is and I can't find it). Other than that the sessions and what they teach is very fun and interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206179719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1412, 'last_played': 1501079792}
review:
I am pleased to say that - even though I have not quite finished the game and it's story, or even all of the Hiragana - this game is by far the best resource I've ever found for learning Hiragana so far, I myself am very passionate about the language and country of Japan and this game is a fun and interesting way to learn that has helped me very much, I'm even starting to use a Japanese mod on my phone's keyboard and am starting on using more honourifics when I speak, as well as using words I have learned along the way more with my English, intergrating the languages - which I would recommend when learning any language.
Hiragana Battle was so well done as a game and as an educational program that I have just purchased the Katakana War game and all it's DLC without a second thought, they have their resources on their website as well: Study-Japanese.net

In conclusion I would highly recommend this game to anyone wishing to learn how to read and write Japanese, Hiragana is a key Japanese writing form and I'm happy to say I'm learning it quickly with no issues at all thanks to this game.
This is an honest review and opinion and if you're interested in learning Japanese (Hiragana mainly but also key vocabulary!) then BUY THIS GAME. You will NOT regret it.

Also the background songs are catchy...

author: {'steamid': '76561198026633656', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1468569303}
review:
I find this title to be a good little RPG with a nice educational purpose. Since I already knew Hiragana before starting this I might not have been the best target group but even so it was good to brush up on them.

Some parts of it was well thought out, such as learning a few hiragana at a time and progressing though the story, but some were not so, such as hiragana often coming in a very specific order in the combats which kind off defeats the purpose as you can almost just automate the combats.

I liked the side quests available that had the intent of teaching the player a bit more about Japanese culture.

All-in-all it's a good title and recommended. I would like to see achievments and trading cards added to it though for even more enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039436965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1496130178}

author: {'steamid': '76561198216247857', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1496034174}
review:
TL;DR at the bottom.

I am not a big review writer so bare with me :D

I already knew how to read hiragana prior to this which made progressing a lot easier for me, but I had no clue how to write it.

This game managed to get me to grab a notebook and spend half my gametime writing each character over and over again across 10+ pages... I don't even like writing in English ffs.
After 9 hours of gameplay across 3 days, I can proudly say I can write all 46 characters by memory! 

Anyways,

Pro's:
- Really engraves Hiragana into your mind through repetition (a lot of it)
- If you don't mind grindy games like me, this game can be really fun.
- Can't remember a hiragana character? Level up your characters while doing so >:D
- Soundtrack is catchy

Con's: 
- As far as I can tell, there is no forced repetition of the vocab that you learn. *EDIT: Can confirm the game does test you on vocabs but it's not for a while so better remember them ;)
- Can be tedious if you do not enjoy the grindy aspect of the game.
- Not much to the story. Evil man forces you to learn Japanese :^)


TL;DR/Conclusion:
A good starting point to learning Japanese, but don't expect huge results. 
Very useful for learning how to read and write Hiragana. 
Repetition through lessons and grinding while doing quests. 
Decent soundtrack. 
Only get this game if you are interested in LEARNING. Yes, get them notebooks out. 
Welcome to school boys and girls.

Will be getting the Katakana version when I am comfortable with Hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154543648', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1495869160}

J'aime beaucoup l'id√©e d'utiliser les combats pour retenir ce que l'on a appris. C'est beaucoup plus amusant que de faire uniquement du "par coeur" ! author: {'steamid': '76561198179262913', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 895, 'last_played': 1495595496}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990702383', 'num_games_owned': 1622, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1150, 'last_played': 1493700112}
review:
Fun litle educational game. The Hiragaana lessons were solid, and the battles were a fun way to memorize them. The actual RPG gameplay, however, could have been much better.

I never felt like I was in any serious danger throughout the game. At the very beginning there were times when a party member got down to around half health or so, but they were very easily brought up to full health and I got through every level without ever once despairing that I may have to back out and try again.

After only a minimal amount of grinding to level up and purchase the most updated equipment, I could handle every level without any fear whatsoever. The party handled almost every encounter in one turn, before the Hiragana warriors even had a chance to strike. On the occasions when a battle required two turns and allowed the enemy to hit back, they either missed completely or did 0 damage. Only very rarely did they roll high and do something like 12 damage, which was negligible.

The magic system is a joke. The characters have an M.Attack parameter, which is strange because there are no magic attacks. There's a spell to give all characters a boost to defense, which is useless when the characters almost never get hit. There's a spell to give a boost to attack, which is also useless since every character except Misaki will usually kill an enemy in one hit. There's a revive spell if a party member dies... which will never happen. There are spells for removing conditions on party members, but even in the cases where a chracter is hit with an attack that imposes a condition, the enemy can still usually be taken out without having to deal with that.

The heal spells can be useful at rare occasions, usually at the beginning of the game. You can stock up on potions that do a lot of the same things as the spells, but you'll almost never need them. 

There are two main stages in the game. In the first stage, you're in your home country. In the second stage, you chase the enemies to Japan. After you've bought all the most updated equipment in each stage, money becomes essentially useless.

I accidentally stole a NPC's entire life savings by looking into a potted plant. It was only 2 gold. Made me feel kind of bad, but the game wouldn't let me give it back.

There was very little effort put into the game's story. I know it's an educational game, but it would have been nice if there was some effort to make it feel like the story wasn't just an excuse for learning. When you're directed to a new level, the directions are like, "In order to continue our lessons, you must go to such-and-such village" - why not even put some minimal effort into it and say something like, "We've got a tip that weird stuff is happening in such-and-such village, we need to go chek it out!"

I know that's a small thing, but attention to details like that would have made the game feel more like a game.

The menu system was bulky and awkward. They could have very easily fit more hiragana options on one screen without the need to scroll. The way general options were set up was also very inefficient, often requiring a lot of back tracking and fiddling around to do what you want to do.

Overall, though, I'd recommend this game because it teaches Hiragana well, and the RPG gameplay, while imperfect, was game-like enough that it distracted my mind from the tedium of studying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123351840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1428, 'last_played': 1493602751}
review:
it has both decent story and well done lesson structure (grinding is recomended for those who take japanese seriously)
with this and a few other third party apps on my phone i have now memorized the entire hiragana and katakana phonetics and if i can do it then anyone can!

author: {'steamid': '76561198143095523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2320, 'last_played': 1505363076}
review:
Well I learn abit of fundamentals in Japanese before I played this, so the learning part is kinda boring for me. Though the story for this game is quite common but it does piques interest on those who wants to learn Japanese.  

It's a bit time consuming especially the fighting part since you have to find the right word for the right character. And also, there's so many monsters spawn which making it more gruesome, but you can just escape the fight especially when I'm fighting against 4 characters. 

The BGM for this game is awesome. The art is ok. Overall, this is a good game. 

P.S. I found a bug on this game. When I went back, from Japan to Snowleaf village just to use the inn so I could save money. I went through Sunnyville village instead of going to the boat directly, and my character became invisible. I went in and out in the city to see if my character would appear again, but it didn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010276466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1492572272}
review:
First of all: I like the general idea of this game quite a lot. combining fun and learning is always the best way to teach and hiragana battle does pretty much precisely that. it is the balance of the two that is worrying me though.

frankly: the odd thing about hiragana battle is - at least in my opinion -  that the learning part is much more fun than the gaming part. 
yes, fighting the hiragana symbols by giving correct answers is a nice way to learn by repetition, but the rpg-part is at times too difficult and tedious. you never know how much health an enemy has- there are no hp-indicators. will one attack suffise or will you need more? will one strike instakill and the next attack on the same symbol be wasted? you just never know. initiative is unnerving and you often end up with half your team being hit or inconvenienced by effects like poisoning, sleep or paralysis, before you even had the chance to do some damage or counter the effects of the last round. you should constantly save the game because there is permadeath that throws you back to your last manual save and with battles as unpredictable as the ones in this game, the grim reaper always seems to lurk around the corner. one streak of badluck and your entire fellowship gets buggered with a fishfork. while the general controls are relatively intuitive and generally alright, inventory management and equipping are quite cumbersome.

these are things you will have to put up with between lessons. learning the symbols, vocabulary and writing is way more satisfying than going out into a ruinous labyrinth, fighting two battles and then having to head back to your base village to heal  and revive your little party over and over again. but then i am not a very rpg-o-phile person and others might be quite happy to endure all that.

if you are stictly looking for a japanese-learning program, have no experience with old rpgs and no patience, keep away from this game. if you like to play oldschool rpgs like the early final fantasys and on top of that learn some basic japanese, then this will be perfect for you. i do hope they refine the next title and make the game part less disruptive and more adaptable to the players preferences.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2420, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1558719193}
review:
This game is... interesting. It teaches you Hiragana (which might be the easiest of the three Japanese character forms) by means of an RPG, where in order to defeat a rogue Japanese mage who is going around conquering defenseless villages, you have to defeat his Hiragana warriors (literally soldiers made out of Hiragana characters). 

So the game teaches you how to read and write these characters. And a small amount of pronunciation. Considering this is one of three games I bought because... well, I want to see if the English subtitles on some animes I've gotten interested in actually are correct. And maybe watch it without subtitles or dubbing...

author: {'steamid': '76561198152550530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1490449432}
review:
I decided to try out this game since I'd been planning for so long to start learning Japanese, and I'm glad I did. Turned out, it's one of the most successful learning tools I've ever tried.

For me the game was addicting to play. It was fun, motivating and everything that learning a language has never been to me before. I had to control myself at times to not play too much of the game at once, because otherwise I would've binged it through in my opinion too fast.

The game itself is made simple and the RPG part of it isn't that astonishing, but I think that's fine because the main focus is, of course, to learn Hiragana.

So, if you would really like to learn Hiragana but don't have a lot of motivation to do it the old fashioned way, give this game a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982319343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1562533876}
review:
Took about 11 hours to complete, so it's already better value for money than *insert AAA FPS of the month here*! 

Goes over the Hirigana and some words, other people have taken issue with the fact that some of the words taught are usually spelled with Katakana but as the game serves to teach you the Hirigana I don't really mind this. Just don't worry too much about remembering the 'spelling' of the words being taught. 

In terms of actual gameplay, it's a very simplistic jRPG style game, you can attack, guard, use items, cast defensive/buff spells and buy new equipment etc. Now to be clear, I hate old school turn based jRPGs, even classics like FF7/8 and Lost Odyssey eventually wore thin for me before I got to see the ending, but mercifully this game requires very little grinding in order to gear and level up your team to the point where they're fairly powerful (mine were about lvl 32 by completion on an ~12 hour playthrough, aided by the bonus levels gained through completing side quests). In fact the joy of it was I liked grinding because it was helping reinforce the Hirigana I was learning. 

I will echo some of the other reviews by saying that you do begin to see patterns of enemy formations rather than having to identify 3/4 random enemies each time, but this didn't diminish the value of the practice too much for me. 

Finally I will say that this is not the first time I have learnt the Hirigana, the first being a few years ago, so a completely fresh learner may have a slightly different experience. I was also supplementing the game with Heisig's Remember the Kana (or was it the other way round) which is vastly quicker but much less fun than playing through this short game! All in all worth the very low cost for a fun way of learning/reinforcing the Hirigana and perfect for a long weekend/quiet evening.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978408150', 'num_games_owned': 907, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1623255736}
review:
excellent jeu d'apprentissage, quand on s'applique vraiment on arrive vraiment a retenir les lettre, je n'en suis bien sur qu'au debut encore, mais je recommande ce jeu a tout ceux desireux d'apprendre le japonais. 
(vous n'apprendrez juste qu'une des trois forme d'ecriture du japon ici)

author: {'steamid': '76561198060804712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1492372770}
review:
My first review ever! I cannot attest to having attempted to learning Japanese before so I know of no other method to do so. This game is a simple approachable way to learn the Hiragana. The game does not overload you with too much information and it bitsizes everything down to make it easily memberable.

I am writing this review based around the primary objective of this game which is a learning environment first and a game second. The game components themselves are playable and simple to understand. 

I would also recommend additional practice writing Hiragana characters on your own a little each day. No point in playing 5 hours straight otherwise you wont remember a thing by the next time.

Edit: I have completely learnt Hiragana thanks to this game, a more focused approach and you can probably learn it all in about 5 hours or so. Spelling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126300382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 952, 'last_played': 1491856371}
review:
Saw this game on sale, bought it on a whim. Best decision of the week(end).
I found myself up at 3am still scribbling notes in my book cause this game had me hooked. :D
Pros : 
Fun way to learn the characters.
Lots (I mean LOTS) of repetition
Allows you to recognise characters.
The writting animations are your best friend. <3
You actually learn this stuff :]
Music was nice too
I liked the blond; fun guy.
When you had to answer with hiragana to the english enemies. That was a good one
Cons: 
A little unballanced since once you reach a certain character line; the "older" ones stop showing up. Once youve reached the Na line (or maybe even before that) I never ever encountered any character from the Ka line.
Thus the groups that show up become predictable and come in a bunch. Ive had the group "yu" "yo" "ya" show up more times than i can count (since i kinda got lost on the map by being a noob) and they even showed up one after the other.
I dreaded going back to the fuji mountain for those colored stones.... jfc..... two steps; battle. I win; two more steps; battle. lvled up two times just to collect five goddamned balls. And ohh lord. I almost didnt find the Blue one.
I have yet to find that magic/legendary sword for that one mission.... i gave up 
Text to speech Japanese... need I say more? XD though it was humorous at times. (like all text to speech)

author: {'steamid': '76561198268946800', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1496575005}
review:
This is a very good game for learning the Japanese language. It took me 21 hours to complete the game, which is long than most people who reviewed this game, because the game suggests you write everything in a notebook but instead I wrote every little detail in the Notes application on my iPhone and iPad using both Japanese keyboards which are included in the Settings application. 

I made two different pages in the Notes application which look a bit like grids because on one page I wrote the hiragana letters in one column, how to pronounce them in the next column, then the same hiragana letters with dakuten marks (") or handakuten marks (o) in the next column and below those columns I wrote grammar particles such as „ÅØ, „Åå, „Çí, „Éò, „ÅÆ and „Åß„Åôwhich mean words like the, to, of, a, is and after learning all the hiragana letters this game also shows you how sentences, phrases or question are set up using these particles all of which I wrote down in Notes as well. The other page in my Notes application shows all the Japanese words I learnt throughout this game in hiragana letters one column, then in romaji (Latin/English letters) in the next column and then the English translation in the final column. If you have an iPhone or iPad or other smart device which you can easily access Japanese keyboards on I suggest writing down every little detail in a grid or table on an application like Notes the same as I have done. 

I am looking forward to playing the sequel Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War which I have also bought recently and am going to start now. If you want to learn kanji characters there is currently no game in this series for them but after I learnt all the hiragana letters from this game I decided to buy a Japanese language manga volume (specifically volume 1 of Âêõ„ÅÆÂêç„ÅØ/Kimi no na wa/Your Name) and it nearly all has hiragana letters or kanji characters and next to each kanji character it shows you how to write it in hiragana letters too so I can just translate everything I don't know yet online by using hiragana letters and learn kanji characters at the same time (which I also write down in my Notes application) so this game was very useful for helping me read my manga too. If you can find a Japanese manga volume like mine with hiragana letters next to kanji characters I think it would be very useful after learning all the hiragana letters from this game to learn kanji too while waiting for a speculated sequel in the Learn Japanese to Survive for kanji characters.
